PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Why has Minister Sharp's aviation adviser written to a member of the Airservices Australia board requiring him to sign an undertaking to resign whenever the minister asks? Isn't it a fact that the Air Services Act clearly limits the circumstances in which a minister can sack board members? Which other members of statutory boards have been required to sign an unconditional resignation statement in order to be appointed or reappointed? How do you justify this unprecedented action which will nobble the independence of all statutory board members forced to sign these resignations? Do you concede that forcing board members to sign these letters will ensure that only toadies occupy positions on statutory boards appointed by this government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit rich being lectured to by this crowd, who turned the appointments into an art form. Merit was about the last thing you ever took into account.
—Jim Short said that—

—Jim Short has far better qualifications than you have. I would have thought that you would keep a bit quiet on that as well. The fact is that in this area there is legal advice which confirms that such letters do not breach the relevant sections of the Air Services Act.
—Are you going to table it? Table the advice—go on.
—Order! Senator Alston, proceed with your answer.

—He's very unruly. I don't know whether he gets paid extra for this, Madam President. I can understand the frustration at not being there on that one day in September, but I will simply answer the question in the appropriate way.

ANSWER.PARA: All prospective board candidates who were asked to sign such a letter, stating that they would offer to resign if requested to do so, have willingly complied with such a request. Mr Sharp has legal advice which confirms that such letters do not breach the relevant sections of the Air Services Act covering appointments to the board of Airservices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you indicate how many board members have refused to sign, and have they been appointed or reappointed? Secondly, now that you have told us that Mr Sharp has legal advice, will you table that advice so that all Australians can see that there is supposedly a transparent process of appointment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a supplementary; that is just a regurgitation of an interjection from the back row. If you had wanted to ask that question, you would have asked it. Unfortunately, you were not even listening to the answer that I actually gave you. It was a fairly short answer, but I was trying to cater for you; I was trying to be helpful.

ANSWER.PARA: I can understand why Senator Schacht might be distracted in this matter, as would anyone who saw that little story in the newspaper a few weeks ago about Senator Schacht being under great pressure on the domestic front. And then his spokesman said, `No, we have still got a constituency. It is basically the silent majority in the disgruntled unionists.' Fancy coming into the parliament and representing the disgruntled unionists of Australia. That is the level to which Senator Schacht has sunk. What he did not hear was this: that all prospective board candidates asked have willingly complied with such a request. So why get up and ask a question about how many people agreed to sign? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Will the minister explain to the Senate why it is in Australia's national interests for there to be a balanced equitable outcome on greenhouse gas emissions? Secondly, does the government's policy on greenhouse gas enjoy bipartisan support?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an important issue, and Australia is contributing to a good greenhouse outcome in the Berlin mandate process in the lead‐up to the Kyoto conference. Australia does so because it accepts that climate change is occurring and that steps must be taken to protect the environment. We believe that for there to be an effective international outcome in reducing greenhouse gases it must be fair and achievable. In other words, a successful agreement in Kyoto will be one that is fair and achievable. It follows that we are not in favour of a discriminatory approach, where the impact falls unfairly on some nations. We are not in favour of unfair sacrifices, and that is of course why we have argued the position for differentiation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth remembering to this background that Australia produces only 1.4 per cent of all world greenhouse gas emissions. Notwithstanding, therefore, that whatever happens in Australia will have very little effect upon the global outcome, we are still prepared to carry a reasonable burden but we are not prepared to sell out Australian national interests to do so. In particular, for the benefit of the Australian Democrats, we are not prepared to sell out thousands of Australian jobs.

Our position is clear and unequivocal. As we move towards Kyoto one would hope that that position would gain support across the parliamentary process. In that light, we are somewhat disturbed to see some signs that the Labor Party is now moving—in some misjudged effort, I suspect—to gain support from minorities within this country. On 25 June, Mr Beazley said:
I would be reluctant to go down the road of committing ourselves to mandatory targets . . . We don't commit ourselves sight unseen to anything.
That seems a fair and reasonable statement. But what did he say today? He picked up on Mr Evans, who decided to take the lead. I will deal with Mr Evans first. He said:

We do see a case for targets: the consensus in the past within this country has been in favour of voluntary targets, but if the consensus internationally moved towards something more binding I don't think we'd be wanting to stand out against that.

In other words, we would not want to be standing up for Australian jobs; it is better to move towards the international consensus. Mr Beazley, not prepared to allow Mr Evans to get out in front, now says:
The international consensus is moving towards mandatory targets . . . we cannot afford to be a rogue and stand outside on international consensus.

It now seems that Mr Beazley and Mr Evans are moving towards demanding that Australia sign on to legally binding targets, perhaps at the European level, that will result in the loss of thousands of jobs, without even knowing what those targets are.

Why do I say at the European level? Because Mr Evans, the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party, hinted as such on his last international tour. He got to England and talked with his friends from government in Great Britain and decided that we should be adopting a different position, not an Australian interest position. He said:
I had an absolute earful . . . from a number of people in Europe last week, including the British Foreign Secretary who said that the Australian government was simply not credible.

In other words, what he says is back the British position—a 15 per cent reduction that would lead to the loss of thousands of Australian jobs—rather than an outcome that is fair and achievable. Madam President, this is a vitally important matter and it is important that the Labor Party supports a reasonable outcome rather than one based on selfish interests. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. I refer to the Prime Minister's press release of 16 September announcing your new appointment as minister for the information economy. Can you inform the Senate what this new responsibility actually entails in terms of resources? How many additional APS employees do you get to assist in your new responsibility, what additional funds have been allocated to your portfolio to establish the national office for the information economy and where have those funds come from?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to explain to the Senate the importance of the information economy because, quite clearly—
—Try answering the question as well.
—That is what the question was all about. What was the first part of the question? You wrote it; come on. The first part of the question was: would the minister explain what it involved? Right?
—Explain what it means in terms of resources.
—What it means in terms of resources is that there is an amount of money that has been set aside.
—How much?
—We will announce that when we are ready.

ANSWER.PARA: I know precisely. The issue is whether—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—There are discussions currently taking place about the precise amount, but there is an amount which I have in mind which is being discussed within government. Let there be no misunderstanding: we have a very clear idea on the way in which this should progress.

ANSWER.PARA: We do not have an obsession with boosting the CPSU and ensuring that we maximise the number of public servants in the office any more than we do in doing anything other than making sure we have the best quality advice. This will lean very heavily on the private sector. We want to make sure that the legal and regulatory regimes that are in place will facilitate and not impede the growth of on‐line service and electronic commerce. It is very important that adequate resources are available but we also expect that there will be a lot of assistance provided by the private sector. If you look at the press releases that have been inundating us in recent times, you will see that overwhelmingly the private sector is wanting to be helpful and to assist the government.

BREAK.PARA: They are not talking about putting money on the table. That is what you do not understand. You think you have to buy these things. Poor old Senator Lundy completely misunderstands. She thinks she just has to put out a press release, get the Canberra Times to take her name off it and run it as some sort of news story. There is a lot of misunderstanding on these issues.

It is a bit unfortunate that, if you are as computer illiterate as some of those on the other side, you are obsessed with how much money is going to be spent on it. We are not concerned about that. There will be the very necessary resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know.
—I do know. I am not in the process of telling you until we are ready.
—Tell us.
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—Have you got the letterhead printed yet, Richard?

—No. If you think we are obsessed with simply making announcements prematurely before we have done the necessary homework, then you have it completely and utterly wrong. What we are in the process of doing is establishing the most appropriate complement of staffing and the most appropriate structure to ensure that people out there understand the real benefits of the information economy and understand that the government is in the business of enabling as many people across‐the‐board to take advantage of those services.

BREAK.PARA: You can only go so far. Quite clearly there are going to be some who will be completely left behind, who will be drowning in a sea of ignorance and will not want to get on board. We will send you the releases in due course and will be happy to translate them for you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will the Office of Government Information Technology be transferred from Finance to your portfolio as part of these new responsibilities?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I have answered the question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Eggleston.

INTERJECT.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President. I simply want to ensure that my `No' answer was recorded—not, as this mob seems to think, that I was simply referring to the earlier part of the question. The fact is, I answered the second part. I hope that is recorded in Hansard .

—Madam President, I have a question for the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Could the Minister inform the Senate of any new resource developments in Western Australia which will benefit not only the Western Australian but also the national economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Eggleston very much for that question. I am absolutely delighted, Madam President, to advise the Senate of two major projects in Western Australia. The first of those is the Rio Tinto development at Yandicoogina in Western Australia, which will represent a $705 million investment and which is expected to come on stream in mid‐1999, less than two years away. This iron ore mine will initially commence production at five million tonnes per annum and, depending on market demand, will increase to 15 million tonnes.

ANSWER.PARA: It is worth pointing out that during construction of that mine—the ore treatment plant and transport infrastructure—the work force will peak at around 800 people. The permanent mine work force, direct and indirect, is expected to be in the order of 600 real jobs.

As regards the second one, the Asia‐Pacific region provides growing opportunities for partnerships in the Australian iron ore and minerals industry. China Steel recently announced its expansion of an integrated steel output and a large scale integrated steel project being progressed toward development by the Yieh Loong group. In fact, later this week I am to meet the president of Yieh Loong who is visiting Australia.

We are witnessing a number of new partnerships. Probably the most interesting of all is the merger of An‐Feng Kingstream—Kingstream being an Australian operation, I might say, run by Mr Ken Court. An‐Feng is the Taiwan company involved. They have created an integrated national steel producer with net assets of more than $A1 billion, paving the way for a project to develop a $1.4 billion steel mill near Geraldton in Western Australia.

This mill aims to produce steel slab to feed the requirements of An‐Feng's Taiwan steel rolling mills, generating exports of over $A750 million per annum by the year 2001. More importantly, the mill will provide for a massive employment generator with the work force hitting a construction peak of around 2,000 and a permanent work force of 900. This translates into indirect employment of around 3,500 real jobs.

Madam President, this project is strongly supported by the West Australian and federal governments. It has received the focused attention of Bob Mannsfield, major project facilitator in the Prime Minister's office. The department of industry has given it major project status, and the project facilitation unit in the Department of Primary Industries and Energy has given it its undivided attention. I met the chairman of An‐Feng, Madam Wu, earlier this year and again more recently on a private visit to Taiwan.

Madam President, these two projects testify to the private sector's faith in the Howard government as a sound regime in which to invest. With the government's major project facilitation unit, low interest rates, a favourable investment climate and the active pursuit of greater markets for Australia, the resource sector and the downstream processing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are the words underlined now, are they? You are reading a bit more loudly.

—Senator, you should be supporting the downstream processing that comes with An‐Feng Kingstream. This will lead to a proliferation of small business, the growth of regional development and more real jobs for Australia. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, do you support competitive tendering for IT outsourcing in budget funded agencies? Do you believe there should be competition for these multimillion dollar contracts? Will you be intervening to overturn Mr Fahey's decision to give $30 million worth of government business—the Department of Finance's IT operations—to a large multinational company without any competitive tendering process?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The government certainly believes in getting value for money and—
—What about competitive tendering?

—not catering for simply what your mates in the union movement might want. We actually take advice about what is in the best interests of taxpayers, and our agenda is, therefore, fundamentally different to yours.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me be quite clear, Madam President. The decision to which Senator Bishop refers was a decision made by the Department of Finance. On 18 September this year, IBM‐GSA was awarded a five‐year contract to supply IT information services to the Department of Finance, and that contract will see Finance's IT infrastructure costs almost halved over the next five years. I know that is the last thing you would be interested in, but it is actually very good news for taxpayers. The projected savings exceed $25 million, or about 45 per cent of projected spending over five years.
Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just be patient. I know you are not the slightest bit interested. I saw that silly little press release you put out the other day saying that you believed there had been a failure of due process and this had resulted in multinational companies securing a contract, et cetera. You have no idea. You are not interested in finding out the facts. You are simply trying to get—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You did not get much otherwise, so I can understand why you are indeed very grateful. The reality is, of course, that it was an extension of the Department of Veterans' Affairs' contract awarded to IBM this year.
—It was a shonk.
—Why don't you just wander outside and say that, and we can have a decent assessment of the merits of the argument?
—It was a shonk.
—Order! Senator Faulkner and Senator Alston will cease shouting at each other across the chamber.

—Earlier in the year there was a contract with the Department of Veterans' Affairs which had been awarded to the same group, IBM‐GSA, following a fully competitive tendering process. Part of that contract had allowed for a 100 per cent volume expansion. All right?
—Tell the truth.

—If Senator Faulkner somehow thinks that he knows better than anyone else and that he has got the answers to riddles that he creates by himself, then I would hope that he will get out there and explain why this is all a massive untruth. I have not heard you making any mention of the contract allowing for a 100 per cent volume expansion. The awarding of the contract is consistent with the government's procurement guidelines which clearly state that agencies should ensure that costs incurred in promoting competition are commensurate with the benefits received.

ANSWER.PARA: What is being suggested here is that somehow the Department of Finance was acting improperly in not going to tender on the basis of the latest contract whereas, as I have explained, in view of the earlier arrangements that have been entered into with the Department of Veterans' Affairs, this was a natural flow on. As you would know, and as I am sure we would find if we went back through your grubby history in government, there are very many savings to be derived from applying the procedures and the lessons learnt. If you have got a success story in one instance, are you suggesting you should not be allowed to apply that again—that you go through all the same processes?
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in explaining it any further, Madam President.

—My question is to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's forecast yesterday in the House of 90,000 job losses from stabilising greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels, and his citing of ABARE research which assumes that a carbon tax of $900 per tonne of carbon emitted would actually be needed. Minister, are you aware that a carbon tax of $900 a tonne is so massive that it would raise over $54 billion a year or about $600,000 for every one of these jobs you reckon is going to be lost? Are you aware that this tax is about 10 times the rate the Industry Commission found would be necessary to reduce greenhouse gases even more? Isn't it the case that the claims by ABARE being cited by the Prime Minister in his scare campaign are becoming so ludicrous and so extreme that they are likely to undermine Australia's already shaky international position? Surely it is about time that our Prime Minister stopped this shonky scare campaign.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I would never describe standing up for Australian jobs as a shonky campaign. I think that this distinguishes pretty clearly the position of the Australian government from the position of the Australian Democrats. What the Democrats are arguing is that Australia should sign on to an arrangement that will disproportionately penalise—do not shake your head, Senator; this is your position—Australians as opposed to others.

—Madam President, on a point of order: the minister is presuming that I have a particular position and is giving that back to me instead of answering the question. My point of order is one of relevance. Would you please ask the minister to refrain from trying to suggest what my position is, actually give the government's position and answer the question?
—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Hill, you are aware of the question?

—Certainly, Madam President. I am answering the question. The point is that the Democrats support a mandatory uniform penalty, presumably at the European level, because they will take the lowest common denominator in this instance—15 per cent off 1990 levels—which will result in the loss of thousands of Australian jobs if it comes to pass. There are not many others, apart from the Australian Democrats and Senator Brown, who are arguing that position. It really is extraordinary. It is even more appalling when the Democrats write letters to the chairmen of international conferences urging that they do not believe the Australian government on these issues, I might say.

ANSWER.PARA: The areas that will suffer most are those within regional Australia, particularly those related to energy producing industries—areas such as the Hunter Valley. It was astounding to hear Senator Campbell this morning talking about the loss of jobs in Newcastle as a result of BHP's decision. I can tell you it will be as nothing compared with the loss of jobs in the region as a result of Australia's signing on to a European uniform and binding target. The Democrats should concentrate on that—the loss of jobs in the Illawarra, the loss of jobs in the Latrobe Valley—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bowen Basin in Queensland.

—The Bowen Basin in Queensland, as my colleague says. These are the areas of regional Australia that would particularly suffer. But the worst thing about it all is they would suffer for no global benefit, because not only does Australia only produce 1.4 per cent of global greenhouse gases, but any reduction that would occur will be taken up by the developing countries that within a few years will be producing more greenhouse gases than are currently produced by the developed world.

ANSWER.PARA: Within the five largest emitters, there is Russia plus two developing countries—China and India. China and India will not have these new penalties on them at all. What the Democrats are advocating is that efficient Australian industry be exported, transported—`leakage' is the word that is used in the jargon—to these countries. It will not result in a better global outcome because the processes will be conducted offshore. All it will result in is a sacrifice of Australian jobs. The Australian government will not do that. We want a good greenhouse outcome, but we want to preserve Australian jobs. We will stand by that position whatever Senator Lees and her colleagues say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. All that the minister has said is based on the shonky research that we have heard about in this chamber time and time again. In a dorothy dixer earlier, the issue of balance and an equitable outcome was raised. How about having some balance in the information that the Australian people are getting? For example, the research by the Centre for Policy Studies, mentioned previously by Senator Parer as refereeing the MEGABARE results, shows a very different outcome. Their research shows a different energy tax mix that would cut greenhouse gas emissions by 12 per cent and increase employment by 55,000 jobs. Why doesn't the Prime Minister give the Australian people all the information, give us the full picture, cease being a lobbyist for one section of industry and start being a leader?
—Hear, hear!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to hear Senator Bolkus say, `Hear, hear!' I guess that means that he is signing on to the new Beazley position on this matter; that is, to advocate that Australian jobs should be sacrificed for the benefit of feeling good. This is not a feel-good debate.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections from both sides at the present time, and it is difficult to hear.

—This is a very serious debate about contributing to a better global outcome on greenhouse gases, consistent with each party accepting a fair share of the burden. We want Australia to do that. A fair share is one that takes into account the particular structure of individual economies. That is all we are asking. Just because we are a very efficient producer of energy and energy related mineral products, why should Australia be penalised? Surely these processes should take place in the country that is the most efficient producer and user of energy. In many instances, this is Australia. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, can you confirm that Geoff Seymour, the First Assistant Commissioner of the Information Technology Services group at the Australian Taxation Office, has quit in disgust at your government's IT outsourcing policies? Are you aware that he has told the publication Computer World that, `Fahey and others do not seem to realise that achieving a best value for money result does not always only mean choosing services provided by the private sector'? Isn't this yet another indication that your IT outsourcing policies are misguided and short-sighted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read some reference to some disgruntled former employee. I am not sure whether there was a direct quote attributing words to that person or whether it was simply a so-called background piece. In any event, anyone is entitled to express a view as they depart the service and to, no doubt, put the best possible gloss on their frustrations. People do, in fact, leave for a whole number of reasons, which are not always related to government policy.

ANSWER.PARA: All I can say is that, if what is being suggested here is that the government is not interested in value for money, that somehow the government should not be out there exploring all the best opportunities to ensure that IT outsourcing is part and parcel of a much better approach and more efficient ap proach to delivering IT services, then you are suffering from the same ideological fog that most of your colleagues suffer from; that is, by reducing the argument to its absurdity, what you are saying is that you should never go to the private sector. Whenever we do, you say that we have an obsession with the private sector and, presumably by imputation, we should not be going down that path.

We are going down that path for a very good reason. I have already indicated the massive savings that have derived to government and the taxpayers from the IBM arrangements through Veterans' Affairs and now through Finance. I would have thought that would be a cause for celebration, but I can understand why your preselectors are very unhappy with that. To the extent that it goes outside the public sector, your power base is reduced. I understand that. I think we all know that, if you had your druthers, you would have everything being given to your mates. You would have everyone paying irrespective of the value. You would not be looking at trying to ensure that the taxpayers are better off as a result. That is our approach; it is not yours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, seeing that you have raised the private sector, let us hear what they have had to say. Mr Seymour's voice was hardly one in the wilderness. Are you aware, for example, of the comments made by Mr Ron Gauci, the Managing Director of Melbourne IT company Ausmosis? At an industry conference last week, Mr Gauci warned, `The mad rush to outsource IT functions will leave Australian organisations without the in‐house skills they need to handle IT projects critical to the development of core business functions.' Are you satisfied that it is possible to separate IT from the core business of every government agency whose IT you are proposing to outsource?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —You quote one person who, presumably, has an acute vested interest in seeing as little as possible outsourced because that way you run the risk of a whole of government approach, meaning that you can derive very substantial benefits from going to a smaller number of contractors. I can well understand the chagrin that might be experienced by some individual contractors. But that does not detract for a moment from the principle that underlines the government's approach; that is, to ensure that we get the best value for money. If you want to get up and rabbit on about the evils of the private sector and how this is simply designed to take—
—This is the private sector talking about you. This is the private sector saying you are a dope.

—No. One person from Ausmosis was quoted as saying that he would prefer another approach. All I am saying to you is that there are a lot of people who miss out on tendering arrangements who would much prefer a different approach to be taken. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister Newman has introduced legislation into this parliament which will see a significant number of young people lose their entitlement to income support under the common youth allowance and, of course, they will become an additional burden on their family. Will the consequent outlays of that family be regarded as tax rebatable under the taxation system and, if not, why not? Would we be able to get a response to this prior to our discussing this legislation in the chamber?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question from Senator Harradine, the common youth allowance is a very important initiative which has been brought forward by this government. It is an initiative which we think has very widespread community support. Senator, I would hope that you would be able to support this particular initiative, which I think most people would regard as a fair, equitable and sensible measure.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to what I would have to say is an obscure part of your question, I will have to take note of that and see if I can give you a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, did you accuse Western Australian Deputy Premier Hendy Cowan of seeing fit to resort to crass political gamesmanship involving GWN's remote area television conversion program? Did you in fact promise him federal government assistance to subsidise the cost of the new $1,000 decoders? How did Mr Cowan gain the impression that you had made such a promise? Would you agree with Mr Cowan's criticism that Western Australia is not attracting a sufficient amount of communications outlays from the federal government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I need to tell anyone in this chamber about Mr Cowan's propensity for making erratic grandstanding statements. So whatever you attribute to me as saying about him, I have no doubt is correct.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got that off my chest. I could go a lot further, but I won't.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a very important question that does exercise the minds of government at the moment and that is in relation to remote area broadcasting services. There are some 12,000 people affected by the conversion from analog services to digital. The problem derives from the fact that you have got different carriers offering different services and, therefore, there is a need for different set-top boxes. Optus is scheduled to allow its satellite services to be connected to one of the broadcasters whereas Telstra via Panamsat has made a separate arrangement with GWN and perhaps with Imparja.

The problem is that it does cost money. It costs in the order of $1,000 or so for that conversion. I can certainly understand the concern of the residents who will find themselves in the position where they are deprived of traditional analog services and are in effect forced to go for digital but who do not have all of the funds necessarily required to pay for that conversion.

BREAK.PARA: We have said that we are prepared to allow the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund to examine this issue. My office advised Mr Cowan's office last week that we proposed to do that. It was only on the strength of, presumably, the receipt of that phone call that Mr Cowan saw fit to go out and say something which he had already been told was incorrect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really? That is serious.

—He chooses to do this. It is not the first time, I have to say; he has got prior convictions. Let it be clearly understood that Mr Cowan's press release concerning RABS digital conversion was erroneous in several respects, including the assertion that RTIF funds would not be used to assist meeting consumer conversion costs. The board is yet to make a decision.

BREAK.PARA: There are a number of other matters in that release which are also dealt with in a release that I put out last Friday night. They will speak for themselves.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has been a very important body in protecting the rights of Australians against discrimination. The Attorney-General has today announced reforms to the commission. How will this restructuring particularly enhance the role of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Payne for her question. She is well known for long having had an interest in human rights matters generally and in discrimination against women in particular. I would have thought that honourable senators opposite would have been interested in this matter too. There has been a lot of speculation over recent months about the future of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. I understand that my colleague the Attorney-General has recently given details of the new Human Rights and Responsibilities Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has always been committed to having a strong and an independent federal human rights body for all Australians. And why wouldn't we? After all, it was a coalition government which signed the Copenhagen convention eliminating all forms of discrimination against women. It was a coalition government which established the forerunner to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission; namely, the Human Rights Commission. So, of course, this coalition government too wants to see that women get protected and that human rights in this country are protected generally.

I am especially pleased to be able to inform the Senate that there will be a specialist position for sex discrimination and equal opportunity at the new Human Rights and Responsibilities Commission. While members of the Labor Party have been playing politics to both domestic and international audiences, the government has been working on a solution to a problem which was created by the Brandy case and the need to reform the role and the structure of HREOC.

This government made strong commitments to women when we were elected and we have kept those commitments. For women, the restructure will not only retain a specialised role for sex discrimination within the revamped commission but also will provide an excellent opportunity to make significant advances for women. No longer hampered by structural problems which have beset the HREOC, the new deputy president will be free to play a prominent role in educating business and the community and in setting out guidelines to avoid discrimination.

The commission will retain current powers to investigate and conciliate complaints, but it will also have a role in education and prevention. Making people aware of their responsibilities when it comes to human rights is as important as protecting those who are subject to discrimination. Both need to be undertaken. For women in particular, changing the culture of the workplace should not wait until a complaint about discrimination is made.

The new deputy president for sex discrimination and equal opportunity will be a strong advocate, a champion, for women to be free from discrimination in the workplace and in all areas covered by human rights legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to have equal opportunity.

—The noise that is coming from those opposite just makes you wonder. This government has listened to the concerns of Australian women. We have taken note of the concerns that people have about the future of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. These changes are the product of having an open and a dynamic relationship with those groups who are interested in government policy. Contrast that with the situation that existed under the Labor Party. Contrast that, for instance, with the former Prime Minister's style of dealing with people who questioned his government.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Conroy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrast that with Senator Conroy, who once again is interjecting. Of all things, he has been attacking ACOSS because he does not like their view of tax reform. For goodness sake, this government listens to, evaluates and acts upon the advice that comes to it. Some people close their ears to ideas that they do not like. The Labor Party's approach is to punish those whose views they do not like, to bully people whose views they do not like. They are not prepared to listen and be innovative and open to new ideas. We in government are. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, did you or your office receive a copy of the draft majority report Telstra: to sell or not to sell prior to its tabling in the Senate on Monday, 9 September 1996? Did you or any member of your staff pass on a copy of this draft report to your department? If you did have a copy of the draft report prior to its publication, who gave it to you or your office? Minister, do you deny that your department assisted coalition senators in drafting the minority report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any direct knowledge or recollection of this matter, other than the fact that it was trawled through exhaustively in estimates a couple of weeks back, or maybe longer. As far as I am concerned, the matter has not gone any further from there.
—Oh really?

—I will have a look at the senator's question to see whether he is asking any more than was being asked then and, if he is, whether we have got anything further to add. But I do not have any recollection of the matter beyond that time.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, your government's argument that cutting the tariff on sugar was justified because free trade would lead to increased exports has been shot to pieces by last week's announcement that the US quota on imported Australian sugar has been cut by 30 per cent. Yesterday the Deputy Prime Minister put out a media release describing the American government's attitude as `ironic'. Ironic! I wonder whether the Queensland cane farmers who just lost $10 million think that it is ironic. Minister, what does your government have to say to Australian cane farmers who have been comprehensively duped into a trade policy which so far has been all losses and no gains?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the members of the sorrowful Joe team—all sad and bad news. The Deputy Prime Minister made it very clear in his statement yesterday that he was very disappointed at the decision by the United States to reimpose restrictions on quotas. I saw Senator Woodley's beat up press release a couple of days ago. It was interesting to see in today's paper an article by Mr Harry Bonanno, who discounted entirely the line run by Senator Woodley. There were also comments from Mr Ballantyne of the Cane Growers Association.
—What did he have to say?

—He said that he did not agree at all with the proposition being made, which in fact was made by the AWU. We have got Senator Woodley in here saying, `Let's butter up the AWU.' It will not work, because the AWU owns the Labor Party in Queensland. It is not about to take over the Democrats, because you are not worth it.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has consistently pressed the United States administration for reform of its sugar regime and will continue to do so. Australian embassy officials in Washington have made clear to US officials Australia's disappointment at the decreased tariff quota allocation. Australia, including our canegrowers, has a vested interest in getting rid of tariff and non-tariff barriers in other countries. Compared with countries like Japan and the United States, in excess of 80 per cent of Australia's production, particularly from canegrowers, is exported.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right—90 per cent.
—Thanks, Senator Boswell; you are right up to speed on this. So 90 per cent is exported and 10 per cent is consumed domestically.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Boswell himself remarked in an interjection yesterday, which I thought was very telling, what you are suggesting, Senator Woodley, is to impose a tariff which would put at risk the jobs of people who work at the Golden Circle cannery in Brisbane. That is what you want, isn't it? You get up in here day in, day out, and tell us to spend money on a whole lot of work programs. When real jobs are concerned, you are intent only in destroying them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What the Deputy Prime Minister said yesterday was that the US avoided any meaningful reform in the Uruguay Round and again in its own 1995 farm bill, but Australia continues to go down the road while America says `Get nicked.' What are you going to do that really will make our sugar growers know that this government is on their side instead of being committed to destroying their industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would expect that Senator Woodley would at least listen to Mr Harry Bonanno and Mr Ballantyne, the spokesmen for the sugar industry. They have totally discounted this. They have accepted the fact that the tariff has gone, and they are more interested in the benefits to them that come from single desk selling. And so they should be, because they do rely to such an extent on exports.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Deputy Prime Minister has said, we do not approve of the US move. We are opposed to it. We think it is not in the interests of our cane growers. This government is interested only in promoting the interests of Australians and Australian jobs. It is perfectly obvious, from earlier questions asked of Senator Hill by Senator Lees, that the last thing in the world the Democrats are interested in is jobs for Australians; you want to destroy them.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, has your attention been drawn to a survey by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants which shows that Australian small businesses will have to pay more than $30 million in extra costs to collect the 15 per cent tax on superannuation? Can you also confirm that the survey revealed that the cost of collecting the tax would increase charges by at least $100 for each small fund member? Is it a fact that half the accountants surveyed said that they would need to increase their fees to clients as a result of complying with the tax? How do you reconcile these developments with your government's professed commitment to reducing small business compliance costs and to cutting red tape?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the detail of the item that Senator Cook is referring to. Let me say that business does under stand—and small business in particular—that there is an overwhelming need for tax reform. The one thing that really sticks in the craw of small business is that, if you go back a decade or so, when they thought your former leader had a serious commitment to tax reform, they thought there was a bit of light.

—On a point of order, Madam President: we have had Senator Alston admit that he cannot answer the question that Senator Cook asked. He is apparently going to answer some other question that was not asked, or to just entertain himself and no‐one else for the next four minutes. Madam President, why don't you invite him to sit down if he can't answer the question.
—There is no point of order.

—Madam President, I can understand why the opposition is a bit vulnerable on this issue. Tax reform is understood by all businesses to be an absolute imperative if we are to get this country moving again. It is bad enough for Kim Beazley to get out there and say that he is no genius; the fact is that he is being modest by half. He has not got a clue what leadership means. He has no idea what the agenda is, and he is not interested in tackling the issues. He is simply burying his head in the sand and hoping that no‐one will notice. I tell you that, from now on, he is going to take notice.
—Senator, I think you have strayed a little from the question.
—Madam President, I think the point has been made, and we will leave it at that.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, it is well accepted that, unlike the previous government, this government is interested in small business. I ask the minister to outline to the Senate the further excellent news, in terms of lower interest rates and increased financial sector competition as a result of the policies of this government, for those Australians who are involved in small business.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for that important and perceptive question, which will assist us to indicate the considerable benefits which the policies of this government are delivering to small business.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party continues to yell out when we speak about interest rates—they were the high interest rate party. They were the party that delivered interest rates of up to 20 per cent to small business.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Cook gets up and pretends to be concerned about small business. I don't recall Senator Cook ever saying anything in this chamber when interest rates for small business soared towards 20 per cent, under the Labor government. There was never a word from Senator Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator Cook, you can get up after question time to tell us how you complained about the interest rates under your government. We will all wait for you.

ANSWER.PARA: The news on the interest rate front gets better and better. I am pleased to report to the Senate that the variable interest rates for small business have fallen to their lowest levels since the relevant data began to be collected in 1996.

In the 13 years of the Labor government—some of those years under Captain Keating; Captain Wacky, as you now call him but, in those days, he was the Prime Minister, Mr Keating—small business never enjoyed interest rates as low as they are enjoying now. As I said, to remind them, under Labor, the interest rates available to small business soared towards 20 per cent. The reductions that have been delivered under this government are worth hundreds of millions of dollars per annum to the small business sector.

This is, of course, great news for small business and great news for job creation. It comes on top of the big reductions in home loan and fixed interest rates, providing very substantial benefits to home buyers and taxpayers via lower public debt interest.

Let me state again, and remind the Senate, that the government is currently repaying some of the Labor debt which was issued at 14 per cent per annum, while issuing new debt at around 6.5 per cent per annum. Last week, fixed rate home loan rates were cut significantly. For example, the ANZ cut its three‐year fixed interest rate by some 0.26 per cent to 6.99 per cent. The ANZ's Chief General Manager said that the new three‐year fixed rate is an extremely good way for customers to lock into a rate below seven per cent until the year 2000. That is good news for home buyers and news which the Labor Party could never deliver.

There are a number of reasons for this very sharp fall in interest rates. One is low inflation. We have locked in a low inflation performance. Another factor is fiscal responsibility. When we inherited $70 billion worth of deficits over the last five or six years from the Labor Party—(Time expired)
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The behaviour on my left is quite disorderly.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communication, the Information Economy and the Arts. What are the advantages and disadvantages from the government's point of view of the phased approach versus the clean break approach for APS employees affected by IT outsourcing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to comment on that. I am happy to get back to Senator Bolkus. If he thinks it is a moot point and he wants to have a debate on the subject, I am happy to accommodate him when I get the information. It has nothing do with information economy, I might say.
—You're kidding. You're a fool.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, Senator Bolkus is on his feet and presumably wishes to ask a supplementary question.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question to give Senator Alston his thirteenth opportunity today to answer a question, which he has not been able to do all day. This question involves something fundamental to information economy. Minister, can you confirm that all agencies in the cluster are being required to opt either for the clean break or the phased approach? Why is your government being so inflexible? Isn't it the case that the phased approach may be preferred by some agencies within a cluster but not by others? Why shouldn't they be able to choose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indicated that this is essentially an argument about redundancy and other termination arrangements. It is a public sector issue. It has nothing at all to do with information economy. It is just a great tragedy that you do not seem to have the vaguest idea what that is about. That is trying to encourage all Australians, individuals and businesses, to take maximum advantage of the opportunities that are going to arise in the area of new information. If you want to ask me about public sector termination arrangements, I am happy to get the information for you.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not profess to understand the subtleties of phased out or clean break. I have sat there and had my eyes glaze over in estimates when you are asking questions on behalf of your clients endlessly and remorselessly. No doubt all of you are absolute experts on it and in due course when you get the flick from here you will be able to go back and earn a decent living telling people what it is all about. But it is not something that directly affects me. To the extent there is information that I can provide, I will give it to you. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Veterans' Affairs: Agency Agreement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to a question asked on 4 September by Senator West. I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—
On 4 September 1997 Senator West asked me questions about the salary packaging provisions in the draft Department of Veterans' Affairs Agency Agreement. The particular questions were:

(1) How does the Minister justify spending $12,000 to encourage SES officers, many of whom earn over $100,000, to avoid income tax, the new 15% superannuation tax and the new Medicare levy surcharge for high income earners.

(2) . . . whether the Minister will now seek to ensure that no taxpayers' money is spent to promote tax avoidance by SES officers in either the Department of Veterans' Affairs or in the Minister's own Department of Social Security.
The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer:

The Department of Veterans' Affairs is presently going through a process of developing a certified agreement for its non-SES staff and Australian Workplace Agreements for its SES staff under the Workplace Relations Act.

"In this process, consistent with Government directions on agreement making, salary packaging proposals are under consideration. Salary packaging will become available to all staff, not just SES staff, but only when the agreements are finalised in accordance with all processes required by the Workplace Relations Act. Costs associated with staff participation in salary packaging including any fringe benefits tax liability will be met by the staff member.

"No taxpayers' money will be spent by DVA to promote tax avoidance by its staff. Prior to implementing salary packaging the Department will develop guidelines and inform staff about their operation. No departmental funds have been spent yet although it is estimated that $12,000 will be the cost of producing the guidelines and conducting information sessions for staff. Neither guidelines nor information sessions will promote tax avoidance. The salary packaging arrangements will not put DVA staff in a special position that would enable them to engage in tax evasion or avoidance. DVA staff will remain subject to the same rules as apply to the community generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response from the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) to a question asked by Senator Faulkner yesterday. I seek leave to have the response incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—
On 22 September Senator Faulkner asked Senator Newman in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence the following question:

Minister, is it a fact that a Mr Jim Bonner, a staff member of the Minister for Defence, faxed to journalists covering the recent South Pacific Forum meeting in the Cook Islands a copy of a Defence cable that was marked "restricted"? Who provided this cable to Mr Bonner? On what basis was the cable provided to Ear Bonner? Was-the Minister, Mr McLachlan consulted about access to this file and document? Does the government support the publication of such classified material?
Minister McLachlan has provided the following answer:
The cable Mr Bonner, a member of the Minister for Defence's staff, sent to media was classified "restricted" in 1985.
The Minister has authority to release material such as the cable and exercised it.
A restricted classification is given when unauthorised disclosure could possibly be harmful to national security.
The cable was restricted as it referred in advance to movements of a VIP aircraft carrying the then Prime Minister, advance knowledge of which could be sensitive.
Disclosure of such information some 12 years later could not in any way be construed as harmful to national security.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 September 1997 Senator Margetts asked a question in respect of the replacement of the research reactor at Lucas Heights. I have received supplementary information from the Minister for Science and Technology. A copy of this information has been provided to Senator Margetts. I now seek leave to have the information incorporated in Hansard .
—Is leave granted?
—I think it is reasonable to have this response read out.
—You are refusing leave?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: MARGETTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I am because I do think it is necessary to hear the response.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response to Senator Sherry who asked a question yesterday regarding changes to social security entitlements which commenced on 20 September 1997. I seek leave to have that response incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

On Monday, 22 September 1997 (Hansard page 6541) Senator Sherry asked me, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question about changes to social security entitlements which commenced on 20 September 1997.
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

The two related measures, referred to by Senator Sherry and which commenced on 20 September 1997, are the extension of the Liquid Assets Waiting Period from 4 weeks to a maximum of 13 weeks, and replacing the Annual Leave Waiting Period with the Income Maintenance Period.

These measures are extensions of measures introduced by the previous government and are intended to ensure that people with the financial capacity to do so bear a fair share of the cost of moving from a job. Cashed out entitlements to leave are in lieu of salary. It is not unreasonable where people have such entitlements for them to support themselves. Similarly, the Government expects a person who receives a large redundancy payment or has considerable savings to, at least during the initial period of their unemployment, take some responsibility for their own support. The previous government believed this approach was appropriate, and so do we.
The measures are consistent with the principle that funds for social security support are targeted to those most in need.

Senator Sherry's claim that the Income Maintenance Period applies retrospectively to 103,000 Australians who have lost their jobs is incorrect. The Income Maintenance Period only applies in respect of relevant leave payments received on or after 20 September 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response to Senator Mackay who asked me questions yesterday relating to redundancies of staff in the Australian Taxation Office. I seek leave to have that response incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows—

On Monday 22 September 1997 (Hansard page 6544) Senator Mackay asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister, questions relating to forced redundancies of staff in the Australian Taxation Office. In particular I was asked whether I was aware:

a) that there are other tax office staff, some at the same level as those who are being made compulsorily redundant and performing similar functions to them, who have been refused access to a voluntary redundancy;
b) that the tax office is currently employing approximately 200 temporary staff to perform the duties of the permanent staff faced with compulsory redundancy; and
c) that the tax office has the option of avoiding compulsory redundancies altogether by moving work between tax office branches.
The Prime Minister has provided the following answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has been going through a redundancy programme. Originally 305 positions were determined as being excess to requirements. Of that number, all but 25 have been dealt with successfully through voluntary redundancies or redeployment.

The ATO is continuing to seek redeployment for the remaining 25 positions and has been exploring with the Public Service and Merit Protection Commission redeployment prospects throughout the Australian Public Service. The ATO is also inde pendently writing to all Commonwealth agencies within Victoria.
The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that he treats compulsory redundancies as an absolute last resort.
Senator Mackay suggested that people at the same level had been refused voluntary redundancies. I am advised that this is not the case in relation to these redundancies.

Senator Mackay also raised the question of the use of temporary staff to perform the duties of the permanent staff faced with compulsory redundancy. Temporary staff are used only for short term seasonal workloads, for example processing of tax returns during the peak processing period.

Finally, Senator Mackay suggested that the ATO may be in a position to move work from other regions to match the numbers of staff potentially declared excess. The ATO has explored this possibility. In some cases the nature of the work prevents its movement, or the costs associated with that movement does not make it viable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a response to a question from Senator Faulkner relating to what he said were conventions that governments would not access the records of previous administrations without seeking permission of former ministers and suggesting there was a breach of that convention. I will answer this briefly because it is in note form. The advice I have received is that Senator Faulkner is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: The convention accepted by successive Australian governments is that ministers do not normally seek access to documents disclosing internal deliberations of previous governments and advice provided to them. At the same time good administration and continuity of government require new governments to have a right to factual information held by departments and all information necessary for proper handling of government responsibility. The cable to which Senator Faulkner was referring was merely an RAAF tasking order and could not by any stretch of the imagination be referred to as a deliberative document of the past government.

The restrictive classification that was referred to by Senator Faulkner was given when unauthorised disclosure could possibly be harmful to national security. The cable was restricted as it referred in advance to movements of a VIP aircraft carrying the then Prime Minister, advanced knowledge of which could be sensitive. Disclosure of such information some 12 years later could not in any way be construed as harmful to the national security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senator Lundy today, relating to the information economy.

There we have it. We have a classic example of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts not knowing the scope of his new responsibilities. He said it all himself when he said that the phased approach that is happening with IT outsourcing in the government sector has nothing to do with the information economy. How wrong he can be! How telling is that of the ignorance of both the minister and this government in their approach to information technology and information services?

The comments by the minister today go to the very heart of the vacuum that this new portfolio exists in. It is not surprising, however, that the industry welcomes such a move, because it is the first taste, the first symbol, that it has had so far that this government has even come close to getting it when it comes to this critical new industry. It is the first taste following a plethora of reports that have highlighted two main things: one is the importance of industry development policies to boost such a critical sector and the second, which both reports dwelled on at great length, is the massive lack of leadership on the part of this government when it comes to information technology.

It is worth tracing back to the origins of the creation of this new portfolio. We know it came in the form of a recommendation in the Goldsworthy report. If you go back further than that and start to look at some of the submissions to the Goldsworthy report, the—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're getting to Lee's time. He did nothing.

—Senator Tierney, I am sure you are following this with your censorship campaign. What we have as part of the Goldsworthy report are submissions which articulate quite well what is required in terms of a new portfolio structure to address information services and technology. I point to the submission provided by the Australian Computer Society which goes quite specifically to the point that a new portfolio addressing information technology has got to go beyond the very few matters that have been put into the portfolio now held by Senator Alston.

SPEECH.PARA: It needs to cover the most critical aspect of industry development. You cannot separate the outsourcing of information technology services in the public sector from industry development information services in Australia. Why? If the minister read his brief he would understand why. The information sector in Australia is intrinsically linked to the government procurement and government provision of services.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: O'CHEE

TALK.START.PARA: —That's rubbish!

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that rubbish, Senator O'Chee? Obviously you have not been listening to what Australian business has been saying.
—Senator Lundy, address the chair and you might get fewer interjections. Senator O'Chee and Senator Ferguson, enough interjections!

—The small business representatives of this sector have been saying since this government got into power and since it has espoused its policies with respect to IT outsourcing that the government has got it wrong. It is doing it in a way that is alienating Australian business.

SPEECH.PARA: IT outsourcing is critical because that is the platform upon which Australian IT companies sell themselves to the world. What is the first question asked by an overseas client as to the nature of an Australian IT company? It is `Do you have a government contract?' It is an absolutely critical prerequisite. Now what are they going to be able to say? They will have to say, `Oh, no, not exactly, but we are subcontracting to IBM' or that they are subcontracting to another multinational. That is great credibility.

What this government does not understand is that the structures it has put in place for IT outsourcing will undermine the position of the indigenous IT sector here. This minister gets up and says, `Oh, a phased approach to IT outsourcing for government services has nothing to do with the information economy.' I put to Senator Alston that it has everything to do with the information economy. Unless this government realises that, this government is going to fall into the trap that John Howard fell into 18 months ago and is yet to climb out of—that is one of complete ignorance about IT services and of a desperate attempt to create a mirage that this government is addressing this issue. It is a mirage. The national office of information economy exists in a vacuum. Until this government picks up the important full scope of information technology, including industry development and including IT outsourcing, it will exist in a vacuum and it will be imperfect and ineffective. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —The only vacuum when it comes to information technology is the vacuum that surrounds those on the opposition benches. Senator Lundy's essential point this afternoon was that she was of the belief that information technology industries in this country could not flourish unless they were directly dependent upon government. That was the essential argument that she advanced today. If one listens to Senator Lundy's argument and compares it with the facts, one will find that there is a glaring discrepancy.
—You can twist it all you like.
—Order! Senator Lundy, you have had your turn.

—Madam Deputy President, it does not matter how many interjections she makes because she still will not manage to get her point across. The reason why she cannot get her point across is that it is unsubstantiated by fact. The fact is this: nationally, 53.2 per cent of information technology employers in this country are saying that they want to increase their work force—not decrease their work force, Senator Lundy, but increase it. This is in direct contradistinction to everything we have just heard from Senator Lundy about how the information technology sector is going to shrivel up. It is not shrivelling up. In fact, it is growing, and it is growing at a faster rate than when Labor was in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lundy would have you believe that information technology companies cannot be successful overseas unless they have a government tender. Let me give you a perfect example why that is wrong. There is a Brisbane based company which is preparing to float on the stock market. It is called Mincom. They are experts at producing software for the management of utilities. They are experts at producing software—
Senator Lundy interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lundy, when there is a program that is designed for inordinate screeching, I am sure you will be an expert at it. What there is in Mincom is expertise in terms of utilities management and expertise in terms of stockpile management. This is a company that has been contracting to the private sector and is grossly, grossly successful in Asia. Of course, it is not because of what Senator Lundy says. In fact, what Senator Lundy says is totally and utterly away from the facts. The truth is that nowhere in the world do you find the information technology sector developing clusters based on government; they develop clusters based on innovative companies. That is what this government is trying to achieve. It is trying to achieve clusters of innovative companies.

SPEECH.PARA: But Senator's Lundy's essential point is that they do not even want it outsourced. That is the point of view of the Labor Party. They do not even want it outsourced because they all want it done inside the department. Of course, if all of it gets done inside the department, none of that expertise can flow out to the private sector. Of course not. The only way it will flow out to the private sector is if the people leave the Public Service.

Senator Lundy's speech here was not about innovation. It was not about information technology industries growing, expanding and becoming more innovative. It was about the shrivelling membership of the union movement, in particular the shrivelling membership of the Community and Public Sector Union, for whom Senator Lundy is the spokesman in this chamber. That is perfectly all right. We all understand Senator Lundy's prejudices, but it is a tragedy when the development of the information technology industry in this country becomes prostituted to the prejudices of Senator Lundy and the CPSU.

They are directly opposed to the growth of the private sector. The CPSU do not want a private sector and yet Senator Lundy comes in here and says that she is interested in the growth of the information technology industry because she wants to lock it all up in the government. That is an oxymoron of the greatest proportion. That one is notable and, of course, is symptomatic of what happens with the Labor Party.

They cannot see how you develop industry because they have never developed industry. All they want to do is lock themselves into some 1950s Marxist, Leninist, command-control economy where the CPSU give the shots to the union officials who are sitting in parliament and dictate the direction of the economy. Of course, it does not work. It did not work in Russia. It has not worked in China. It did not work in Albania. It has not worked in Cuba. But that has never stopped the Labor Party from espousing it here.

This debate is all about 1950s ideological obsessions. It is not about growing information technology industries in the 1990s or into the 21st century. No, the Labor Party have never let fact get in the way of their prejudice. They have always had a one‐eyed view and, unfortunately, the telescope is up against the wrong eye. They cannot see where the future is going. That is why the membership of the CPSU and the support of the Labor Party dwindles every single day when they make these outrageous statements. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator O'Chee was listening to this side of the chamber and not his own during question time. I know that he has a keen interest in sport and he would have seen at least the symbolism of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) being unable to answer a series of questions on his new responsibility. The first questions and answers, I think, were the most telling: `What sort of staff will you have, Minister?' `Don't know.' `How much money will your department have, Minister?' `Don't know.' `Where will you take the resources from, Minister?' `Don't know.' At least that was the essence of the answers that the minister gave us in response to the first question.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have a close look at the minister who is being championed as the saviour for the information technology industry in this country. He cannot even tell this chamber what resources he is going to have to administer this portfolio area which is going to be the saviour of the information technology industry in this country, if we are to believe the hype of this government.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) earlier this month put out a press release entitled `The information economy'. He said that the information economy, properly managed, would deliver high economic growth, jobs and more choice for families. The Prime Minister said his government had given this sector high priority because it was the key to realising Australia's potential into the 21st century. The Prime Minister was right to place importance on this sector of the economy because information technology can offer much to future generations in the form of stronger economic growth, more jobs and a higher standard of living.

We are well placed to realise this potential—or at least we were well placed under a Labor government. Under Labor, we were building a highly skilled work force. We were building a culture of strong investment in research and development, in education and in training. We recognised the key role that government plays in this key sector. It accounts for 40 per cent of the information technology market and, therefore, has a pivotal role to play in developing the industry.

Mr Howard obviously sees this differently. His recent rhetoric is a long way from the reality of his policies. The reality is that it is almost a blind commitment to IT outsourcing. The reality is, as in other key areas of the economy and the community generally, it is an obsession with short-term financial bottom line by this government. Mr Howard cut the computer bounty. He cut tax incentives for research and development. As I said earlier, he is locked into a policy of outsourcing with contracts flowing not to Australian business but offshore to big multinationals. That is great for the industry! Senator O'Chee might have heard that if he were still in here.

So the Howard government has managed to match a great opportunity with no incentives, no policy framework and certainly no eye to the future. Unfortunately, without a radical change in approach, this opportunity—the foundation for which was laid by the former Labor government—will be an opportunity lost. So let us not harp on the hollow announcements of this government creating a portfolio responsibility with a minister who apparently does not even have the clout to negotiate his staff or the financial position of this area of the department, or to know whether he is going to get more money or take money from other areas in his department. He could not answer those questions today. That is the only fair assumption on the material that is before us.
