People in the industry are hopeful that this portfolio responsibility will give some further impetus to their industry, but I think their comments have to be looked at when you look at some of the other comments of this government about savings to be made about IT outsourcing. There is an article in today's Australian quoting Mr Cliff Smith of Novell, the software developer, who is very clear in his statement when he says:
They are wrong—
that is, the government are wrong—
to assume that the implementation—
that is, the implementation of the information technology areas by outsourcing—
will be any cheaper.

The industry is telling you it is not going to be cheaper. It is no good to quote one-off examples of saving. You have to look at the whole picture. The industry is saying that this government is not going to save money by its IT outsourcing policy. There may be some other reasons used to dress up the policy but, frankly, the policy is going to be a failure on the basis of trying to save this government money. Let us look at the real needs of the industry. Let us review these policies, just as Labor was, and get it right. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had two speakers from the opposition on this matter so far, but they missed some of the very fundamental points. The fundamental underlying point, of course, is that in Australia this industry is booming, which actually puts paid to the comments that you were making, Senator O'Brien. This government is picking up the cusp of this matter and pushing it to the future by creating this new ministry of the information economy. That is more than your government ever did.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot remember you ever proposing such a ministry. As a matter of fact, what I remember under your government is a minister by the name of Michael Lee, the member for Dobell, whom we used to call the Rip Van Winkle of communications policy because he sat on his hands and did nothing for three years. What he did was commission a number of reports. There was a report brought down in 1993. There was another report brought down in 1995, and then we went into the election. From 1993‐96 the government fiddled around with reports but actually did nothing. Opportunities went begging in this country when we were so well positioned for this new boom in the information age.

If we have a look at what we had at that point, we had an opportunity that was wasted by this Labor government for three years because we had a communications regulation system that was national, unlike some other countries, like the United States, where there are 51 regulators—the 50 states and the federal government. We had a number of major companies. We had a structure where the backbone went around 80 per cent of the Australian population in a very short distance between Brisbane and Adelaide. We were very well positioned for the information economy. But your government blew it. Your government blew the chances.

What this government is doing by setting up this information industry ministry is moving in this new direction and focusing policy on developing Australia as a major player in the information age. Senator O'Brien and Senator Lundy are very misleading in saying—if I quote you, Senator O'Brien—that things are going overseas. If that is the case, why is this industry actually booming? Why do the figures show that there is a job explosion in this industry that even exceeds the explosion in the communications industry generally? If we come to IT specifically and have a look at the growth—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a legacy of the Labor government.
—It was a long time ago, Senator Sherry. You cannot claim that for too much longer.
—Why do you blame us for the unemployment rate, then?
—Let's blame you for something. Let me show you this graph.
—Order, Senator Sherry! Senator Tierney, address the chair, please.
—Through you, Madam Chair.
—To me.
—If I can show Senator Sherry this graph here, it shows IT dropping and then absolutely booming, up 53 per cent.
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President, I do not know whether other senators can read the graph that Senator Tierney is holding up.
—Very clearly, thank you.

—You have glasses on, so I can understand why, perhaps, but you have got your back to him. It must be a bit difficult. If the senator would like to incorporate, or seek permission to incorporate, the graph, we would then all be able to read it. But it is not possible to read documents across the table like that.
—There is no point of order. Are you seeking leave, Senator Tierney?
—I am seeking leave to incorporate this document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document is from the Australian of 26 August, page 41. It goes into—and you can read this, now it is being incorporated—the way in which the job market in IT is booming.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy President.
—I know this is very embarrassing. You are just highlighting that, Senator Sherry.
—The reason for accepting incorporation is so that we do not have to hear any more of the tedious argument of Senator Tierney. We can read it for ourselves in the Hansard .
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you. I know these figures are going to be very embarrassing to you, but let me underline them for you, Senator Sherry. Fifty‐three per cent of the IT industry firms are actually putting on staff, and that is up 12 per cent. Computer professionals job growth is going up at 6.2 per cent a year currently, as opposed to 2.8 per cent in the rest of the skilled work force.

BREAK.PARA: If your basic thesis was right, you would not find this. You claim it is all going overseas; it is not going overseas. The vast majority of this work is going to Australia. It is the imaginative and visionary policies of this government, that are allowing things to go to outsourcing, that have helped to create and generate this industry, which will be one of the lead growth indicators for the Australian economy in the years to come. This is all under the rubric of this new information ministry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to take note of a number of non‐answers from Senator Alston, but particularly in respect of the creation of the information economy ministry. We are very interested to hear when this ministry will be created and what it will consist of.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time now the government has taken decisions to contract out and outsource various government services, in particular the outsourcing of information technology services provided to the government and provided by the government. The steps that the government has taken are very interesting. Of course, ministers, government members and senators would have us believe that the private sector is very happy about the process which the government has embarked upon.

It would seem that that is not the case. It would seem that many departments and their officers and managers are not happy with the process that is taking place. The outcomes that we will achieve, particularly with regard to savings, are questionable. I will quote some statements in the media following an estimates committee hearing. Mr Andy Macdonald, the chief government information officer, and Mr Alan Nevins, First Assistant Secretary, Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, were reported as doing their damnedest to answer questions without actually saying anything. That is also the view, I think, of people within the private sector.

Of course, it is said by the private sector that the approach taken to the letting of contracts is not going to work. There is no doubt—and I think we would all agree—that the information technology industry has a real capacity to provide jobs and significant financial benefits for this country. But it will not do that unless it is dealt with appropriately and properly. That is clearly not what is happening at this point in time with the government's approach.
As I said, Mr Gosman recently appeared before the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee. In what is now a public statement, he said:

Thank you. We are here representing the Australian indigenous telecommunications industry. That includes companies such as Sytech, Jtec, Randata, Compucat JNA. We also represent the Information Technology and Telecommunications Security Forum, which has some 50 companies involved.

In terms of our views on outsourcing, we agree with the comments of Minister Fahey in the recently released Goldsworthy report that outsourcing offers significant industry development opportunities, particularly internationally. However, we believe that such opportunities will not be grasped without a firm, explicit industry development policy.

Among the contracts that have already been released, a $30 million contract has been let to IBM by the Department of Finance, which has headed the charge of outsourcing information services within the government. The minister said on the one hand that piggybacking was wrong but then he let a contract to the same company without even going to competitive tender. Yet the minister's statement about competitive tendering and a series of exposure drafts for managers of departments all say that competitive tendering had to happen. Of course, Mr Gosman is quite correct. Unless the government does this right, we will not get the outcome that we should from this. Clearly, the government has not been doing it right. Of course, Minister Alston is not going to help matters either with this bogus ministry for information economy.

As I said, there are three exposure drafts. They are: The performance improvement cycle, Competitive tendering and contracting, and Before you sign on the dotted line. All of these were provided to heads of departments to engage them and to educate them in a process that they are now required to embark upon.

Moreover, I recently received an invitation from the Department of Finance to participate in a round table forum of officials at the Boat House by the Lake, Grevillea Park, to discuss competitive tendering and contracting within the government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —It does strike me that today's question time has given us enough evidence that the opposition have lapsed right back into their old ways. The reason they lost the election was that they represent the most narrow sectional groups. They have learnt nothing from the election, because they are still representing, in a biased manner, a very narrow band of sectional groups.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, we had the questions in regard to the greenhouse debate, in which the opposition have teamed up with the Democrats to support—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. My point of order goes to relevance. Why is Senator McGauran not defending his col league the National Party Deputy Premier of Western Australia from that vicious attack instituted by Senator Alston? That is the relevant issue that Senator McGauran should be addressing.
—There is no point of order, Senator Sherry.

—The Labor Party and the Democrats are taking up the greenhouse position, which is an anti‐Australian position. It is an anti‐jobs position that relates to information and technology. This government has made several decisions—be it the greenhouse position or its outsourcing of information technology—based primarily not only on the efficient running of the budget but also on the capability of increasing jobs in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to excuse Senator Lundy, because she is a new senator, but there is evidence enough that the opposition have learnt nothing from their defeat in the election. The base political reason that they are attacking the government's policy on information technology outsourcing is simply that they are spokespeople for the Public Service union. Of course, they do not want any of the Public Service efficiencies and changes that we are introducing going out to the private sector, because it undermines their union base, as they see it. It does not in reality, but that is how those opposite see it. That is why you are against the Telstra privatisation: it was simply that you have come in here as spokespeople for the union movement. We had the best of them just yesterday making his first speech in this parliament. You, Senator George Campbell, have come in here and—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran, would you like to address your remarks to the chair, please.

—I have a lot to say about information technology and I should not be distracted by the new senator, Senator George Campbell. But I want to be the first one to remind him, when it comes to debating jobs in this parliament, that it has been said that he has over 100,000 manufacturing jobs around his neck. So let him never debate in this parliament the subject of unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator George Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should never open your mouth on unemployment in this country, Senator. However, getting back to the issue before us, let us look at the benefits of the government policy of outsourcing of information technology. I have already mentioned the jobs—that it will bring new jobs to the marketplace.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Can I have some order on my left please: Senator Carr, Senator Jacinta Collins, Senator Forshaw and Senator George Campbell. Thank you.
—You may have left one or two out. Senator Collins should have been named.
—Excuse me, I do not need any help; Senator Collins was named.

—There are massive changes going on within the Public Service. The government was forced to act, given the budget deficit and the government debt left behind by the previous government. We were forced to make these changes. The public require us to make efficiency changes within the Public Service in Canberra. There are efficiency changes, there are industrial relations changes, there are changes to the Merit Protection and Review Board and there is outsourcing in all areas, of which information technology is one example. It is all designed to put the Public Service here in Canberra on a far more competitive footing, to deliver services far better. There will be no reduction in services per se, but they will be delivered better. This feeds into the budget process which has been somewhat of an obsession of this government in its first 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The financial benefits can already be seen within the Department of Finance. Their recent contract with IBM is set to save some $25 million over the next five years. I quote that figure off the top of my head—it is in the millions of dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure that's right?
—Here it is. I was right: $25 million over five years will be the savings within the Department of Finance alone.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Forest Protection
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: Immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;
support incentives for nationwide composting, soil remineralisation, and planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 216 citizens)and Senator Lees(from 215 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Industries
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in parliament assembled:

The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are concerned with the recommendations of the draft Industry Commission report into the Textile, Clothing and Footwear industries, and that acceptance of these recommendations could see a further 1900 Tasmanians lose their jobs.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support Tasmanian Textile, Clothing and Footwear workers by rejecting the Industry Commission's recommendations to slash tariffs and export assistance for this vital Tasmanian industry.

PETITION.TITLE: Timed Local Calls
PETITION.PARA: A Petition to the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain residents in the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the Senate the harsh and regressive decision by the Howard Government to allow telecommunications carriers to charge timed local calls for data communication services such as electronic mail, facsimile, the internet and other on‐line services. This measure will adversely affect business and individual users of the above services, and particularly hamper the operations and growth of small business.
Your petitioners call on the Senate to request that the Howard Government rescind their decision, and ensure local data communication services are charged on an untimed basis.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of the undersigned residents of the State of Tasmania draws to the attention of the Senate the adverse impact on students of:
2. Federal Government increases in the Higher Education Contribution Scheme; and
3. The Federal Government's mismanagement of the Austudy Actual Means Test.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to take action to address student and parent concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the presence in Parliament House of the Pilgrimage Project to Stop Uranium: Reclaim the Future,
(ii) the pilgrimage includes two visitors from the area of Russia affected by the Chernobyl catastrophe and a woman from the Gorleben district of Germany,
(iii) the pilgrimage group has visited uranium mines at Ranger and Roxby Downs and considered carefully the Jabiluka and Olympic Dams expansion proposals, and

(iv) the pilgrimage group has met with Aboriginal communities already affected by uranium mining or potentially affected by proposed uranium mines, including the Martu, Oolbagoooma, Mirrar, Doomadgee and Aranta communities, all of whom said very clearly that uranium is okay if undisturbed, but once dug up it's big trouble; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Coalition Government and the Australian Labor Party to listen to the voice of ordinary Australians who do not want uranium mined in this country and who want Australia to get out of the nuclear fuel cycle altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) condemns the Federal Government for siphoning monies from the Natural Heritage Trust to fund the Tasmanian Regional Forest Agreement;
(b) notes, with concern, the precedent that this could set in negotiating regional forest agreements in other parts of Australia; and

(c) calls on the Federal Government to expedite the signing of the Regional Forest Agreement in Tasmania by providing adequate monies that have not been diverted from the Natural Heritage Trust, to end the uncertainty over industry and environment outcomes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) nuclear activities in Australia are producing tonnes of long‐term low‐, medium‐ and high‐level waste, a problem for which there remains no safe solution,
(ii) nuclear power reactors will contribute to the greenhouse effect through their construction, the mining of uranium for fuel, maintenance, decommissioning and long‐term storage of wastes,
(iii) Australia's current level of nuclear‐related activities will leave long‐lived nuclear wastes as a long‐term legacy for future generations,
(iv) the Government endorsed the expansion of the world's largest uranium mine at Roxby Downs in South Australia,
(v) the Coalition Government has approved the expansion of the Ranger uranium mine in Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory,
(vi) the Federal Government does not recognise any environmental impediments to the development of the Jabiluka mine in Kakadu National Park,
(vii) the Federal Government has endorsed the building of a new nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights on the outskirts of Sydney,
(viii) the current generation should not be creating intractable problems for future generations,
(ix) measures to monitor and regulate the uranium mining industry in Australia are not strict, broad or transparent, and
(x) cyclotron and spallation technology are an acceptable way for producing medical isotopes; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) move to end all nuclear fuel cycle activities in Australia, given that there is no proven, safe solution to the problem of nuclear waste,
(ii) take steps to stop the expansion of the world's largest uranium mine at Roxby Downs in South Australia,
(iii) develop and implement a strategy to close the Roxby Downs uranium mine,
(iv) take steps to stop the expansion of the Ranger uranium mine in Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory,
(v) reject the development of the Jabiluka mine in Kakadu National Park,
(vi) reject the development of any additional uranium mines, and
(vii) not proceed with plans to construct a new nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights on the outskirts of Sydney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Mackay, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, she will move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern:

PARA.TAB: (i) the Government's inability to reduce the unemployment figure of 8.7 per cent, and
(ii) the decrease of Australian workers' confidence in the labour market, evident in the participation rate of 62.9 per cent, the lowest in 3 years;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) rejects the comments by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) that Australia needed a freer labour market and lessened job security to reduce unemployment; and
(c) calls on the Government to reverse its low skilled, low wage, low job security approach and implement a policy direction that provides genuine jobs and job security for Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) Monsanto Australia Limited has made an application to the National Registration Authority to extend the current growing season for Bt cotton to include central Queensland,
(ii) transgenic cotton plants contain selectable marker genes which confer resistance to kanamycin and neomycin, as well as bacterial selection markers for spectinomycin and streptomycin,
(iii) cotton is an exotic plant in Australia,

(iv) the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee has stated that the possibility of gene transfer from cotton to native Gossypium species can not be ruled out if Bt cotton is planted on a large commercial scale, and
(v) the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee has recognised the potential for insect pests to develop resistance if Bt cotton is planted on a large commercial scale; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) expresses concern that the introduction of genetically‐modified agricultural stocks are a concern to many Australians, and that there must be sufficient data available to make informed assessments from the Australian experience recognising the inviolability of species, the dignity of individuals and the need to preserve naturally evolved life forms in their natural environments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate congratulates Mr Bob Glading, Deputy Commissioner, Life Insurance, Insurance and Superannuation Commission, on receiving the Actuary of the Year award from the Institute of Actuaries.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

BREAK.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee for inquiry and report by 25 November 1997:
Whether a new reactor should be built to replace the High Flux Australian Reactor at Lucas Heights on that site or on some other site in Australia, with particular reference to:

(a) the suitability of building a new reactor in a densely populated suburban area of Sydney and the impact on the environment of the Sutherland Shire community of a new reactor on the Lucas Heights site;
(b) the availability of alternative technologies to generate neutrons for medical, scientific, mining, industrial and other uses;

(c) the safety, cost, viability and effectiveness of alternative technologies such as cyclotrons and spallation sources compared with the long-term commissioning, operation and decommissioning of a new reactor; and
(d) whether the issues raised by the 1993 Research Reactor Review have been satisfactorily addressed in the context of the decision to proceed with a new reactor at Lucas Heights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) recognises the negative impact that the Government's cuts to child care has had on families;
(b) expresses concern:

PARA.TAB: (i) at the closure of 25 community-based child care centres since operational subsidies were removed on 1 July 1997 and the expectation that another 25 centres will close by the end of 1997, and
(ii) that more than 4 000 families have had to reduce their hours of centre-based child care or withdraw their children from child care services altogether; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) condemns the Government for forcing many women to withdraw from the work force or to reduce the hours they work simply because they can no longer afford the cost of child care; and
(d) calls on the Government to reinstate operational subsidies for community-based child care centres until a full inquiry into the effect of the withdrawal of these subsidies can be undertaken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with alarm, the National Association of Community Based Children's Services survey which shows that:

PARA.TAB: (i) 73 per cent of families exiting care cited fee increases as the reason for taking their children out of child care,
(ii) 67 per cent of families leaving centres are using informal care,
(iii) more than 25 per cent of centres in each State and Territory have reduced staffing levels, and
(iv) 50 small child care centres will close nationally by the end of 1997;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) condemns the Government's cuts of $820 million to child care over two budgets, leading to:

PARA.TAB: (i) fee increases of up to $20,
(ii) lower quality child care,
(iii) the closure of services,
(iv) job losses, and
(v) changes that are forcing some people to stop working, take their children out of child care, or rely on backyard care;

SPEECH.PARA: (c) deplores the Government's lack of consultation with the child care industry about implementation of the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 and failure to provide adequate information about regulations and guidelines to be included;
(d) expresses concern about limits on hours of care and emergency child care, which will limit the availability and reduce the quality of child care; and

(e) denounces the Government's attempts to rush the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 through the Parliament and its attempts to implement the bill by 1 January 1998, which will cause chaos in the child care sector.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration References Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

BREAK.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Finance and Public Administration References Committee for inquiry and report by 12 May 1998:
(a) current relationships between federal, state and local governments and whether they serve to strengthen the accountability of local governments to their constituents;

(b) current methods of financing local government, including intergovernmental transfers, whether they are equitable, adequate and appropriate and whether better means are available, paying particular attention to how to adequately fund high-growth areas with pressing infrastructure needs or areas of particular disadvantage because of isolation or other factors;
(c) possible action on the part of the Commonwealth to guarantee to local governments the fundamental rights to protections necessary to enable them to meet the need for:

PARA.TAB: (i) full and free democratic local elections and representation, and
(ii) full local accountability to meet local needs and objectives; and

BREAK.PARA: (d) recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution as a democratic tier of government and as part of a statement of commitment to the principle of subsidiarity.

(iii) incorporates programming policies which oppose prejudice on the grounds of race, sex, nationality, religion, disability, ethnic background, age or sexual preference; and

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

PARA.TAB: (i) the Government has stalled on a child abuse prevention strategy since it took office,

(iii) children continue to suffer abuse; and

PARA.TAB: (i) monitor all aspects of government, other policies or actions which detrimentally affect children, or cause, or contribute to child abuse, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) the budget cuts to the Energy Research and Development Council which will abolish that organisation,
(ii) the quality of Australian researchers, and
(iii) the potential for Australia as a large land mass with considerable winds which have not been harnessed;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) expresses concern that:

PARA.TAB: (i) the projects directed at wind-power research will not receive further funding, and
(ii) alternative energy resources are not being seriously considered by the Government; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c) considers that wind energy should be part of the Government's strategy in developing sustainable, alternative energy sources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) that Hanover Welfare Services (Hanover), an organisation which provides assistance and support to homeless people in the State of Victoria has released details of a research study into the link between homelessness and rates of suicide amongst its clients, and

(ii) the initial results show that people who are homeless show significantly higher rates of suicidal thoughts, attempted suicide and self-harm than the rest of the community and that the rate of attempted suicide is six times higher in people who are homeless; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Federal Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) recognise the link between homelessness and suicide,
(ii) take the initiative in establishing a national housing strategy which ensures that every Australian has access to safe, affordable housing, and
(iii) address, as a priority, the issue of homelessness in Australia by seeking the advice of organisations such as Hanover.

In division—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I would just draw the Senate's attention to the standing orders and the need for disclosure of interests. A number of senators do have shares in coalmining companies, and they might like to consider whether or not the standing orders apply to them in this situation.

—I am sure the words you have just said cover my situation too.
