DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on the crash of RAAF Nomad aircraft A18‐401 on 12 March 1990, and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE REFERENCES COMMITTEE ON THE `CRASH OF RAAF NOMAD AIRCRAFT A18‐401 ON 12 MARCH 1990'
The Committee recommended that the Government amend sub‐section (1) of section 96 of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 by extending the time limitation on charges from three to five years.
The final Government response to the recommendation is as follows:
The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation. The necessary action to amend the relevant statutory provision will be initiated shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee last year reported on the crash of a Nomad aircraft at the RAAF Edinburgh airfield in South Australia, in which the pilot, Flight Lieutenant Donovan, was killed. The committee made the recommendation that the Defence Force Discipline Act period be extended from three to five years. The significance is that the Defence Force Discipline Act prescribes that, unless disciplinary action is taken against someone within a period of three calendar years, a statute of limitations applies and no action can be taken against the person so named.

SPEECH.PARA: On a number of occasions—in fact, on far too many occasions—where accidents have occurred in the Department of Defence, the period of the inquiry has extended beyond three years, so the Defence Force Discipline Act has prevented any disciplinary action being taken against anyone who is found culpable in any way at all. This is clearly wrong; hence the committee's recommendation that the period be extended from three to five years so that it was not possible, procedurally, for someone to escape any censure, if indeed there was censure, to be attributed to their actions in relation to the accident.

Why it should take the Department of Defence more than three years to investigate an accident is a good question for the parliament to ask because, while a number of people are always involved in accident inquiries, and there is always research and data to be collected, a period of three years should be more than sufficient to reach conclusions and for action to be taken. But, unfortunately, that has not proved to be so in the past, so the government has advised the parliament that there will be an amendment to the Defence Force Discipline Act to extend that period from three to five years. That is something which I wholeheartedly support.

It is an important decision that the government has made. I would hope that it is only part of the business of an inquiry into, and a reform of, the processes used by the Department of Defence and the three services—the army, navy and air force—to inquire into accidents which involve either the loss of life or a major loss of property.

BREAK.PARA: Fortunately, these incidents are relatively rare in the services and, given the nature of service training, a loss of property and, at times, regrettably, a loss of life, even with the best of planning, occur. But it is important that there is a just and accurate inquiry process when those unfortunate incidents occur.

I think it is fair comment that there is mounting public criticism of the way the services have conducted inquiries. We have had a number of them in the past. The principal one at the moment is the Black Hawk inquiry, which is getting a lot of publicity, and I do not wish to canvass or discuss that in the chamber this afternoon. But it is not confined to the Black Hawk inquiry. We have had a number of accidents, ranging through all three services, where lives have been lost and/or significant materiel or property damage has taken place.

There is a degree of public criticism about the way those inquiries have been conducted. Consequential to that public criticism, of course, is a lack of public confidence in the services and their inquiries. It is terribly important that the services do have in place a system that provides a just analysis and a system of censure for anyone who falls short of what is expected of them in these circumstances.

I have spoken about this on numerous occasions because this has been an interest of mine that goes back many years. I do not intend to canvass the arguments this afternoon, but I just say that I have said in the past—and I have not looked at the Hansard to get the precise words, but I have used the phraseology in general—that the boards of inquiry which have been set up by the army, navy, air force or the Department of Defence have usually operated meticulously and accurately in their assessment of an accident. Yet no‐one has ever been held accountable for their actions when there has been clear evidence that they have failed to meet the standards or responsibilities placed upon them.

With the passage of time, I have looked at a number of boards of inquiry, and I am now satisfied that a lot of those boards of inquiry could have been much better conducted. It is important in the Defence Force that military justice takes place accurately and fairly.

It is a complex issue, and it is bedevilled, in part, by the fact that, quite a number of years ago, this parliament moved away from having two forms of the application of military justice—military law—within the services. One form was where you appeared before the CO and were asked if you agreed to be dealt with by the CO in a summary manner or where you were asked if you wished to be subjected to a court martial or some sort of formal inquiry.

Most misdemeanours were dealt with by the person on the charge electing to be dealt with summarily by the CO of the unit at the time. By and large, it might have been rough justice but it was pretty fair and most people supported that. Some years ago this parliament decided that we had to regularise it. We went more into a narrow legal application of military law. We have now seen a whole plethora of advocates and barristers and formal court proceedings. I think that has distorted, in some degree, the application of justice within the services. That is a bit of a red herring to what I am talking about here.

What I am talking about here is when we lose lives through an accident or when we have major property damage. It is always essential in those cases to determine the cause—what went wrong and why it went wrong—so it does not occur again. If there had been negligence or carelessness involved then it is appropriate that those personnel who were negligent or committed acts of irresponsibility somewhere along the line get some censure for it; otherwise you cannot maintain discipline in the defence forces. Soldiers, airmen or sailors are not going to do the difficult and dangerous things they have to do in defence activities in training if they see negligence or irresponsibility in their superiors, whether they are non-commissioned officers or officers, and loss of life or property as a consequence of it and no‐one being censured.

I did propose that some while ago, about 18 months ago, we did need to look seriously at the whole of the system of inquiries that we have. I would hope that what we have seen today in the government agreeing to the extension from three years to five years for the statute of limitations under the Defence Force Discipline Act is the start of a review process by this government into the whole of the administration of justice within the Department of Defence.

My proposition is that we have some independent inquiry, inspectorate‐general, set up so that beyond a certain level—and that level would be loss of life or material damage that runs into $5 million or $10 million—an independent body looks at all the causes and all the relevant facts, makes a recommendation and has the power to enforce disciplinary action or changes to procedures of the Defence Force that are consequential from that inquiry.

I have to say with the greatest of regret, and having looked at this over a very long period in great detail, that I do not believe it is possible for the defence forces to act as judge and jury for their own affairs. I think it is a very similar case with the police forces. The police forces have demonstrated on numerous occasions that they cannot discipline and control their own activities. I think there is a parallel—and I say this with the greatest of sadness—with the Defence Force. We do need an independent assessment of that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
Debate (on motion by Senator MacGibbon) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the respective committee chairmen, I present reports of the following legislation committees on annual reports: Economics, Finance and Public Administration, Legal and Constitutional.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the reports be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Robert Ray, I present the 68th report of the Committee of Privileges entitled Persons referred to in the Senate: Mr Ray Platt and Mr Peter Mulheron .

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

This report is the 25th in a series of reports recommending that a right of reply be accorded to persons who claim to have been adversely affected by being referred to in the Senate. On 21 July and 7 August 1997 the President referred to the committee letters from Mr Peter Mulheron and Mr Ray Platt respectively relating to remarks made by Senator Boswell in the Senate on 18 June 1997. The President referred the letters to the committee as submissions under privilege resolution 5. The committee has considered the submissions and recommends that responses agreed to by Mr Platt and Mr Mulheron and the committee be incorporated in Hansard .

The committee wishes to emphasise, as it has done on previous occasions, that in matters of this nature it does not judge the truth or otherwise of statements made by honourable senators or persons. Rather, it ensures that any person's submission, and ultimately the response it recommends, accords with the criteria set out in privilege resolution 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the comments by Senator Denman are worthy of note. In particular, in following this procedure the Privileges Committee does not make a finding about the truth or otherwise of a statement made by an honourable senator. The whole purpose of this procedure is to allow people who have been adversely referred to in this place to have a right of reply. That means that sometimes people will have the opportunity to correct grievous errors against them, and sometimes people will take advantage of this procedure to perpetuate whatever myth they want to perpetuate. I do not want to form a judgment on particular circumstances.

BREAK.PARA: I do wish to address one of the matters which I think arises from the report of the committee, and that is the ability of persons who are not specifically named to make a submission to the President and to request of the Privileges Committee a right to make a statement to be incorporated in Hansard. The practice to date has been that, where people are referred to obliquely, they should have that right of reply. Of course, Senator Ray has often said in this place that the committee errs on the side of safety and errs on the side of giving people a right of reply. But I am concerned that, if a person is not clearly identified, it is potentially inappropriate to extend that privilege too widely.
Let me give, for example, some possible fact situations. Suppose an honourable senator from the opposition were to get up and attack the members of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never!

—Never, Senator Carr. But, were that to happen, under the application of the convention as it currently stands it would be open to every one of the 40,000 members of the National Party in Queensland to make a submission to the Senate Privileges Committee via the President. Then the Privileges Committee would have to form a view as to whether to follow the practice or not.
—How horrifying.

—Senator Hogg says, `How horrifying.' I think it would be horrifying, Senator Hogg—not horrifying that we would set to right any of the wrongs of the opposition, but that the time of the Privileges Committee—and your time, Senator Hogg, is valuable—would be taken up in consideration of those sorts of matters. This is obviously the floodgate which could be potentially opened by the operation of the convention as it currently stands.

BREAK.PARA: Obviously there has to be some leniency, but I believe that, unless it is possible to identify a specific person as a result of a reference made in this chamber, it is inappropriate for us to be extending a right of reply and incorporation of it in Hansard to everybody who may potentially be caught in a class of persons. Imagine if 40,000 members of the National Party in Queensland all replied to some of the things that we hear Senator Carr and his friends saying in the chamber every day. If that were to happen, the Hansard would be several pages thick, the cost to the taxpayer would be outrageous and the good time of the Senate would be wasted.

What I am saying is I believe that the President should give some consideration to referring this matter to the Procedure Committee or to the Privileges Committee, as she thinks appropriate, and, in particular, asking either one of those committees to form a view as to what the threshold test should be for a person to have a right to make a submission and ultimately to have it considered by the Privileges Committee.

If I were to say that members of the Labor Party, members of a particular branch of the Labor Party or members of a particular branch of a union had been indulging in whatever thuggish tactics, I do not believe it is appropriate that they should have a right of reply. If, however, I said that a person who was the secretary of a branch of a union—and there could only be one person—had indulged in thuggish activities, then obviously that person should have a right of reply against what I have to say.

In my view, the test should be whether a person or particular persons are exclusively identifiable by the reference made in this chamber. If a reference is made to a class of persons—and in the case of the matter before the Privileges Committee, I think Senator Boswell made reference to staff of a particular publication—then I believe that that does not necessarily mean that particular people are identifiable. There was no reference made to Mr Mulheron by name in the speech made by Senator Boswell. I do not believe that people were identifiable and therefore I do not believe an egregious wrong has been done against them. They have not been adversely referred to, in the same way as those people would probably not be entitled to take an action for defamation.

Honourable senators should bear in mind that this procedure was put in place because people who were adversely referred to in this chamber had no right to seek redress by way of an action for defamation. So, accordingly, Mr Acting Deputy President, may I respectfully suggest to you that you convey to the President my concerns about this matter and suggest that she give some consideration to referring it either to the Procedure Committee or to the Privileges Committee to ensure that we do not open a floodgate which would allow potentially thousands and thousands of people who feel aggrieved to have a statement incorporated in Hansard when they have not been personally referred to in this chamber and they are not exclusively identifiable as a result of a particular speech that has been given by an honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I am the subject of the matter before the Senate Committee of Privileges, I feel that I should make some statement. On 18 June 1997 I made a speech in this chamber about Pauline Hanson and the damage she was doing to Australia and about the people that she was associated with, especially some of the more extremist groups that she had links with. One of those people, a Mr Platt, I did mention in my speech. The other one, a Mr Mulheron, I did not make any reference to.

SPEECH.PARA: As a senator of this parliament for some 14 years now, I have taken my duties very seriously. The Senate is the forum to which I was elected and the forum where I make contributions. I do so only after serious consideration of my words and their likely impact. I do so only after extensive research. I do so only after deciding that it is in the public benefit to make certain facts known. It would be a sad day if senators were curtailed in this chamber from exposing extremists. Once we are possessed of such information and have checked and considered it carefully, it is our responsibility to communicate it to the Australian people. To hold back would be to be an accessory to the activities of the likes of Ray Platt.

To keep this information private would be to stand by and do nothing while unsuspecting and decent Australians fall into the trap set by the likes of Platt and his Strategy magazine. The right forum for senators to use is the Senate. That is what we were elected to do and this is the place to do it in.

Mr Platt's Strategy newspaper is a haven for many of the undesirable far Right elements in our society. The Strategy is full of one‐world‐government conspiracy theories. As editor, Ray Platt must take full responsibility for the offensive articles about Jews and for the advertising space he has sold to groups such as the League of Rights, Lock, Stock and Barrel and Christian identity ministries and—whether he sold it or not—for Pauline Hanson's half‐page ad in the Strategy. Mr Platt is saying he did not sell the advertisement, but it is in there. What negotiations took place between Mr Platt and Pauline Hanson, I am not privy to. But, undeniably, there was a half‐page ad for Pauline Hanson in the Strategy newspaper.

Platt must take responsibility for promoting a tour by American extremist Jack McLamb, an associate of Bo Gritz who stood on the US presidential ticket along with the Ku Klux Klan's David Duke. That was in a paper. Platt must also take responsibility for publishing articles by Peter Archer and Tony Pitt, who are One Nation organisers and office holders. The Strategy newspaper also ran a story about an interview with One Nation's Victorian convener, Andrew Carne, complete with a photo.

While some articles may be harmless and merely ridiculous, other articles show up their true agenda of extreme Right thinking. I consider that my speech has been successful in alerting Australians to the dangers he and his newspaper represent. I voted for the legislation that allows Mr Platt to have his say this way. That is part of democracy.

Of course, many might think that, with his own newspaper, Mr Platt has had plenty of opportunity to defend himself and does not need to go whingeing to a Senate committee. I wish to point out to the Senate that Mr Platt has used his newspaper to make malicious and slanderous attacks on me, which so far I have been willing to let go through to the keeper as just one of the hazards of speaking out. I do not own a newspaper, but I am a senator, elected by the people of Queensland to raise issues of importance in the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: By bringing this matter to the attention of the Privileges Committee, Mr Platt gives me the opportunity to repeat with the greatest confidence the facts about his activities and the people with whom he associates. Ordinary Australians do not believe the same things as Mr Platt, or his newspaper would be a national daily. Mr Platt's connection to the One Nation party was integral to the speech I gave because it showed that Pauline Hanson's party was advertising for money and support in a newspaper tainted with extremism, racism and anti-Semitism. These are not social behaviours to which ordinary Australians aspire.

In an interview with the Australian on 31 May this year, the national director of One Nation, David Ettridge, explained how radical far Right activists `won't have any effect on the policy, direction or literature of One Nation'. He said:
I'm streetwise enough to spot them and get rid of them.

Mr Ettridge has shown himself unable to deliver. My speech last June showed that One Nation was already advertising in Ray Platt's Strategy newspaper. Since then, the links with other unsavoury groups of the far Right have grown more blatant.

In the current edition of Lock, Stock and Barrel, its editor, Ron Owen, describes in detail a meeting with David Oldfield at which strategy and policy were discussed. Also in attendance were Ian McNiven from the Firearm Owners Association and Tony Pitt, who has written for Strategy and is himself a One Nation office holder. Lock, Stock and Barrel even advertises full transcripts of the meeting for $5 plus postage. They claim Oldfield said:
If I'm going to fight anyone it's not going to be over keeping guns, it's going to be the bloody Indonesians.
Denis McCormack, chief spokesman for the group Australians Against Further Immigration, has also reported his meeting with Oldfield in the following way:
When I first actually met David Oldfield at my home—
note `at my home'—
on 13 June 1997, we covered many issues.

This information came from McCormack himself in a letter to the Australia/Israel Review . It is not me who is suggesting that there are these links. I am reporting what the people involved have said on the public record. Far from not having anything to do with the far Right, as suggested by Ettridge, the One Nation party is actively associating with them. Oldfield is going around harvesting their support one by one. It is no wonder that the One Nation party is experiencing a slide in political support.

Once again, I thank Mr Platt for the opportunity he has given me today to fulfil my duty as a senator in exposing the extremist Right for what they are and who they are. I look forward to further opportunities each time they, or their friends, wish to pursue their case by the Senate Privileges Committee. I seek leave to table a copy of a page out of the Lock, Stock and Barrel and a copy of a page out of the Australia/Israel Review.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: CARR

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not seen the particular documents, but we would be more than happy to agree, if I could actually see what they are.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The responses read as follows—
APPENDIX 1

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSES BY MR RAY PLATT AND MR P J MULHERONAGREED TO BY MR PLATT AND MR MULHERONAND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGESPURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF 28 FEBRUARY 1988

INTERJECT.PARA: Response by Mr Platt

Senator Boswell, on 18 June 1997, made a series of statements in a speech to the Senate which contained a number of errors. These errors in turn, have impugned myself, the publication of which I am the editor and both by name and association the good character of those who are contributing writers to The Strategy .

Over a period of some years the veracity of The Strategy has been proved by the subsequent reports, albeit often quite sometime later, by the major electronic and print media. The Strategy has an enviable reputation of reporting, precisely, inter views or comments made for publication, without selective quoting or distortion.
Senator Boswell stated:

Hanson and One Nation claim that they have nothing to do with extremist groups . . . But the facts are that Pauline Hanson's One Nation not only harbours and promotes extremists as office bearers and potential candidates, but it advertises in the anti‐semitic, racist and extremist rag, The Strategy .

Along with pages of glowing editorial, Ms Hanson's party has taken a half page ad soliciting for membership and donations. This was not done months ago when she was a naive politician. This advertisement appeared as recently as last month—May.

[A party official] was boasting to the national press about not having anything to do with extremists when his party had just done a deal with the country's most powerful extreme Right publication. The Strategy promotes many of Australia's leading extremists, . . . and even uses stories from the La Rouchian news service.

The One Nation have never taken an `ad' of any size or description in The Strategy nor have they solicited for any coverage of events. Any material appearing in this paper has been gained from media releases, which have been available to all publications, or from reports by someone attending meetings etc.

The La Rouchian news service, i.e. EIRNS, is, according to all reports, a White House accredited news service and has been singled out from time to time by the President to ask questions at press interviews.
Senator Boswell further stated:

The editor of The Strategy , Ray Platt, organised the visit to Australia of the US militia extremist, Jack McLamb. McLamb's business partner, Bo Gritz, had stood as a Vice‐presidential nominee on the ticket of former Ku Klux klansman, David Duke.

Jack McLamb is one of Arizona's most decorated police officers (retired) and serves on more community based committees than room permits here to list. Bo Gritz is one of America's most decorated Vietnam war veterans and, it is said, was involved in the `Special Services' operation that freed the American hostages from Iran back in the 80's. Both these men have been involved in helping to break (peacefully) various `stand‐off' situations.
Suffice to say—having met and spent two days with Jack McLamb—I have never met a finer or more Christian person.
What an honour for myself—to be linked with such distinguished gentlemen!

Mr Peter Archer, also referred to by Senator Boswell, has been a contributing writer to The Strategy . Mr Archer was not involved in organising the Jack McLamb tour; this was an inadvertent error on the part of the paper that connected Mr Archer to that tour. Mr Archer has only ever been a non‐paid voluntary contributor of articles.
For the Senator to praise our paper as notorious (thesaurus: celebrated, distinguished, famed, renowned, well‐known) would indeed be an honour coming from another.

The Inverell Forum 94 was also mentioned. It has to be said that this paper has had the privilege of sponsoring the Inverell Forum for a number of years. Over the years there have been a wide variety of `notable' (in their field) speakers—doctors, authors, and lay people of many talents and persuasions including a NSW National Party politician and some highly respected university lecturers. For the senator to label such an event in this derogatory manner shows his lack of knowledge.
Ray Platt
I refer to statements made in the Senate by Senator Ronald Boswell (Qld) on 18 June 1997, and wish to refute the slanderous statements in the Senator's speech:
1. Senator Boswell: "But the facts are that Pauline Hanson's One Nation . . . advertises in the anti‐semitic, racist and extremist rag The Strategy . . . "

Senator Boswell has made false reference to The Strategy as anti‐semitic, racist and extremist, thus sufficiently identifying the newspaper's staff as `anti‐semitic and racist' as to injuriously affect their good reputation and impugn their good character.

Under the Magna Carta and Universal Declaration of Human Rights, I am not bound at law to divulge religious or political beliefs; however, Senator Boswell's anti‐semitic slur gives sufficient cause to refute the allegation in defence of my good character, which has been called into question without genuine regard for protocol and manners, by false and misleading assertions.
2. Senator Boswell: "Not only does Ms Hanson sell her wares in the nation's most notorious far Right newspaper, but she recruits her organisers from its staff . . . "

Senator Boswell has, again, asserted an unsavoury connotation in recruitment for political parties from the ranks of the staff of The Strategy. Nor is `it' beholden to any so‐called anti‐semitic organisation.

Comment by Senator Boswell directed at staff members of The Strategy has served to discriminate, and vilify them as being anti‐semitic, whereas several are of Judaeo‐Christian ancestry but not Zionist‐fundamentalists. The comments deeply offend me, and relatives and friends.

Reference to a `deal being struck' between [a party official] and The Strategy is false and misleading. Similarly, the allegation that The Strategy placed the Independent member for Oxley's party advertisement is untrue. Ms Hanson's articles are mere press‐releases, borne out by the fact that they bear a `Net' reference, and were offered by me as news‐worthy items to the Editor, Mr Ray Platt.

The Honourable Senator has made remarks, many of which are not substantiated in fact, but the product of his erroneous assertions, that have impugned the name and good character of an array of people.

I conclude now with the comment that I expect the Honourable Senator to apologise for vilification he has levelled at the current Strategy staff and myself, and that he will accord us the same civility when we (I) express our civil and political rights. The main‐stream media had misreported much and misconstrued the context of Hanson speeches for sensationalism to sell many newspapers, whereas The Strategy strives for truth.
Peter J Mulheron

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on the Small Superannuation Accounts Amendment Bill 1997 and on the principles relating to the provisions governing the early release of superannuation benefits, as contained in the bill, together with submissions received by the committee and a transcript of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate the tabling speech in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Twenty‐sixth Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation
Tabling Speech
This is the twenty‐sixth report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.
This report does two things. It covers the reference to the Committee of a Bill as well as a broader reference involving the principles contained in that Bill.

On 19 June 1997, the Senate referred the Small Superannuation Accounts Amendment Bill 1997 to the Committee for inquiry and report. The provisions of this Bill tighten the arrangements relating to the early release of monies held in the Superannuation Holding Accounts Reserve (SHAR). The Committee was required to report on the provisions of that Bill.

The principles dealt with in this Bill are to be applied to the entire superannuation system. Accordingly, on 26 June the Senate extended the reference to a comprehensive analysis and full public hearings on the implication of the provisions of the Bill, particularly their impact on low and middle income earners.
The Bill contains three principles for tightening the provisions governing the early release of superannuation benefits as outlined by the Government in the 1997 budget documents. These were:
1. to remove access to superannuation monies where the balance is less than $500;
2. to restrict access to superannuation monies for persons under preservation age who are permanently leaving Australia; and

3. to restrict access to superannuation monies on the grounds of severe financial hardship by instituting a new severe financial hardship test which requires persons to have been in receipt of specified Commonwealth income support payments for a continuous period of 52 weeks if under age 55, or for a cumulative period of over 39 weeks if over age 55.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Small Superannuation Accounts Amendment Bill 1997

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill affects the operation of the Superannuation Accounts Holding Reserve. SHAR was established by the Small Superannuation Accounts Act 1995 , commenced operating on 1 July 1995 and is administered by the Australian Taxation Office. It is a fee‐free collection system for small superannuation contributions, and provides for employers to pay superannuation contributions to the SHAR rather than to superannuation funds.

SHAR was established to accept contributions from employers where the employer's superannuation fund will not accept a particular contribution because of requirements that fees and charges cannot exceed the interest earned on such amounts. It is part of the small amounts protection regime.
Amendments in the Small Superannuation Accounts Bill restrict the circumstances when monies held in SHAR can be withdrawn, by:
. removing the $500 threshold
. removing the permanent departure ground, and
. establishing an objective test for hardship.

The amendments tighten the preservation arrangements in the SHAR. These amendments were to take effect on 1 July 1997, but do not apply to withdrawal requests lodged with the Commissioner of Taxation before that date.
Chapter 7 of the report constitutes the specific report on the Committee's inquiry into this Bill.

The matters raised in the amendments to the Small Superannuation Accounts Amendment Bill 1997 are also to apply to the whole of the superannuation system. To achieve the broader changes, the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations and the Retirement Savings Accounts Regulations needed to be amended with effect from 1 July 1997. Consequently, Statutory Rules Nos 150—153 amending those regulations were gazetted on 26 June 1997, and tabled in the Parliament on 25 August 1997.

The Committee's responsibility, however, was to inquire into the issues and not to recommend on the amending regulations themselves. Accordingly, the report examines, in turn, the general issue of preservation of superannuation and then the three specific issues raised by the amendments, namely:
. abolition of the $500 threshold;
. release of monies to a non‐resident only after preservation age; and
. replacement of the `severe financial hardship' test with an objective test of hardship based on receipt of specified Commonwealth payments for a specified period.

The Committee received 21 submissions and conducted three public hearings, the last of which was to hear from the relevant Government officials. During the first two hearings the Committee received evidence from the major accounting firms as well as internationally oriented companies affected by the changes to the permanent departure rules.

In relation to the changes to the hardship rules, evidence was provided by financial counsellors as well as individuals affected, which provided the Committee with useful case studies on the effects of the Government's changes.
Other evidence was provided by superannuation industry bodies covering all three measures, including the abolition of the $500 threshold.

There were some differences in opinion among the Committee members about these changes to the early access rules. These differences are reflected in paragraphs in the report which identify which Senators had a particular view about what. Also, there were some differences in the recommendations which appear in Chapter 6.

Particularly in relation to the changes in visa classes which affected the permanent departure ground, the Committee found this reference to be complex. The Committee received substantial evidence on the relationship between visa changes and superannuation, and the resulting effects on international business operations.

Committee members differed in their conclusions as to the appropriateness or otherwise of early access by overseas visitors on temporary business visa holders. However, there was general agreement that there should be no exemption from the application of the Super Guarantee for those people.

The Committee generally agreed with the Government that, in relation to Australian citizens or permanent residents departing overseas for whatever period, the release of preserved superannuation benefits should only occur after such persons have reached preservation age.
The Committee also generally agreed on a package of changes to the Government's new test for financial hardship.
In relation to the abolition of the $500 threshold, Coalition and Labor Senators considered that the threshold should be reduced to $200.
The Coalition Senators accepted the Government's position that restriction on early access to super was necessary for the successful negotiation of social security agreements with other countries.

However, the Coalition Senators expressed their concern at the delay in completing these agreements, and at the seeming lack of understanding of the differences between Australia's superannuation scheme and that of other countries.

In the longer term, the Coalition Senators accept that early access should be granted to temporary business visitors on their permanent departure. This should occur as international social security agreements are finalised.

I make special mention of the work of the secretariat in the preparation of this report. There was a considerable amount of research required in areas not within the expertise of this Committee, and I know there was a committed and professional effort made in producing the draft report for the Committee's deliberations. So a special thanks to the secretary, Peter Hallahan, executive assistant, Jade Ricza, and the research officers, Rod Adams and James Greentree, for their good work.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry wanted to say a few words on this report. While we are waiting for him to come, I would draw to the Senate's attention that this is a report on the Small Superannuation Accounts Amendment Bill 1997 on the principles relating to the provisions governing the early release of superannuation benefits, as contained in the bill. This is obviously a very important matter, particularly given the increasing numbers of Australians who are facing financial destitution as the high levels of unemployment and redundancy gripping this country are forcing more and more people to call upon their superannuation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the chamber. I was delayed because I was just hearing some particularly depressing news about the announcement by the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) a short time ago to close the public sector superannuation funds in the name of choice. Yet another broken promise by this government. But that is an issue we will deal with on another occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: The report that has been tabled by my colleague Senator Watson deals with further broken promises of this government in respect of superannuation. The report deals with the new regulations for tightening the early release of superannuation which, firstly, remove access to amounts in accounts of less than $500; secondly, preserve non‐residents' superannuation until preservation age in Australia; and, thirdly, introduce a new financial hardship test based on 52 weeks of continuous receipt of Commonwealth income support payments for those aged under 55, and 39 weeks cumulatively for those aged over 55.

Labor's recommendations in the report that has been tabled today provide fairness to the government's provision for the tightening of the early release of superannuation. The government's original proposals were too harsh in their effect on lower middle income earners, particularly those suffering from financial hardship. In a climate of high unemployment, high redundancy rates and community wide job insecurity, workers who are retrenched or made redundant should be able to access their superannuation, as they have been able to in the past, if in severe financial difficulty.

The government's new arrangements could have an adverse impact on at least 78,000 people. That figure is based on the number of applications received by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission for early release in 1996‐97. Of course, the impact of the other measures preserving non‐residents' superannuation in Australia until preservation age would impact on tens of thousands of people on top of the 78,000 people that the new hardship provisions would impact on.

Labor's key recommendations in the report are: a reduction in the government's proposed waiting time to qualify for financial hardship from 52 weeks to 12 weeks; a reduction in the amount below which people can withdraw superannuation from $500 to $200; a six‐month transitional period for Australian citizens permanently departing Australia, to allow those who made plans under the previous rules to change their arrangements; and, finally, full access to superannuation benefits for non‐residents permanently departing Australia.

The government's proposed measures, introduced by way of regulation, took effect from 1 July 1997. Labor has expressed concern in the report at the inconsistent approach of the government's overall superannuation policy, which restricts early access for people under 55, but effectively slugs Australians aged over 55 before they reach retirement age. The government is tightening the early release of superannuation on the one hand, but is forcing people who reach the age of 55 and who are in receipt of income support payments to draw down on their retirement nest egg before they are ready to retire. That is a result of social security measures that passed the Senate late last year. Effectively, the government is forcing battling Australians who have lost their job at the age of 55 to live on their superannuation.

The committee's report—I note with agreement from Senator Watson and his coalition colleagues—was critical of the government for the very short notice given before the changes took effect, describing it as `clearly inadequate'. This was supported by evidence from leading accounting firms, Coopers and Lybrand, Ernst and Young, and William M. Mercer. Mr Charles Blunt, whom some people here might remember as a former leader of the National Party, now Chief Executive Officer of the American Chamber of Commerce, described the short notice given by the government as `just a joke'. The report says that `many people were caught out by the swiftness of the government's changes'. The moves announced in the May 1997 budget were not gazetted until 26 June 1997, but took effect from 1 July 1997.

The committee heard evidence critical of the government for failing to consult. This is a constant theme with the government in respect of superannuation changes: announce the changes, say you are going to consult, do not listen or fail to consult, and then just implement what you have announced. We have seen that time and time again in respect of superannuation changes. The superannuation tax just highlights in one major way the government's failure to consult. The report is critical of the government for failing to consult with those who may be affected by the proposed changes before they were implemented.

One of the interesting, unintended consequences referred to by Mr Charles Blunt of the American Chamber of Commerce was the impact on the establishment of regional headquarters in Australia by international companies. The committee concluded that not allowing expatriate workers access to their superannuation upon permanent departure retrospectively overrides existing contracts of employment of those mainly chief executives, middle ranking management personnel temporarily in Australia. It was seen as a disincentive to the employment of expatriates and also to the establishment of regional headquarters in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: The location of regional headquarters in Australia provides significant opportunities for economic growth and growth in trade and employment. Given this government's dismal record on unemployment, it is somewhat surprising that they have introduced a measure which acts as a barrier to investment in Australia and the creation of Australian jobs. Even government members of the committee were critical of the use of superannuation policy as a leverage for negotiating social security agreements with other countries—this is the government's excuse.

Concern was expressed at the length of time it will take to conclude such agreements and the lack of appreciation by the bureaucracy of the difference between Australia's superannuation system and that of other countries. Certainly, I do not think committee members were particularly optimistic about the alleged reason given for the tightening up of some of these provisions or that these negotiations with other countries could be resolved in the next 10 or 20 years, if at all.

Labor calls on the government to reconsider its policy of early release of superannuation policy. Labor will be moving a motion to disallow the current regulations before the Senate. There is one final reason that may convince the government of the foolishness of its approach—aside from the reasons I have outlined. We invite the government to take the opportunity to implement the fairer arrangements that I have identified. By implementing these fairer arrangements proposed by Labor, the government will save $182 million over four years. I reiterate that to the Senate: by adopting Labor's fairer approach on the early release of superannuation, the government will save $182 million over four years.

That is an amazing amount of money. And that is on top of the basic unfairness of these measures which are highlighted in the report—not just by Labor senators; a number of coalition senators have expressed concern at times in the report at the policy approach of the government. But saving $182 million as a consequence of Labor's initiatives should convince the government, if anything can. Labor has taken a very positive approach in this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's very constructive.

—That is right, Senator Carr. It is very constructive. It is in the interests of people suffering hardship out there in the community that the tightening of provisions is carried out in a fair way. On top of that, the government saves $182 million over the next four years. I commend this report to the Senate.

BREAK.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator O'Chee) adjourned.

TITLE.XREF: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Brownhill) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

The bill would increase the amount previously appropriated for 1997 under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992 by $17.938 million in line with normal price adjustments, taking total funding for 1997 to $909.263 million.

In 1997, Commonwealth funding alone is expected to provide 43,000 student places over and above those provided in 1996. This will contribute substantially to an estimated total increase of 55,000 training places this year.

The bill would also amend the legislated amount for 1998 to $890.585 million to give effect to the 1997-98 budget decision to reduce funding for distribution to the states and territories by the Australian National Training Authority by $20 million. The bill would appropriate the same level of funding for 1999.

This budget measure provides an incentive to the states and territories to achieve efficiency gains in vocational education and training operations. The reduction represents about 0.7 per cent of total Commonwealth, state and territory funding for the sector. It should be seen against the background of a 37 per cent increase in Commonwealth funding for the sector since 1992.

At the Australian National Training Authority Ministerial Council meeting on 23 May 1997, all state and territory ministers supported a resolution noting that the reform of the vocational education and training sector agreed at the meeting has the potential to improve efficiency and effectiveness in the provision of vocational education and training.
Indeed, there should be substantial capacity to fund further growth in the sector from efficiency gains, including those resulting from the reforms led by the government.

These reforms are far‐reaching and demonstrate the government's commitment to vocational education and training. This year's budget has clearly demonstrated this commitment with an overall increase in the allocation for vocational education and training of $144 million, or almost 12 per cent, compared with the expenditure of $1.2 billion in 1995‐96 when the labor party was in government.
There has been some reallocation of funds to focus on our highest priority—the reform of the vocational education and training system and the establishment of new apprenticeships.

About 70 per cent of young Australians do not go from school into university. Vocational education and training has a major role to play in making sure young Australians obtain the skills needed to get them into jobs and in ensuring that Australian businesses can meet the challenges of the global economy.

The government is working with the states and territories to establish a training system which is responsive to the needs of industry and business enterprises, while operating within a national framework that is based on national standards and high quality, portable national qualifications.

The centrepiece of the government's reforms to vocational education and training is new apprenticeships. New apprenticeships are being developed to expand the number of training opportunities, especially for young people, into new industries to take advantage of economic growth and employment potential. At the ministerial council meeting last month, the states and territories endorsed arrangements to ensure implementation of new apprenticeships. This was an historic agreement to introduce a flexible, national system which meets the needs of today's enterprises wherever they may be located in Australia and whether they are large or small. It also maintains a focus on protecting the interests of those undertaking training, through simpler but quality‐assured regulatory arrangements.

The ministerial council agreed that there will new funding arrangements for off‐the‐job training for new apprenticeships, allowing employers and their trainees to choose the provider to deliver their training. For the first time, we will have a demand driven training system, giving employers an unprecedented opportunity to select the training that meets the needs of their business. More than $500 million a year in Commonwealth, state and territory funding will be available for allocation among public and private training providers under this `user choice' system. This bill provides the Commonwealth's contribution to that funding, as well as ongoing support for other aspects of vocational education and training provision.

The bill provides the solid foundation for building a national vocational education and training system which delivers quality outcomes, especially for young people, more efficiently and with less red tape. It provides a solid foundation for expanding opportunities for Australia's young people and improving the bottom‐line for Australian enterprises.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TITLE.XREF: TELECOMMUNICATIONS (INTERCEPTION) AND LISTENING DEVICE AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —We had reached the stage in relation to the Telecommunications (Interception) and Listening Device Amendment Bill 1997 where I was replying briefly to some of the matters that had been raised. (Quorum formed) This bill has two principal purposes: one is to authorise nominated members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to issue interception and listening device warrants for law enforcement purposes; the other is to include the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission in the telecommunications interception scheme. Only one of those issues has been raised in this place and that, of course, deals with the authorisation of nominated members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to issue interception warrants.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that the government has found itself in a situation where judges in the Federal Court and Family Court are declining to exercise their powers to issue warrants. As a result of this situation, the government has had to look to other means in order to issue warrants.

In relation to clause 19 of the bill, the government has made it very clear that it is just not handing out this power to anyone; it is looking at people who will have to be nominated by the Attorney‐General and those people will come from a pool consisting of the Deputy President of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, a full‐time senior member, a part‐time senior member and a normal member. The deputy president has to be a qualified lawyer; the full‐time senior member has to be either a qualified lawyer or have special knowledge or skills as determined by the Governor‐General; and for the part‐time senior member or member there is a requirement that the person must have a practising certificate and must have been enrolled to practise for not less than five years. In other words, in the first instance we have the requirement that the pool from which the Attorney‐General draws is a pool of qualified people. That does not automatically mean that that person who so qualifies is automatically nominated. The Attorney‐General then exercises some discretion and nominates that person.

I would point out to Senator Bolkus who thought that some criminal experience was valuable in this area that, indeed, Family Court judges who have hitherto exercised this power have had no criminal experience. In fact, most Federal Court judges have had no criminal experience. Some of the finest judges in relation to the criminal law jurisdiction have had commercial backgrounds. So I do not see that as any particular problem in relation to the exercise of this power.

The other aspect that I would raise is that in the Grollo decision the High Court had misgivings about the appropriateness of judges consenting to perform the function of issuing warrants. Even the High Court said that it was troubled by the matter. It went further in relation to the situation of the ACT where it indicated that there could be a conflict of interest. As a result of that, two of the ACT judges contacted the Attorney‐General and declined to exercise this power. It is a problem that I will touch on later when we come to one of the amendments posed by the Democrats. But suffice to say that, where you have a judge who is practising in the jurisdiction, there could well be problems with a conflict where that judge has previously issued a warrant for the interception of a telecommunication and then is dealing with bail of a person who is charged or is, indeed, dealing with the trial of that person. You simply could not have that happen. So there are aspects of conflict of interest to be looked at in this matter as well.

I reiterate that the government considers this to be a most serious power indeed. That was alluded to by speakers from the opposition, the Greens and the Democrats. It does not take this step lightly. It is a step that the government takes in an effort to have some way out of the impasse in which it finds itself. The interception of telecommunications is an important tool in the fight against organised crime but, at the same time, it is a serious exercise of power by a state over individual or individuals. What the government has come up with is a balanced approach whereby the liberty of the individual is protected, whilst at the same time ensuring that there is a strong mechanism available in the fight of organised crime.

I find it regrettable that the opposition cannot agree to this and that others will oppose this bill. This bill has not been put together as some ad hoc remedy. It has been put together in a concise and rational manner to address a problem which was not of the government's making. It was the Grollo decision which said that the issuing of a warrant was an administrative matter. It was the Federal Court judges and the Family Court judges who said, `We do not wish to exercise this power to issue warrants.' Where does the government go? What room has it got left to move in? None, unless it comes up with legislative amendments.

For there to be attacks on the government in relation to civil liberty or infringing on the rights of individuals is really quite out of order, because what the government is trying to do here is address a situation which was beyond its control. If those critical of the government were serious, they would look seriously at supporting this bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 4), before item 1, insert:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4A Arrangements with States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory

PARA.TAB: The Governor‐General may make arrangements with the Governor of a State, the Australian Capital Territory Executive or the Administrator of the Northern Territory for the performance by all or any of the persons who from time to time hold office as Judges of the Supreme Court of that State or Territory of the functions of a Judge under Part VI.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, page 6 (after line 10), after item 14, insert:
14A Subsection 5(1) (definition of State )
Repeal the definition, substitute:
State , except where otherwise provided, includes the Northern Territory.
(3) Schedule 1, page 6 (after line 33), after item 18, insert:
18A Subsection 6D(1) (definition of Judge )
Repeal the definition, substitute:
Judge means:

TAB.TAB: (a) a person who is a Judge or former Judge of a court created by the Parliament; or
(b) a Judge of the Supreme Court of a State in respect of whom an appropriate arrangement in force under section 4A is applicable; or

(c) a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory who is not a Judge referred to in paragraph (a) and in respect of whom an appropriate arrangement under section 4A is applicable; or
(d) a person who is a former Judge of the Supreme Court of a State or of the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Schedule 2, page 14 (after line 3), before item 1, insert:
Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 12AA Arrangements with States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of this Division, the Governor‐General may make arrangements with the Governor of a State, the Australian Capital Territory Executive or the Administrator of the Northern Territory for the performance by all or any of the persons who from time to time hold office as Judges of the Supreme Court of that State or Territory of the functions of a Judge under section 12G.

SPEECH.PARA: Insert:
Judge means:

TAB.TAB: (a) a person who is a Judge or former Judge of a court created by the Parliament; or
(b) a Judge of the Supreme Court of a State in respect of whom an appropriate arrangement in force under section 12AA is applicable; or

(c) a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory who is not a Judge referred to in paragraph (a) and in respect of whom an appropriate arrangement under section 12AA is applicable; or
(d) a person who is a former Judge of the Supreme Court of a State or of the Australian Capital Territory or the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Schedule 3, page 16 (after line 3), before item 1, insert:
1A Subsection 219A(1) (at the end of the definition of Judge )
Add:
; or (d) a person who is a former Judge of the Supreme Court of a State or the Northern Territory.

The issue before us is not the illegal tapping of phones but the legal tapping of phones. During the second reading debate, I heard some senators straying into the area of illegality. That is obviously an area which we would all be extremely concerned about, but the Telecommunications (Interception) and Listening Device Amendment Bill 1997 focuses entirely on the limited number of legal telecommunications interceptions allowed through the warranting process. Every speaker, especially those from the govern ment, confirmed that they would prefer judges to issue those warrants.

In 1994 it was recorded that 30 out of 35 federal judges were designated as being appropriate to issue warrants. I am told that the number of judges who are capable of issuing warrants at this time is between 50 and 55. I would remind the Senate that there are over 700 judges in Australia.

What we know is that the High Court has said that this function is an administrative one not a judicial one, but it has not said that judges may not do it. It has said that they may continue to issue warrants as designated persons. It is the federal judges who have now said that they do not wish to carry on because of their workload. It is the view of the Labor Party that they should simply be given the resources to relieve that workload, and that is a legitimate argument. If the demand for their services is such that they need extra resources, we should be examining that issue but that issue cannot be resolved through this bill.

The judges have said essentially that they do not wish to do this job anymore. However, we all find some difficulty with that proposition because, in the meantime, they have been carrying on doing it. So there are senators and others who think, `Maybe it's just a bluff and they could do it regardless.'

Our approach is to recognise the problem, recognise the government's solution and essentially attack the problem from a different direction—that is, we would increase the pool of judges from which the Attorney-General can draw. We do not suggest that the more than 700 Australian judges would all be suitable or would all want to do the job, but we have laid out a set of judges who we do think would be suitable.

We think judges of the Supreme Court of each state would be suitable. We think judges of the Supreme Court of the ACT or the Northern Territory would be suitable. We think a former judge of the Supreme Court of a state or territory would be suitable. Since every party has unequivocally said that it is judges they want to use first and foremost, we say to the government that here is a method by which you can increase your pool of judges.

I would also remind the Senate that the AAT itself includes judges. My information is that the president is a judge of the Federal Court and 15 presidential members of the AAT are judges of the Federal Court. So by all means throw them into the pool as well from the AAT.

This amendment is designed to take into account the particular circumstances that we find ourselves in. But it also has the benefit of enlarging access on a geographical basis; of making more judges available in cities, states and large regional centres where at present it is difficult to get the warrant process easily enacted.

A judge means a judge or a former judge and will reflect the community concern clearly expressed by Senator Bolkus, of which we are aware, that the community wants these functions to be performed by judges wherever possible. We would suggest to you that these amendments are not contradictory to the government's intention or Labor's intention, but complementary to them. They in no way go against the spirit or the intention of the existing legislation, and in no way go against the spirit or the intention of the proposed amendments; they simply enlarge the pool.

If anyone on either side of the chamber wants to tell me that state Supreme Court judges are not suitable for this task, having clearly outlined on the Labor side their preference for judges with criminal experience and background, and having outlined on both sides of the chamber their preference for judges anyway, I want to hear them publicly say to me why state judges cannot also fulfil this role.
I do not think I need to speak much longer. I think the amendments are quite plain on the face of them. I look forward to hearing your remarks and, hopefully, to experiencing your support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say on behalf of the government that it is unable to support this amendment. Although there would be an increase in the pool, the question of whether the Supreme Court judges with their judicial duties would be in the same position as the Federal Court judges and the Family Court judges remains to be seen.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a similar problem with ACT court judges, as mentioned in the High Court, that is, the question of a conflict. There is no doubt that a state Supreme Court judge would be well qualified to make a decision of this sort, but the trouble is that in some of the smaller states, where the number of judges is fewer, they could well be deciding on a matter which comes before them in the criminal sittings. That of course poses a conflict situation. Although the pool is enlarged, you would need to make an application, perhaps, outside the state to try to avoid that. I am looking at, say, a state like my home state of Western Australia where there are only a dozen or so judges. It might have grown a bit more than that, but it is not a great deal. If you went to a pool of some 700 judges, as mentioned, you might well be looking beyond the state's border. That then has problems for the authorities concerned.

As mentioned previously, the Commonwealth cannot force judges to do this job if they do not want to. That is a problem we face as well. That is what caused the amendments in the previous Labor government's time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to start off by asking the minister a question, and I would like to make some comments in response to Senator Murray after I get the answer. Minister, could you advise how many intercept warrants were actually issued in the last financial year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that on notice and make inquiries. Perhaps we could continue with the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I would like to make a few comments. The minister, probably a bit loosely, said that the opposition is opposing the bill. We are not opposing that part of the bill that relates to the Police Integrity Commission in New South Wales. We are on the record as consistently saying that we think that body should come within the ambit of this act. As I say, the minister may have been a bit loose in his language, but I want to make that clear at this particular stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I want to make is that we do not accept the argument put up by the government, nor do we accept the concerns of the Democrats in respect of this matter. The minister said that judges are declining. I think the facts will show that last year hundreds of intercept warrants were issued and there has been no hold up in the issuing of such warrants. The administration of justice has not been detrimentally affected by the reliance on Federal Court judges or federal judges to issue warrants under the act.

For the government to argue that judges are declining and warrants are not being issued is, I think, a misrepresentation of the situation. As I said, hundreds of warrants have been issued and the administration of justice is continuing at an acceptable rate. I say that to Senator Murray as well. He is concerned that the judges may go on strike. We do have a responsibility in this parliament to make the law, to balance all the policy considerations. We should not be pushed around by either judges or police forces. We should take their considerations into account and, of course, we should balance them in the context of all the concerns that we should take into account.

One of those concerns, of course, is to protect innocent Australians from excessive intrusiveness when it comes to telephone interception. That is particularly why, when this legislation was first framed, the balance was struck between federal jurisdiction judges having a role in issuing warrants and not judges of any other state or territory jurisdiction—and, in fact, no other person who does not hold a judicial office under the federal government.

So that is the balance that needs to be remembered. Our priority and our concern here needs to be to strike a balance again and to maintain a balance. Judges are in fact issuing warrants in their hundreds; they may in fact be knocking some back. I do not know how many have been knocked back, but it is within their ambit of operation and it is within their capacity to refuse the issuing of warrants in some circumstances. No‐one has argued that any police investigation has been jeopardised by a particular judge going on strike.

The other concern raised by Senator Ellison is Grollo's case. Grollo's case was quite explicit. Six to one judges held that the exercise of the power to issue a telecom interception warrant by a judge was a valid exercise of power by the officers involved. It was not inconsistent with the exercise of judicial power. The High Court, of course, laid down some basic preconditions that needed to be met.

What the government, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) and the Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) cannot shy away from is that that particular case held six to one that the exercise of this power was constitutional. Not only that, in Wilson's case last year the High Court upheld the previous authority on the matter—Grollo's case. So we have had two recent High Court rulings upholding the constitutionality of this particular provision.

What we have to direct ourselves to on this particular instance is the proposal being put up by the Democrats. When this legislation was first framed, it was clearly understood that we were talking here of a federal function. Telecommunications is very much within the constitutional responsibility of the federal government. I think it was held by all sides of parliament at the time that, as such a function, it should be in the control of the Commonwealth government.

As a consequence of that, we held that it should be federal judicial officers who should have the power to assess any application for an intercept warrant. I do not think we should deviate from that particular position now. There may be a need for more judicial officers to exercise discretion here—that is the argument that the government is putting up—but I, for one, do not, and the opposition does not, accept the argument that we should broaden the net and allow state judges to exercise power as well.

BREAK.PARA: Firstly, we are talking about a federal function. Secondly, at the time that this matter was first being canvassed in this place, there was real and legitimate concern about allowing state judges with the influence—and some of them under the influence—of their police forces to have the capacity to issue warrants. There was concern at that particular time about what was happening in Queensland with Premier Joh Bjelke‐Petersen and his lack of knowledge of the separation of powers. There was even concern about the corruption of some aspects of the police force in that state.

You could look at recent events in Queensland and say, `Well, there still has to be some concern about whether the separation of powers is understood in that particular state,' whether, in fact, there is sufficient separation from some judicial officers. We have seen the fiasco over recent months of commissions of inquiry in Queensland and how those commissions have been struck out on the basis of bias.

So I think the policy concern is still a real one, and I think the concern about whether the separation of powers is understood sufficiently enough in some areas of some state jurisdictions is a real one as well. I do not say that is a legitimate concern in respect of most state jurisdictions, but I do say that it can be a problem. It has proven itself to be a problem in some state jurisdictions over recent years.
So for those reasons, Senator Murray, we do not support your amendments. Not only for those reasons, though I accept that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is better than the government's from your point of view.
—No, from our point of view it is better that it be maintained under federal control, as opposed to allowing the net to broaden into state jurisdictions.

BREAK.PARA: The other thing about the Democrats' amendments is that, in essence, despite Senator Murray's exhortations, at the end of the day the Attorney-General would probably still find himself in a position where he would be relying on the same range of officers that the government has put up in its package. So we do not accept the Democrats' amendments for those two reasons and, as a consequence, we will not be supporting the Democrats' amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is better that I make a few remarks first, and then the Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) will be able to respond. I would indicate that I have some difficulty with the arguments that have been put before us. If the federal judges have recused or excused or excised themselves, you no longer have any federal judges available.

SPEECH.PARA: So I would have thought that, given Labor's choice—although, quite obviously, it is best to keep it neatly within the federal role—state judges are your next step before you go on to the AAT. What Labor essentially is saying is that they do not accept state judges, and we cannot have federal judges; therefore, they will accept the AAT. That is the indisputable logic of what they have just said.

Then the minister said he is concerned with conflicts of interest. Frankly, conflicts of interest arise now. It is always up to the judges themselves to recuse themselves or to refuse to deal with a particular issue. That issue is the same whether it is federal or state—and, in fact, it gets easier because of the larger pool.

The third point is that judges themselves are capable, by virtue of the authority vested in them by the constitution, of refusing to act at all in this situation. We have the Federal Court judges who have already refused to do that. So it is possible the state judges themselves—some or all of them—might take the same attitude and refuse.

The fourth and most important rebuttal of the minister's remarks, I think, is that the Attorney-General himself or herself makes the choice as to which person to approach. Now he does that and he would do so in the future. So if there were a problem, as outlined by Senator Bolkus, with a Queensland judge or if there were a problem in the view of the Attorney-General as to competency, ability or appropriateness in a particular geographical or jurisdictional area, the Attorney-General would be able to deal with it.

BREAK.PARA: I have not found the reasons for opposing the Democrats' amendments convincing from either the government or Labor. From both sides it is the `we will have our model and nothing else' sort of approach, which I think is regrettable when we have actually tried to be of assistance in this matter.
Minister, I have for my assistance checked on my last notes as to how many judges there are in Australia. Last year there were 767. So it was a pretty big pool.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus asked a question about the number of warrants that were issued last year. The figures we have available are for 1995-96 and they show that there were 747 warrants issued. They were contained in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 report that is provided for under the act, which is a very good mechanism indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: The judges have said that they are continuing to issue warrants on an interim basis only until alternative arrangements are made. That is only a temporary arrangement. This issue was not a problem when the 747 warrants were issued. So to rely on those numbers is by no means safe, because what we have now is only a temporary situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fine line, isn't it? What we are assessing here is the best way to go to ensure that some restraint is put on the issuing of warrants when police want to tap the phones of citizens. We have to be very careful that we put the civil rights of Australians up front in this.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no minor matter that people have their phones tapped. It is also no minor matter that there are criminals in the community and we all want them caught. So it is a big balancing act. That is where the judiciary, whether it likes it or not—and, apparently, some of it does not like it—has a very responsible role to play.

I think most citizens would want to know that, before a warrant was issued which allowed a police officer to tap their phone, the matter had been before a judge with consider able experience who had listened to the reasons and did not issue that warrant lightly. I do not think citizens would want it to go beyond judges.

This is a piece of federal legislation. I have the feeling that Labor's position that it should therefore remain with federal judges is a strong one. Senator Murray has told us that there are 767 judges in Australia. Does that include state judges or is that federal judges?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is everybody.
