—That is the total. I do not know what the number of federal judges is. Senator Ellison for the government has told us that in the last year in which figures were available there were 747 warrants issued to allow phones to be tapped. I would love to have a list of whose phones were being tapped. In fact, I think that is information that ought to be available to the public—after the minimal amount of time lapse anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: That information would make interesting reading for us all, particularly for people who are active in public life and who feel that their phones may be tapped for reasons which are not to do with criminal activities and are not to do with justifiable suspicion on behalf of the authorities but may have more to do with paranoia by the authorities which is wrongly directed against citizens active in public life.

So it is a difficult matter, but I side with the Labor Party on this. As a strong defender of civil liberties, I believe it is a most grave matter to issue a warrant for police to listen in on phone calls. It is necessary on occasions. It ought to come before judges.

The number of warrants we are dealing with is, on average, two per day for the whole of the nation. I do not think that is going to break the judicial officers down. I do not think that is a burden that is beyond the judicial capacity of the Federal Court judges. If it is, then the government has to see to it that the judges are given the augmented wherewithal to be able to deal with that average of one or two warrants coming before each judge per annum.

I come down very strongly on the side of civil liberties and safeguarding them. I am not saying that we should not have phone taps. Occasionally they are essential and the results coming from them bring good to society. We must not be cavalier about it; we must be extremely cautious.

I think the government would do better putting those resources into the judiciary, which is going to ensure that these warrants are dealt with in the fullest and most thorough sense. Citizens will be assured that it is practised judges in the federal arena who are dealing with those warrants and nothing less than that and the judges will be assured that they are given the wherewithal to be able to deal with what is, sadly, the increasing burden/wish of the authorities of the state to tap into the phone conversations of citizens. Let us face it: many of those citizens are going to be innocent, but there are also those who might have something to hide or who might be caught doing something against the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Ellison has satisfied the committee that it would not be better for the government to accept Senator Murray's amendments. I imagine it would be better than nothing. I have not heard reasons from the government which would convince me to vote against Senator Murray's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Advice from the Attorney‐General's Department needs to be treated with caution. I found that from a recent experience in another area. I am treating any advice that comes from the Attorney‐General's Department with extreme caution. Senator Bolkus has indicated that some of the advice, at least, may have been such that one would need to have another careful look at it. From what has been said by both the opposition and the government, I am not convinced that Senator Murray's proposed amendments should be opposed.

I know the situation implies that, if there are not sufficient judges in the extended pool, you go back to the AAT. That is a bit of a problem. I wonder whether Senator Murray could explain to the committee whether that would be a last resort, that you would have to exhaust the extended pool before you went to the AAT. Perhaps Senator Murray might explain briefly to the committee his intention and the effect of the amendments, if they were carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the nub of the issue, and that is a good question. Without doubt, it is an exhaustive process. First, Federal Court judges are approached. When their ranks have been exhausted, judges or former judges of the Supreme Court are approached. Only when their ranks have been exhausted are members of the AAT approached. In fact, later amendments that I will speak to would achieve exactly that. Since, according to the government—as I said, I do believe them—the federal judges have said that they will not continue this process, to my mind the first rung is knocked out, at least for the moment, until such time as they may reconsider that issue. So I would then move on to the state judges.

—Your answer seems to imply that it is a mandatory step, but do your amendments not say that the Governor-General may make arrangements? There is probably no way that you could force the government to make arrangements, but I think it is a fact of your amendments that there is a wide range of discretion and no compulsion for the Commonwealth Attorney to make arrangements with any particular states. The amendments that I see state that the Governor-General may make such arrangements, and the word `may' implies the capacity of not having to so make those arrangements. So there really is no way that you can enforce this, is there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, that is a good question from Senator Bolkus. For your assistance, I would refer you to page 2 of sheet 635 revised, amendment No. 4, which I will speak to once this debate is over. Proposed subsection (5)—I think it is a plain English instruction—says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister must not nominate a person under this section unless the Minister is satisfied that the number of eligible Judges . . . is insufficient to issue warrants . . .
That is pretty explicit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is not a judge an eligible judge only if an arrangement has been made by the Commonwealth with the state? If such an arrangement has not been made then such judge, from whatever state jurisdiction they may come from, does not qualify to be an eligible judge. The Attorney, not having to make any arrangements, and having not made any arrangements, under clause 12AA is in a position where he can quite clearly state that there are no eligible judges available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, that is a good response. At present, under the law, the Attorney‐General can exercise his discretion over which federal judges he approaches. It is not mandatory for him to approach every federal judge. Plainly, to achieve the intent of the legislation he has to approach some federal judges, but it is a fact that not all federal judges are authorised to issue warrants, and I think the minister would be able to confirm that. By nodding, he is confirming it.

SPEECH.PARA: Through my amendments, I have merely continued the practice of discretion. If these amendments were successful, the Attorney-General would have no doubt that the parliament intended him to approach judges of the states. What is more, further on in other amendments we have required that a reporting process be put into place so that we as the parliament can monitor the consequences of these amendments. So I accept some of your qualifications, but it is the existing system that we are pursuing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murray, I want to come back to that because it is a point. As I said, we do not support your proposal to extend it to the states. But, on this particular point, if you look at amendment 1, proposed section 4A, together with proposed section 12AA in amendment 6, it is quite clear that, no matter what you want to do, your amendments say that it is very much within the discretion of the government as to whether any arrangement is made with any particular state.

SPEECH.PARA: You may want the Attorney to set up agreements, but your amendments only provide for a discretion from the Common wealth government to so make those agreements. If they do not make any, then there are no eligible judges to satisfy the rest of your amendments and, as a consequence, we then move on to the AAT members as proposed by the government. I understand what you want to do, but my point is that you are not in fact ensuring that it happens. I can understand why you are not—that is, because it is probably impossible to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, Senator Bolkus, we did take advice and attempted to follow current procedure. Of course, if it was a condition of your support that you wished to change the encouragement to a command and go from `may' to `must', I would certainly consider such an amendment favourably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, it is not our policy objective to broaden the net so far. What I have been trying to do in the last few minutes is to explain to the committee that, even if you want to do what Senator Murray is setting out to do, it is hard to do so. One reason why you have the word `may' instead of `must' is: how can you force agreements between state and territory governments? That is something that I think has bedevilled federal‐state activities in a whole range of areas. If you were to force it here, then I think a whole raft of other problems arise, such as resourcing, funding, jurisdictions and so on. So I think we are dealing with a proposal which has some real structural problems as well as policy problems.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 1, item 19, page 7 (after line 26), at the end of section 6DA, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) Despite subsections (1) and (2), the Minister must not nominate a person under this section unless the Minister is satisfied that the number of eligible Judges, excluding persons who are Judges within the meaning of paragraph (d) of the definition of Judge , is insufficient to issue warrants under Part VI.

(6) If the Minister has nominated a person under this section and subsequently becomes satisfied that the number of eli gible Judges is sufficient to issue warrants under Part VI, the Minister, by writing, must withdraw the nomination of a person appointed under this section and the person's nomination ceases to have effect.

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Schedule 2, item 2, page 15 (after line 4), at the end of section 12DA, add:

PARA.TAB: (5) Despite subsections (1) and (2), the Minister must not nominate a person under this section unless the Minister is satisfied that the number of eligible Judges, excluding persons who are Judges within the meaning of paragraph (d) of the definition of Judge , is insufficient to issue warrants under section 12G.

(6) If the Minister has nominated a person under this section and subsequently becomes satisfied that the number of eligible Judges is sufficient to issue warrants under section 12G, the Minister, by writing, must withdraw the nomination of a person appointed under this section and the person's nomination ceases to have effect.

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Schedule 3, item 2, page 16 (after line 31), at the end of section 219AB, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) Despite subsections (1) and (2), the Minister must not nominate a person under this section unless the Minister is satisfied that the number of eligible Judges is insufficient to issue warrants under section 219B.

(5) If the Minister has nominated a person under this section and subsequently becomes satisfied that the number of eligible Judges is sufficient to issue warrants under section 219B, the Minister, by writing, must withdraw the nomination of a person appointed under this section and the person's nomination ceases to have effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect and intent of these amendments is indeed to establish a hierarchy of choice from federal judges to the AAT. It is clearly the view of the Labor Party that the workload objections of federal judges would be overcome if they were given sufficient resources to carry out the functions that they have. It is not within the ambit or possibility of this bill to deal with that. If the government did decide to give the federal judges greater resources, we would then, presumably, on the Labor Party's hypothesis, find judges withdrawing their objection to carrying out these warrants.

BREAK.PARA: It is the intention of these amendments—and they still apply to the act—to force the minister to go through all the federal judges first, before he or she decides to access the AAT. As we said in our contribution to the second reading debate, we recognise that the AAT is the next best level after judges. We think the government has made the right choice in that regard, but we are also very determined that every single judge who is available to us must be explored. These amendments will constrain the Attorney‐General in using non‐judicial persons before he or she exhausts the pool of eligible judges. We hope that the Attorney will use as much of his persuasive powers as possible to persuade federal judges to continue with the same function that they are carrying out now.

TALK.START.PARA: —This particular proposal coming up at this time creates some problems, because it prejudges how the opposition amendments will go. If, in fact, the opposition amendments to delete the government's proposal to extend the available personnel to more than judges are passed, then there is no need for Democrat amendments Nos 4, 8 and 10. I seek the indulgence of the committee to defer those amendments at this stage, and to revisit them after the opposition amendments have been handled.

—I think that we should hear from the government as to how it sees these matters. How the government sees these matters will no doubt be taken into consideration by honourable senators when voting on Senator Bolkus's proposals.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of what Senator Harradine says, perhaps the government will state now that it is opposed to these amendments. I take the point that Senator Bolkus made. Perhaps it could have dealt with the opposition amendments. As I understand it, the Democrat amendments that we are dealing with, which are 4, 8 and 10, are opposed by the government. No doubt the Democrats are trying to achieve something which is laudable but I just cannot see that this is a terribly workable way of understanding this task. It would have, I think, practical problems in relation to legal challenges, in relation to the validity of warrants issued by the various members nominated.
—I ask that at this stage the committee defer consideration of these amendments till after the opposition amendments.

—It is sticking out a mile what is going to happen. The Democrats have said they are going to vote against your proposal, so they will go down. Then we are going to get back to where we are now. I guess the government might have to at that particular stage vote for the proposal of the Democrats. I would like to see them vote for the proposal of the Democrats, if that is their intention, on the basis of their merits rather than on the basis that if we do not vote for them they may go down. I assume that if the Labor Party's amendments are negatived by the government and the Democrats, the Labor Party is going to support the Democrats' proposal which is currently before us. I certainly would like to hear an argument about that. But if it is the wish of the committee to defer this then so be it.

—There are probably two knowns in this debate and two unknowns. If our amendments do go down then we will support the Democrats' amendments. We do not know explicitly whether the Democrats will in fact oppose the opposition amendments. Nor do we know whether the Independent, Senator Harradine, will support the opposition amendments. If we can get some indication at this stage as to what their position is on our amendments then maybe we can quickly plough through this.

—I think it is appropriate to indicate formally, as we have indicated informally, that we are going to oppose your amendments, Senator Bolkus, although I would have preferred to have listened to your exposition of them. At this stage it certainly seems likely that we will oppose them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I might take that as an invitation from Senator Murray to just talk briefly about our amendments and arrange this committee stage into a cognate debate on the Democrat and opposition amendments. As I said in my speech on the second reading and as I said earlier today, we do not accept the government's contention that there is anything like a crisis in this area. There were 740 warrants issued in the last reported financial year. Though there have been some judges who have declined to issue warrants, it is obvious that the wide body of judges are performing this function entrusted to them by the parliament in a way they should do in accordance with the law.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not just our concern. As I said yesterday, the President of the New South Wales Law Society, Patrick Fair, said on 22 July:

Because of the necessity of ensuring that appropriate safeguards of privacy are maintained, along with the integrity of innocent conversations transmitted by telephone, the Law Society has long expressed the view that any warrant to intercept these communications should only be granted by a judicial officer. Accordingly, the Criminal Law Committee does not support the devolution of the power to issue telephone interception warrants to members of the AAT.

There is concern, there has been concern and there should be concern that governments and parliaments do balance the requirements of surveillance and law enforcement with the protection of the innocent. I think over the last 14 years or so since this legislation has been in place we have had a system in place which, it has to be said, the law enforcement agencies have been able to work within and work well within. I think 740 warrants a year is a fair indication that the system is working to the satisfaction of law enforcement interests. Without knowing the actual number of warrants rejected, I think it is fair to say that some innocent people have also been protected during the course of the operation of this legislation.

The Attorney argues workload problems. But let us acknowledge that this government has slashed back funding for the courts. The Chief Justice of the High Court has been very explicit about his concerns. Other courts—family courts and federal courts—have also had the same pressures applied on them. Although you could argue that in actual terms the resources have been static, in real terms they have fallen behind. In a real sense federal courts have had to pick up more and more jurisdictions. The Federal Court itself, for instance, has over recent months had to assume responsibility for, amongst other things, industrial relations, human rights issues and a growing interest and concern in immigration related matters.

Whereas the volume of work in that particular court has increased, its real resources have not increased. In fact, they have remained static in actual terms. So the courts do have more responsibilities. What this government should be doing in the interests of administration of justice is ensuring that the slash and burn policy when it comes to justice is not continued. If the government had adequately resourced the courts, and were it to do so in the next financial year, then you would not have this sort of pressure. But I suppose 740 warrants do not amount to more than a handful per judge per year.

The second concern that was raised by the Attorney was a constitutional one. It was raised again here today. I have to say that, in his public statements, both inside and outside the parliament, the Attorney has been quite misleading on the constitutional point. He talks about the constitutional problems raised by the Grollo case, but the Grollo case was explicit. In the Grollo case, which was a couple of years ago, the High Court held six to one that the exercise of the power to issue telecom intercept warrants by a judge, provided certain basic conditions of fairness and so on were met, was not inconsistent with the exercise of judicial power.

That was reinforced by the High Court last year in the Wilson case. In that particular case, all the judges noted that the issuing of telecom intercept warrants was not an issue before the court in that particular case, but the court specifically accepted the authority on the subject—namely, Grollo's case.

Constitutionally, it is clear from recent High Court decisions that there is not the problem that the Attorney-General pretends there to be or that the Attorney-General's Department pretends there to be. In fact, I should say some parts of the Attorney-General's Department, because, as I mentioned yesterday, Chief General Counsel Mr Burmester only recently, in respect of the Crimes Amendment (Control Operations) Bill 1996, gave an opinion. I will read out what he had to say about Grollo. He said:

. . . the majority was prepared to uphold the particular exercise of power in question as it was the judges "deciding independently of the applicant agency whether an interception warrant should issue that separates the eligible judge from the executive function of law enforcement.
He continued:
It is the recognition of that independent role that preserves public confidence in the judiciary as an institution."

The Chief General Counsel said that the High Court was prepared to uphold this particular exercise of power. So, on that particular ground, though the Attorney-General tries to blow it up into a concern, the law is quite clear—six to one.

The third argument the Attorney puts up to support his proposal is that it is, in some way, inappropriate for judges to issue warrants and then to be subject to judicial review by judges within their own court. That is and has been part and parcel of our judicial system. Judges are always susceptible to review by other judges of the same bench on a full bench. That happens quite consistently. Our argument is that the Attorney-General really is clutching at straws when he tosses up this third argument to support his agenda.

In essence, and I must put this on the record, we have here a recycled claim from the judiciary. I say `recycled' because it was one that was put up to us when we were in government. I think it has been put up annually for the last four or five years by the judges. The previous government, though it was suggested to us, did not feel there was a need for it. The figures that the minister has already spelt out today support the fact that we were right in our contention that there was not a need for it: 740 warrants issued by judicial officers of the federal jurisdiction over the last reportable financial year.

BREAK.PARA: For those reasons, we oppose this. We oppose this for those broader concerns that led to the framing of this legislation in the way it was framed some 14 years ago: a concern to not hinder but to assist law enforcement agencies and also to protect the public from intrusiveness. We felt the protection was best maintained if you had a relatively high ranking judicial officer to scrutinise the issuing of the warrant. No reason has been proffered in this recent debate to suggest that we should deviate from that balance that has served the public and the parliament well over the last 14 years. It is for those reasons that we oppose the government's initiatives in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the Democrat amendments be agreed to.
—I seek the indulgence of Senator Harradine to allow the opposition amendments to be put first.
—You may have a very good case.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the committee that further consideration of Democrat amendments Nos 4, 8 and 10 be postponed? There being no objection, that course will be followed.

INTERJECT.PARA: The question now is that items 6, 19, 20, 24, 25, 27 to 39 and 47 to 50 of schedule 1 and items 1 to 8 of schedule 2 and items 11 to 13 of schedule 3 stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will now return to consideration of Democrat amendments Nos 4, 8 and 10, which were postponed earlier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Because we lost the earlier amendments Nos 1 to 3, 6 and 9, with the leave of the committee I wish to further amend amendments Nos 4 and 8 by removing a line which is no longer applicable.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I amend my amendments as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment no. 1, subsection (5), omit ", excluding persons who are Judges within the meaning of paragraph (d) of the definition of Judge ,"
Amendment no. 2, subsection (5), omit ", excluding persons who are Judges within the meaning of paragraph (d) of the definition of Judge ,"

TALK.START.PARA: —May I have some clarification? As I understand it, Senator Murray proposes that you try to get judges, but if you cannot get judges you get people from the AAT. If that is so—and I want to put this on record—that seems to me a demeaning of people on the AAT. You have to make up your mind to have people from the AAT or not. It seems a bit harsh to enlist people from the AAT and then, when you get sufficient judges, to put them off the list. That seems to infer a lesser ability on the part of the AAT people and to use them according to convenience, which is not a very good way to go about this process.

—If I may respond through the chair, Senator Cooney, you are both right and wrong. The government, the opposition, and other parties within the Senate have clearly indicated a preference for judges. Undoubtedly, in the hierarchy of choice we as a Senate prefer judges ahead of other persons with legal training to issue warrants. That has been unequivocally stated in this chamber. But you are also wrong in this sense: 16 members, the President and the presidential members of the AAT, are also judges; therefore they feature in the hierarchy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I have not made my point as well as I might. As I understand it, your amendment No. 4 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) If the Minister has nominated a person under this section and subsequently becomes satisfied that the number of eligible Judges is sufficient to issue warrants under Part VI, the Minister, by writing, must withdraw the nomination of a person appointed under this section and the person's nomination ceases to have effect.

The whole thrust is that, if we do not have enough judges, then you appoint people from the AAT. Presumably they are going to do the job well and properly. If they do not do the job well and properly, we should not appoint them in any event. But if they are well and proper people to perform a job, how can you suddenly take it away?

BREAK.PARA: If I may, I will use the illustration of a surgeon, since Senator Herron is here. We say to a member of the public, `We are going to have Senator Herron operate upon you, as the best that there is, but if he is not around we will have Senator Abetz operate.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—If Senator Abetz is not a good surgeon, we should not nominate him in the first place. But if we do nominate him as a good surgeon, how can we then say he is not a good surgeon by taking away his brief in an obligatory way. The other problem that I have about this is that some members of the AAT at least are appointed on a temporary basis. I think it is a bad scheme to have people issuing warrants who are appointed on a temporary basis. They are the two issues I would like you to attend to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Through you, Madam Chair: Senator Cooney, I have never thought of you as a frightening person. In fact, I have always thought of you as a very gentlemanly person. But I must say you frightened the life out of me with the analogy of Senator Abetz chopping us all up! It really is a bit of a worry.

SPEECH.PARA: But to return to the thrust of your remarks, civil libertarians, the community, and everyone who has spoken in this house have all said that their preference is for judges, and that if the Federal Court judges had not said that they are refusing to do this task, they would have remained our first choice. The fact is that we are not advised that that refusal is permanent, so we wish to have the opportunity to give substance to the wishes of the community that if those federal judges change their minds—and it is the opinion of Labor that if they got enough resources they may well do so—the community would prefer that that function goes back to judges, however well regarded and however well the AAT does its job.

Let me repeat what I said in the second reading debate. I, personally, and the Democrats, have the highest regard for the AAT. But in this matter we believe the community is right to prefer warrants to be issued by judges, and these amendments of ours make that obligatory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Democrats are really concerned about the balance between civil liberties and the concern in the community as to who would issue these warrants and enforcement, then they would have voted for the previous amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: You have opened the floodgates now. You have given the government permission to go broader than judges and now you are saying, `Although we have said you can do that, we would actually like you not to do it.' Come on, give it a break! you are actually living in the real world here. What you have done by supporting the previous vote that we had in this place was to allow exactly what you are now saying should not happen. How about some consistency?

We cannot go back to that vote—I know that—but you have let the public down in terms of your position on that previous vote. The arguments are all there, but you had some fear, formulated and fermented by the government, about traditional officers not doing the job. Now you are saying, `Well, they may have a rethink. They may wake up tomorrow morning and think it's not such a bad thing to do after all. We will do it.' You have been told consistently that this has been on the ambit claim agenda for four or five years; and, despite it being on the ambit claim agenda, some 740 warrants or more have been issued over the last full financial year.

The judges have been explicit: some of them do not want to do it. That is what has led to the government putting this up. Now you are saying, `Well, okay. After four years of not wanting to do it, they might wake up tomorrow. Just in case they do wake up tomorrow, we will have subclauses (6), (6) again, (5) and (10).'

Really, we are seeing an enormous overdose of naivety on this particular issue, Senator Murray, I am sorry to say. If you have those concerns, then you could have done something about it some 15 or 20 minutes ago. I said at the start that the opposition would support your amendments 4, 8 and 10 as a matter of principle. I think Senator Cooney has a legitimate point with respect to the second part of each of those amendments. I say that at this stage, but would like to hear what the government says about them before we take a final vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Chair. A kind of perverted, twisted, dishonest morality has just been expressed. Thirty minutes ago—
—Senator Murray, you might like to withdraw a couple of those words.
—I withdraw them all because I am not sure which one would take offence.
—Both sides were offended.

—In that case, I will certainly withdraw them. The fact is that just 30 minutes ago I moved an amendment which would have opened up the application of this bill to allow all the judges in this country to be accessed prior to having to go to the AAT. I said at the time that I thought that both the government's and the Labor Party's rejection of that amendment was very poorly argued.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that there are 767 judges in this country. I understand that at the moment some 55 of those are accessed through this scheme. The Labor Party refused to even consider going down those avenues, and then they have the gall to complain that, because I would not let them split their bill, somehow I have been inconsistent.

When I say that something is a perverted system of logic, I mean that the twists and turns of it escape me. When I say that it is a dishonest representation of our views, I say it because, for blatantly political and aggressive reasons, the purpose, intent and argument behind our earlier amendments which were defeated by both the government and Labor were ignored.

I do not intend to be referred to as being inconsistent in this matter. We have clearly said, `Judges first'. We have clearly said that we wish to enlarge the pool of judges, and we have clearly said that we rank the AAT behind judges. There is nothing inconsistent about that in our arguments or in our voting. All we refused to do was to split the bill. We refused to buckle under Labor's particular tactical purpose. That is the way this place works. The fact is this bill has to be dealt with on its merits.

I am quite happy to accept the points made by Senator Cooney—that he feels that there is an inference of a slight against the AAT. It is unintended, but it is without doubt the intention of these amendments to establish a hierarchy of choice and to reflect the community's view that these very serious matters should remain in the hands of judges; and that if the Federal Court judges review their attitude they will then be the people who should be accessed and the AAT people should be knocked off the list. That is the consequence of it. I have put the arguments plainly. I think I should have a plain response. I do not expect, in the process of debate, to be then referred to as `joining the real world' or to hear remarks about consistency, because, quite frankly, I will reply with equal vehemence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not an attack on Senator Murray, but the legislation contains a problem that ought to be faced. What is required is that, if enough judges become available, the minister must withdraw the nomination of a person appointed from the AAT. That must mean that, if the Senate passes this legislation, the Senate believes that an innocent person about whom an application is made to have his or her telephone tapped is going to get less fairness in some way if that application is made to someone from the AAT than he or she will if the application is made to a judge.

SPEECH.PARA: I am saying, Senator Murray, that the legislation itself contains a distinction which will make it obvious to anybody who is subject to an application for a telephone tapping that he or she is going to get a fairer deal if the application is made to a judge than he or she will if the application is made to somebody from the AAT.

If that is not so, then why do we make the distinction? Why do we say that the nomination of a person—who, apparently, up until the time the nomination was withdrawn, was doing a proper job—must be taken away from such a person by the minister, if that person is not in some way, in reputation, in actual fact or in qualifications, a lesser person than a judge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point which has been made by Senator Cooney, but I do say that Senator Murray has been consistent and we have been trying to be consistent on this matter. Senator Murray did indicate—and it has been said previously, I think, by other people within this chamber—that this particular function should be a judicial function. That has been the desire all round. Even the government indicated, by inference as I understand it, that it would be preferable if there were sufficient judges to perform these functions.
—In the second reading speech.

—As Senator Murray said, that statement was made by the government in the second reading speech. Senator Murray tried to extend the pool to cover judges of the state jurisdiction, but that move failed. I then voted with the opposition in an effort, I suppose, in the long term, to retain this function for the judiciary. I can understand the points that are being made by Senator Cooney, but I do not quite see that that necessarily flows. One thing that I would like to raise with the committee—and perhaps the minister may respond as to how he sees it—concerns amendment 8, schedule 2, where the additional words say:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite subsections (1) and (2), the Minister must not nominate a person under this section unless the Minister is satisfied that the number of eligible Judges . . . is insufficient to issue warrants under section 12G.

I would like a bit of explanation from members of the committee as to how they see the minister would satisfy himself that the number of eligible judges is insufficient. I ask the minister and Senator Murray: in the event of a person being charged on the basis of information obtained as a result of the interception warrant, would it be open to that person, as an initial point I suppose, to challenge the basis of the charge on the grounds that the minister should prove that he was satisfied that the number of eligible judges was insuffi cient and that he had nominated a member of the AAT?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —What the government says about this proposed amendment is precisely the query that Senator Harradine has raised, that is, that the proposed amendment not only requires the Attorney‐General to be satisfied at the time of nominating the person for the AAT that there are insufficient judges, but also to continually satisfy himself that the number of eligible judges is inadequate in order to justify the continuation of the AAT nominations. Not only is that an onerous task but, more importantly, it is an aspect which is subject to administrative law considerations. There is provision under the act that evidence which is obtained can be inadmissible if obtained under certain situations. Section 77(1) of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a communication passing over a telecommunications system has been intercepted, whether or not in contravention of subsection 7(1), then:
(a) . . . neither information, nor a record, obtained by the interception is admissible in evidence in a proceedings except in so far as—

other sections are concerned. What that means in general terms is that intercepted material and designated warrant information can be inadmissible except as provided. The government has the view that under that section there could be a problem if someone challenged the Attorney's nomination and said, `At the time you did not satisfy yourself adequately as to the number of judges available.' As I said earlier, this problem could be subject to legal challenge. There is also the practicality of it, that the Attorney‐General has to continually satisfy himself or herself that the number of judges is not sufficient. So you have two quite demanding obstacles in your path there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bolkus for conceding the floor. We would be content, if it was the will of the Senate, to pass these amendments to include a clause—which hopefully I can have drafted relatively quick ly—which would say that, if an AAT member was an eligible person at the time, the fact that there was also an eligible judge available at the time would not be grounds for appeal. They are both of equal status and have equal rights in this matter. That therefore would result in a situation where, if both were appropriately accredited by the Attorney-General, both could operate with equality under the law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Harradine for raising the point of concern that I also had with these amendments. We have obviously discussed the concern that Senator Cooney had, but I have had some concern as to what these amendments would mean in a practical sense—that is, whether a warrant could be challenged and whether the amendments of the Democrats would put the operation of any investigation in jeopardy because of the imposition of what can be said to be a worthy aspiration but is something which, expressed in legislation, could really create a technical problem which could frustrate investigations. I think Senator Ellison has reinforced the concerns that I had about this particular amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, in principle, we understand and accept what Senator Murray is trying to do, but I think there are sufficient problems with this in a technical and practical sense for the opposition not to support it. That probably means that Senator Murray does not have to go off and prepare a further amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have the amendment available if it is the will of the senators for me to put it before them.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendments (4) and (8), as amended, and (10) be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, page 13 (after line 10), at the end of the Schedule, add:
Insert:

TAB.TAB: (ab) information about the availability of judges to issue warrants under Part VI and the extent to which nominated AAT members have been used for that purpose, but not including information that would identify a particular judge or AAT member; and
(ac) an analysis of any discrepancies in practices involving the issuing of warrants between Judges, former Judges and nominated AAT members; and

SPEECH.PARA: Insert:

PARA.TAB: (1) The annual report for 1999‐2000 must include a review of the amendments made by the Telecommunications (Interception) and Listening Device Amendment Act 1997 to this Act.

(2) For the purposes of the review, the Minister must arrange for a public notice, in plain English, to be published in at least one daily newspaper circulating in each State and Territory, calling for submissions from the public on the operation of amendments providing for the issuing of warrants by nominated AAT members, and including an address to which submissions may be sent.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment will add to the reporting functions under the main act so as to include, on an ongoing basis, the issue of the availability of judges. I draw to the Senate's attention that we have not seen—but perhaps other parties have—any correspondence from the federal judges stating that they will not carry out these functions. We rely therefore on the word of the minister to spell out these things. Perhaps my adviser has seen that correspondence, but I have not seen it.

I am also of the belief that the judges' decision is not a permanent and irrevocable one. I understand once again the Labor Party's view that, if the judges were given sufficient resources, they would carry out their functions as they did formerly. I do not know whether that is true or not. Only the judges can tell us that.

This amendment adds to the public confidence arguments. We think it adds to accountability and transparency issues and it includes the provision of a public report enhancing those elements. Simply put, it indicates annually the state of play on the availability of judges, which is a matter of great concern to the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just have a wonder about that Democrat amendment. I would hate the position to be reached where there was a perception, if not a reality, that the executive was in some way—

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted; progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This document deals with the operation of the Department of Administrative Services and the expenditure made on behalf of certain members of parliament. Since we were last here, our own situation in this regard has changed to some extent. Some of the operations that were formerly carried out by the financial management section of the Senate have now gone to the Department of Administrative Services.

I just want to say that the people who work there served us well, and I would take this opportunity to mention them and thank them for the service they have given us over the years. That section is still under the quite outstanding control of Graeme Nankervis. He is assisted by Graeme Holt, Tony Styles, Chris Leeman and Judith Kelly. I mention Tony Styles, for example. He often saved things that needed to be saved, and he has to be thanked for that.

I would like to mention them at this time, and I would have liked perhaps to have done it previously. This does give me an opportunity to thank them for the service that they have given over the years and to wish them all the best for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity to say a few words in respect of the significant changes that have been made to travel arrangements in this parliament. There is an old aphorism about it being difficult to teach old dogs new tricks. Whilst not impos sible, it is difficult. I also want to say, as one of the more senior members of this chamber now, to my astonishment—I have just been checking with my colleague Senator West—what a passing parade there has been through this place. I have lost track of just how many senators have been through here in the last 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The service that I have been provided with by Senate staff has been exemplary for the whole of that period of time. It has been an absolutely glitch free service and, more particularly, a service that has been tailored to the needs of the members of the parliament by people who know what those needs are and know how to serve them properly. I might have to eat my words on this, but I got another letter just this morning from the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull) apologising for some of the early glitches in the new arrangements with the new travel agent. I noted to my interest that the amount of money which will allegedly be saved by these procedures has been magically reduced by half a million dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Did you notice that too, Senator? Talk about rubbery figures. I got an earlier letter from the Minister for Administrative Services that talked about how conscious we should all be that $1½ million would be saved by these magical arrangements. I see that has now magically gone down to $1 million in the latest piece of correspondence I got from him this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: I am prepared to say that I do not believe that the taxpayers will save $1 million at all with these new arrangements. In fact, if any money is saved with these new arrangements—this is a matter which, I am quite happy to tell the government, I and perhaps some others will be pursuing in some detail in Senate estimates—I do not believe for one minute that it could not have been saved just as easily by introducing whatever reforms are necessary into the existing arrangements here in parliament.
I have now been furnished with an entire fleet of plastic cards, PIN numbers to go with them and a string of numbers that it would take a supercomputer to get across.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you still don't know where you're going.

—I have no idea. I am just a typical Australian—I hate change. It is an arrangement which may work. The only advantage, which is continually pushed down our necks, is that we are going to save $1 million of taxpayers' money. I do not believe it. As I say, at the end of the day I will be interested to pursue it. If any money is saved there will not be a dollar, in my view, saved by virtue of this arrangement now being put into the hands of a private company—Jetset or whoever. Let me say I do not utter a word of criticism of that organisation. I am sure it does a wonderful job. I have no idea how good a job it is going to do for us. But I think this alleged saving is an absolute mirage.

BREAK.PARA: If I sound a little irritated, it is because I am. It is because I do not like having to change an arrangement which has worked for me, as I say, without a glitch for 10 years, administered by hardworking and dedicated Senate staff. I am irritated by that. The test will be well and truly on this government as to whether the only reason for making these utterly unnecessary changes, in my view, to the travel arrangements here is to save a dollar. I do not believe, as I said before, that the changed arrangements will save any money. I think, frankly, it is a whole lot of fuss about absolutely nothing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The document that we have for discussion at this time is Department of Administrative Services—Ministers, Parliamentary Secretaries and Office Holders—Travel Expenditure 1996/97 . I want to say a couple of things about it.

SPEECH.PARA: This document simply has amounts of money and some indication of where people have been. It is not a document prepared by an independent auditor. I want to know if the travel allowances and expenses of ministers, parliamentary secretaries and office holders in this government and in the previous government have been the subject of the same sort of independent audit that the travel expenses and travel allowances of senators have had over the last however long. If not, why not? We have all had to go through it. None of us worried about that. Yes, they found something wrong with my travel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't believe that.

—Yes, I happened to apply for a day's travelling allowance for Canberra when I was not in Canberra. It was in late April of 1996. The Senate did this and it was very thorough. The Senate found that there was an airline ticket from Melbourne to Canberra on the Wednesday of that week—I cannot recall what date it was—but there was no indication of my going anywhere on that day, though I had come up here on the Monday. Of course, that was the week of the tragedy at Port Arthur, so travel arrangements were not uppermost in our minds at that time. They wondered how I had got there. Did I walk on water or what? No, the situation simply was that we went down in a VIP aircraft—
—Did they consider that as an active option?

—We went down on a VIP aircraft and came back to Melbourne on one that same day. Then I had to stay overnight there. So they owe me money! I hope they make the adjustment because I stayed in Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give credit where credit is due. What I do object to is our travelling allowances being now dealt with not by the Senate but by a minister's department. I believe, quite frankly, that is quite contrary to the separation of powers of the executive and the legislature. I do take exception to the fact that this transfer was done by the Senate when almost no‐one in the Senate knew what was in the recommendations from the staffing committee.

As I pointed out to the President of the Senate in a letter dated 5 September, which I will seek leave to have incorporated, this transfer was done on 4 September. The report of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing was tabled and it was ordered to be printed. Seconds later, there was this motion:

That the Senate adopt the committee's recommendation to note the Government's decision and agree to the transfer of responsibility for the administration of senators' travelling allowances from the Department of the Senate to the Department of Administrative Services.

That was put forward when no‐one, other than the members of the committee, had even read the recommendation. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my letter to the President of the Senate dated 5 September. I will return to this subject very shortly.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—
5 September 1997
Senator the Honourable M Reid
President of the Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Madam President
RE: 27TH REPORT OF THE STANDING COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING, ENTITLED TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE ADMINISTRATION OF SENATOR'S TRAVELLING ALLOWANCES
I wish to register my strong objection to what I believe was the entirely inappropriate manner in which the above report was dealt with in the Senate on 4th September.

Madam President you presented the Report to the Senate. The Report was then ordered to be printed. Seconds later at 9.44am Senator Robert Ray moved, "That the Senate adopt the committee's recommendation to note the Government's decision and agree to the transfer of responsibility for the administration of senators' travelling allowances from the Department of the Senate to the Department of Administrative Services."

The normal procedure would have been to move that the Senate take note of the Report and for the debate to be adjourned after Senators had spoken. I suggest that it was entirely inappropriate for Senators to be asked to adopt a report when it had not even been distributed to Senators, other than to members of the Committee. I presume that like me, most Senators would not have had the chance to see this Report much less to study it.

Actually when I realised the debate was on and the general subject matter thereof, I hurried down to the Senate chamber. On entering I was told it was all over—in just ten minutes. Executive Government . . . 10—The Senate and due process . . . NIL.

I am sure that had you been aware of these facts, you would have made sure that the matter was not finalised until Senators had the opportunity of receiving and studying the Report. This is particularly the case since the Report raises a number of questions, not least those relating to the separation of powers and the possibility of political surveillance by the Executive Government of Senators engaged in Parliamentary duties on behalf of their electors.

I would be most obliged if you would raise this matter with all other Senators by letter. I hope that the Senate will agree to have the matter recommitted and debated in accordance with usual Senate practice when all honourable Senators have seen and studied the Report.
Yours sincerely
SENATOR BRIAN HARRADINE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Department of Administrative Services report because I share the same sensitivity to an issue raised by Senator Harradine; that is, the independent audit status of the report that is before us this evening. I have no problems with my travel allowance and my claims being laid open for public scrutiny. I think that in the short time I have been in this chamber I have nothing to fear, nor will I have anything to fear in the future because I think they will stand the test of time.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the system, it seems to me odd that my records are subject to an independent audit, yet the report that has been tabled here is not subject to any independent scrutiny whatsoever. I think that really is a weakness in the system. If one looks at the substantial claims that are outlined in this report before us—no-one is doubting the claims that are before us in this report—it lacks the authenticity of that independent evaluation and assessment so that there is no shadow of doubt that the document is free from any material error.

Having said that, though, I think it is good that the Australian people are made aware of what their politicians spend in exercising their duty and their right and their privilege in representing the Australian people. I think the Australian people do not necessarily have all that good an understanding of what politicians do in their day-to-day life. Of course, if they listen solely to the view that is presented to them by the media, in many instances they will have a completely distorted view. They will put completely out of perspective the amounts that politicians expend in dutifully pursuing what they are entrusted with by the Australian people.

So this report really does not serve as fodder for the media to carve up any politician of any persuasion—I think, in particular, it goes to the report that refers directly to me and other people in both this house and the other chamber—it serves the purpose of showing to the Australian public that we do have a great deal of responsibility, that we exercise it in a fair and equitable manner and that, like other people in the community, we are accountable for what we do. That accountability presents itself here.

As I said, the only factor that I would raise in respect of this report is that there seems to be no independent audit done on the report. One would hope that this particular aspect is picked up and addressed at a suitable time in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to comment on the DAS report and on the new travel arrangements. Like Senator Cooney and Senator Bob Collins before me, I found the utmost cooperation from the staff dealing with our travel arrangements in the past. Nothing but every level of assistance has been forwarded to us.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the arguments for the need for new changes in terms of rationalising processes, cutting costs and introducing an element of accountability, but I am concerned to hear the points that Senator Hogg has just raised about whether that accountability extends right through all of our representatives. For instance, I note from tonight's news the concern with respect to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, and the question of whether he should be held accountable in relation to changes in his travel claims.

The very concerning report on tonight's news was that Minister Sharp had made a significant adjustment to his travel allowance claims, but no reason had been given to the department as to why those changes needed to be made. I think we should all be accountable and Senator Hogg's comment is quite pertinent in that sense. I would like to know why I and any other senator or member has needed to change, especially in such a significant way, their claims in relation to their travel allowances.

There is another issue I would like to highlight following Senator Bob Collins's comments about to what extent these changes relate to somewhat of a mirage or a fuss. I find those consequences affect me personally. They also relate to Senator Harradine's earlier questions in relation to the minister's department being responsible and the autonomy. Senator Harradine raises a very important point—this information will be within the minister's department.

I had an experience last year where certain information was leaked to the media about my proposed travel arrangements. It was very concerning. Whether I was planning to travel with my family or not was used as a political football in the workplace relations inquiry. How that information might be anybody's business is beyond me, but again it was used as a political football. If this information exists within ministers' departments, then how much more prone are we likely to be to those sorts of things occurring again in the future?

I would also like to highlight the point that, while all this fuss exists on accountability on these issues, where does it leave people such as me who are in situations new to representatives of this parliament, who have young children and need to juggle their family life in relation to their travel arrangements? We cannot raise those issues in this climate. The criticism would be appalling, because of all this emphasis and fuss that is being raised by this government on these issues. It is affecting women representatives with young families. We need to adjust the system to deal with our needs as they differ from those of other representatives. The system was designed to deal with a different nature of representative in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, saw tonight's Channel 9 news story. I think the thing that needs to be said in relation to the DAS travel arrangements document tabled today in the Senate, which I understand was tabled in the House of Representatives earlier, is that we can see what it says; we cannot see what it does not say. It is not an audited document in the sense that in an ordinary audit process an independent body would be vetting a document. What we have here is a document which expresses the view of the minister's department.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the point that Senator Harradine made about the importance of there being a separation or at least a vindication of the minister's department position by independent bodies. For example, this document purports to set out certain travel costs of ministers. But if you look under the `car hire' column, you will see there is a hash symbol. If you look down at what that symbol means, you will see it means that the amount of money set out in that column only covers Comcar costs and excludes cabcharge and hire car costs.

In some cities Comcar does not operate. So depending where the travel originated, it is possible that that would falsely represent the usage of the minister's entitlement in the sense that cabcharge or hire car—which are not represented there—might be a significant part of the costs incurred to enable the minister or parliamentary secretary to travel in accordance with entitlement.

I say that because, if you look at the document, there are a great many annotations which set out changes or important factors which relate to the claims of individuals, for example, when they became a parliamentary secretary or a minister. I pointed out the annotation in relation to car hire charges and there is also an annotation that some figures include claims for spouse entitlement. Yet there is no annotation which relates to the alteration of the claim by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) as outlined in the report on Channel 9 tonight.

Taking the words of Mr Laurie Oakes, who was the journalist presenting the report tonight, that alteration was made in `secret'. That is borne out by looking at this document and seeing that there is no annotation in this document which reflects the changes that had been made to the original claim and the repayment made in `secret'—and that was the term used by the journalist in that story. If the journalist is correct, then this is a very serious matter, and I am sure my comments will merely skim the surface of the comments that will be made in relation to this matter.

I hark back to Senator Harradine's comments that, if we are to receive these reports, then they should not be sanitised by the minister's department, certainly not simply to protect any particular minister or parliamentary secretary. I understand—and senators can correct me if I am wrong—that no such alteration or concealment would have occurred in the figures which have been presented by the Senate over the last few years and published. Those figures were available publicly and, if someone claimed to have repaid something that they had originally claimed, that would be shown in the reports presented to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a point of explanation with respect to the previous comments. I want to make it clear that I made no inference on any honourable senator or any honourable member in the other place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to raise an issue that came about as a result of the tabling of the report on the operation of the War Crimes Act 1945 to June 1997. This report highlights that a special investigation unit was established to investigate serious war crimes which arose out of revelations contained in a review of the material relating to the entry of suspected war criminals into Australia. That unit was established within the Attorney‐General's Department in 1987, with the stated objective being to collect probative evidence of the commission of war crimes, as defined by the act.

I raise this issue in the context of the recent revelations regarding Mr Konrad Kalejs, who was extradited from Canada. He took out Australian citizenship in the 1950s. It was alleged that this particular individual had undertaken activities in relation to a paramilitary death squad which was responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of Jewish people in the Baltic States during the Second World War.

I am sure the Senate would remember that these issues caused considerable concern within the Australian community, particularly given the remarks of the Premier of Victoria, Mr Jeffrey Kennett, who indicated that in his view there was no way that these actions should be further investigated and that prosecutions should not be launched against this citizen. These are very serious matters which go to some fundamental issues about Australia's attitudes towards human rights.

I acknowledge that in these particular cases the issues are particularly difficult. I also acknowledge that the United States government felt it necessary to reject Mr Kalejs's application for permanent residency and that he was sent back to Australia because of the allegations concerning his activities in the Second World War. I also acknowledge that these are issues that the Canadian government has thought were sufficiently serious to warrant the deportation of this person back to Australia, especially given that these matters do go to such basic issues of human rights.

It concerns me that the Premier of Victoria feels it necessary to dismiss these questions in such a flippant and cavalier manner. While we have to acknowledge that the reasons taken by the Canadian government in relation to its deportation orders were based upon different legal standards—that is, the balance of probability—what is also apparent is that, to prosecute these matters, questions arise in terms of reasonable doubt. The Australian government ought be undertaking thorough investigations of the Canadians to ensure that there is no basis for prosecution.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I had occasion to peruse the booklet of the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title entitled Native title and reconciliation: an international brief . This booklet was being provided to members of parliament in European communities. The booklet accompanied a delegation of the National Indigenous Working Group on Native Title to Europe. The native title working group has also briefed foreign diplomatic missions in Australia as, for example, they did on 21 May.

SPEECH.PARA: All this in itself is not remarkable. Indeed, on the face of it, these activities ought be welcomed to assist the people of the world to understand our approach to issues of native title and indigenous welfare. It is a tribute to our democracy that this delegation is able to brief the international community and produce booklets such as this at taxpayers' expense.

So while there existed the potential for good to come out of all this, I am saddened to report that the opportunity for education was unfortunately discarded for the opportunity of propaganda. Right at the front of the booklet under the `contents' section appears this quote from the Chairman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, Pat Dodson:

(Aboriginal people) were poisoned—waterholes, soakages, where people sustained their life—they were places that were poisoned, and that is the imagery that Aborigines have in terms of the Wik 10 Points, that this is a final poisoning of the last waterhole.

Those activities did occur, and they are condemned and regretted. Such actions are unforgivable; they should never have been contemplated, let alone undertaken. But I ask: for what purpose are we told these things, and why is this imagery used? It seems to me to be as helpful and intellectually sound as recent references by the One Nation Party to cannibalism by Aborigines. Neither view is promoted by those genuinely committed to achieving reconciliation.

The evoking of these types of images pours fuel on the fire; it does nothing for reconciliation, which we are led to believe is Mr Pat Dodson's purpose in life. Rather than gaining sympathy or support, this type of language will inflame and alienate. And those, like me, who spend literally days searching for genuine solutions, are left feeling deflated and frustrated.

My experience is that Australia has such an excellent reputation overseas that the vast majority of the international community dismiss this type of offensive imagery. The imagery also alienates many non‐indigenous Australians because of its extremism. There are many aspects of the booklet which I could focus on, but time permits only a few exposes.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—It really is a sad reflection on the Labor Party, isn't it?
—Order!
—You obviously haven't caught up with the Aborigines who were poisoned by strychnine in the grounds of the John Flynn Church just a decade ago.
—Senator Bob Collins, I have called for order a number of times. I ask you to abide by the chair's call.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It really is sad that, when you are addressing a matter of this nature, people like Senator Collins and those on the other side cannot simply listen in silence to what is a very sincere and genuine approach to try to get the two extremes to desist from making their outrageous claims.

SPEECH.PARA: This booklet purports to discuss native title and reconciliation. In discussing native title and its development, there is only one mention of the land fund. This occurs on page 7, where we are told:

The government promised to establish a Land Fund and to implement a series of social justice measures (the Social Justice Package) to address the impact of dispossession, disempowerment and disadvantage of indigenous peoples. National consultations were conducted and reported, but the Social Justice package has not yet been implemented.

Our overseas friends reading such a commentary were led to believe that the land fund has not yet been established—and, on the basis of that quote, you cannot blame them. In fact, that is the only time that the land fund is referred to in the document. In fact, the land fund has been established and instalment payments have been made on time and in full.

The fund is bankrolled by the Australian taxpayer at a contribution of $1.289 billion. That is approximately 70c per Australian man, woman and child, or $164 for each taxpayer and $3,650 for each Aborigine. The fund will give the Aboriginal community in this country $45 million per annum to buy property until eternity.

To make no mention of the land fund and the size of it is at best an unprofessional oversight and at worst an attempt to deliberately mislead by way of omission. To fail to mention the $1.289 billion land fund in any discussion on native title, pastoral leases and extinguishment is to fail to understand the issues. Pastoral leases were deemed to extinguish native title before the High Court decision on Wik. Therefore, part of the indigenous land fund compensation for dispossession was for dispossession due to pastoral leases. Yet no‐one has suggested that we claw back any of the indigenous land fund although, logically, such an argument could be sustained.

The payment of the land fund in the context of 18 million Australians is a substantial contribution in monetary terms. But behind the monetary contribution and, indeed, more important than the money, was the act of the Australian people in extending their hands of goodwill. To ignore this significant goodwill gesture, and to fail to mention the size of it, is to mislead the international community. It is on the basis of this misinformation that some elements may be making judgments about Australia in the run‐up to the Olympic Games.

Having been provided with a booklet, a number of European parliamentarians asked me about native title issues. They were horrified and disappointed at the failure of the National Indigenous Working Group to make full disclosure of the land fund and the huge sum involved. The National Indigenous Working Group has done untold damage to themselves and our indigenous community by their misrepresentations.

Even worse than this omission is the gross and unforgivable misrepresentation of the 10‐point plan. On page 13 of the booklet we are quite blandly told about the government's proposal to upgrade pastoral leases to freehold. This is simply untrue and that assertion besmirches Australia's image overseas. When one is confronted with such gross and deliberate distortion, one is less likely to give the National Indigenous Working Group the benefit of the doubt as to the omission of the land fund.

I plead with the National Indigenous Working Group and our indigenous brothers and sisters not to engage in such activities as I have outlined. I am desperately concerned that these activities not only belittle the indigenous community overseas when the truth comes to light but, more importantly, they evaporate the substantial reservoir of goodwill that non‐indigenous Australians hold towards their indigenous brothers and sisters. If you overplead your cause, you lose credibility and are treated with cynicism and scepticism; your sincerity is questioned and, ultimately, you will be seen as opportunistic.

By all means, the National Indigenous Working Group ought to be forceful in their representations but, ultimately, truth will out and all the passion, representations and effort will be for naught if the representations are based on falsehoods or gross omissions. You see, human nature is to reject the gilding of the lily, because the gilding of the lily is usually a practice engaged in when one thinks the truth is not enough. So, to my indigenous friends, let me plead: keep it straight and you will regain the goodwill of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down, you hypocrite.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I found that a particularly offensive remark in this context and I would ask that Senator Conroy withdraw.
—Senator Conroy, would you withdraw?
—I withdraw.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development: Travel Allowance Minister for Administrative Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to address the issue of the travelling allowance claims of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp. It has been exposed today that Minister Sharp claimed since the election 144 days travel allowance and that he has repaid some 47 of those 144 days—and, in fact, now claims only 97.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk very briefly about the pattern of travel allowance claimed by Minister Sharp. I just want to put the lie to the spin doctoring that is going on feverishly at the moment from the government's spin doctors in the gallery. They are saying, `Oh, this is just the odd Thursday night after a week sitting in Canberra.' Let us be absolutely clear. There are a number of occasions when we are talking about several days on end. It is not just Canberra that we are talking about either. At least eight days were claimed at the higher rate in Sydney. He was not in Canberra; he was in Sydney. It is travel allowance at that higher rate that Mr Sharp has paid back.

This is going to be explored most forensically, I can assure you, by the opposition in the days and weeks ahead. But I do want to say this: it absolutely beggars belief that these are inadvertent mistakes. That claim completely lacks credibility. I will leave Mr Sharp to another day, starting tomorrow. Tonight I want to talk about the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Jull, because Mr Jull has been involved in the most blatant and underhand cover-up of Mr Sharp's travel claims.

Mr Sharp has been exposed not by his own actions at all; he has been exposed by the media. In fact, he has been exposed by Laurie Oakes, a journalist for Channel 9 and the Bulletin. The truth of the matter is that Mr Jull, the Minister for Administrative Services, said to the House of Representatives on 5 March when asked a question about parliamentarians' entitlements:
Let me just say that we are going to clean it up and we are not going to give any comfort to those who are found to have undertaken any impropriety in the use of their entitlements.

That is what Mr Jull said in the House of Representatives on 5 March. What has he done? He has allowed a cabinet minister, a colleague, a mate, to doctor his travel details. That is what Mr Jull has done. He has allowed a cabinet minister, a colleague, a mate, to doctor his travel details before they were tabled in the House of Representatives. Mr Jull has accepted a cheque from Mr Sharp—a cheque for no small amount, a cheque for $8,740—no questions asked. In fact, we are told that Mr Jull, the responsible minister, did not seek any explanation from his cabinet colleague.

This compares to the situation in relation to the tabling of travel allowance claims from former Labor ministers in circumstances where Labor ministers were morally but not legally obligated to repay some moneys to DAS—and I say very clearly in a very different league to Mr Sharp, a completely different league to Mr Sharp. But what happened when that occurred? The fact that they repaid those small moneys was highlighted in the documents that were tabled in the parliament. The fact that they were required to repay money was drawn attention to. It was a different standard because a number of then Liberal and National Party shadow ministers were in a similar situation. Of course that was not highlighted by Mr Jull. It was a different rule for former Liberal and National Party shadow ministers than it was for former Labor ministers.

But this is the same minister involved in this cover-up who on 15 June assured the parliament, and more importantly assured the Australian people, that he would do the right thing under a new system for parliamentarians' entitlements. Let me quote what he said. Let me draw attention to this extraordinary press release of 15 June, given the expose that has occurred today. The press release states:

The Minister for Administrative Services, David Jull, today announced proposals for a more transparent and streamlined system for the administration of Parliamentarians' entitlements, including full disclosure of politicians' travel expenditure.
Oh, really! It continues:

Mr Jull also announced the introduction of six‐monthly tabling in Parliament of expenditure details for all Senators and Members, including Ministers, on the costs of air and car transport and related travelling allowance payments.
Oh, really! Then Mr Jull went on to say:
This would enable expenditure against entitlements to be fully reconciled and available for public scrutiny.
