The Minister said the Government's changes would restore confidence in the entitlements system.

What has been exposed today is that Mr Jull deliberately covered up the fact that a ministerial colleague of his—a senior cabinet colleague of his—repaid a very substantial amount of money to the Department of Administrative Services, no questions asked.

It is, as I have said, a blatant cover‐up from Mr Jull. It will not only be Mr Sharp who has a lot of explaining to do about this issue. It will not only be Mr Sharp who has to explain why he repaid apparently wrongly claimed travel allowance of some 47 days. It will not only be Mr Sharp, because Mr Jull has a lot of explaining to do about the administration of his own portfolio. If it is shown that Mr Jull deliberately covered this up, then Mr Jull will have no alternative but to resign.

This is a serious offence from not only Mr Sharp but also Mr Jull, who has shown a complete abrogation of commitments he made in the parliament and commitments he made to the Australian people about accountability of parliamentarians' entitlements. Mr Jull has an awful lot of explaining to do. I can assure you that the Labor opposition will be chasing both Mr Jull and Mr Sharp down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to address an issue that is important but perhaps not quite as staggering as the information we have just had presented before the chamber. I rise to discuss the issue of ideas in the electronic age.
—It will be far more intelligent.

—I believe that the digital age faces a major dilemma, and one that I am sure Senator Herron will appreciate—that is, how do we recognise and value an idea? In the virtual world this is particularly important as digital property can be easily copied, transferred and sent all around the world with, and some times without, the knowledge of the originator. The dilemma therefore is how we protect that idea so that the idea's originator can benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: Our existing structures for the protection of ideas and innovation are the intellectual property laws in the form of trademarks, patents, copyright designs, confidentiality and a range of sharp business practices. These broadly labelled intellectual property laws have served us well and have developed to meet the needs of printing presses and, of course, the Industrial Revolution.

However, the electronic advances in computing challenge many of these particular laws. I note in particular the recent decision of Telstra v. the Australasian Performing Right Association. I think this case illustrates the problem perfectly. In that case, on‐hold music was found to infringe copyright. The consequences of this decision are significant, even though the decision has only noted the implications. The words of Justice Kirby in that case are worth referring to. He said:

. . . It has been argued that telecommunications carriers and perhaps even internet service providers could potentially become liable as a result of internet users' down loading works which are protected by copyright . . . the Parliament may need to consider these questions—and others arising—and to formulate a legislative response to them. They cannot be solved , but have not been overlooked, by me.

Digital technology has evolved into something significantly different from what these laws were designed to protect. We have seen the struggle of the Australian courts and of international bodies which have tried to fit computer programs under the existing copyright regimes. In each instance, the courts or tribunals have sought to protect the ideas behind the programs.

There is also the problem of which laws we should apply to a technology which crosses the traditional institutional boundaries. For example, an Australian user connected computer connected to the Internet can listen to an Internet radio station that is in America. The Copyright Act has a technology specific broadcasting right covering over the air wireless broadcasts while there are no copyright rights over sound recordings or broadcasts that occur over cables.

The Internet user relies on a telephone line provided by a telecommunications carrier to connect them to the Internet. The server they use may be in Australia and the content could be by an Australian artist. Which laws should cover this and how should we change our laws to best reflect our community interests and the interests of those with particular ideas?

Intellectual property in the digital forum is concerned with rights that attach to particular subject matter which, of course, is intangible. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights recognises this as a right to protection of a person's mental labours. Our current laws cover these rights in terms of property—an institution that is given the sanction of positive laws for a social purpose. The traditional concepts of poverty are a far cry from our current needs and are arguably the source of many of our present difficulties.

Intellectual property is a distinct class of incorporeal property, which is significantly different from the rights recognised in corporeal objects. It is not possible to possess or occupy an item of intellectual property in the same way one may possess or occupy a piece of land, a cow or whatever particular object you might refer to. Further, the concept of property fails to recognise that there is nothing inherently scarce or sacred in the subject matter. A copy of a particular subject matter does not affect the further copying, and one person's inventive idea does not limit the amount of an idea available to others.

We should recognise the rights which attach to the intangible products of intellectual labour. This is particularly important in the digital forum so that our thinking and the way we deal with this new technology are not constrained by the institutions of the past. We need to develop new laws and new ways of recognising intellectual effort.

Ideas, of course, are the basis for our ongoing technological advances, and they need to be recognised by our community. So I look forward to the government legislating in this area. Perhaps the new minister for the information economy might like to put forward some ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?
—Who is that? I think we know, but I am not quite sure if he does. Senator Alston seemed rather uncertain as to his portfolio responsibilities in that area today.

SPEECH.PARA: Might I suggest to the minister that some of the areas he could consider include not only how we use the information economy and information technology as a wealth creator or a generator of jobs but also an examination of some of the key issues related to the IT sector—that he look not only at how we resource that sector and resource the department, because clearly he was not particularly sure as to how he was going to resource his own needs in this particular area, but also at encryption, electronic commerce, defamation, intellectual property rights, privacy and, I guess, just general community concerns in relation to unfair practices of, say, large businesses when it comes to the IT sector.

Of course, no doubt colleagues on this side would suggest that outsourcing of the IT field should be among those areas that the new minister should consider. But I hope that he will pay attention not only to intellectual property rights and the difficulties in the electronic age but also, in particular, to the issue of privacy and the extension of the privacy laws to the private sector so that information technology is also protected.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Transport and Regional Development: Travel Allowance Minister for Administrative Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The jury is certainly out on Mr Sharp as to whether he should stay a minister or not. We are witnessing at the moment something which I always find fascinating—that is, a matter is leached from a department, a minister is embarrassed, then the minister starts running the lines out to journalists and others in defence. It is our job to forensically look at those lines of defence.

SPEECH.PARA: The first line run tonight, which I was a bit confused about, was the 100‐kilometre rule. What that has to do with overnight claims in Canberra, I do not know. The second line run out was, `I took them out of my diary and I made mistakes.' Give him credit: he is not blaming his staff. He does all his travel allowance forms himself and he happened to take 47 mistakes out of 144 nights claimed!

But, if you want to check the credibility of this, Mr Jull and Mr Sharp are in a position to do so. They should table his original travel allowance claims and his amended ones, and we should see the date on which he signed off the false claims to see whether it was only a week ago, two weeks ago or six months ago. I might have some understanding if Mr Sharp did not claim any travel allowance for six months, went through his diary and made some mistakes, albeit 47 mistakes in two cities. But, if in fact he put them in month by month and cannot, as a minister, remember where he was in the previous month and has such an incompetent diary or incompetent staff, doubts remain about Mr Sharp and these travel allowance claims.

The original story that sort of floated out was that this was the odd Thursday night, yet in March 1996 we see he claimed four nights in a row in Canberra. That was four in a row when he was not here, according to his own admissions now. The next week he claims two, has a night off and claims another two, yet these are apparently inadvertent errors.

How can you claim eight nights in Sydney at $320 a night when you were not there but thought you were there? It is all very well to radio the air traffic controllers and demand priority entry into Sydney—so we know he does go there—but how could he claim eight nights scattered over this period, including two in a row, and not remember? You see, when he comes to defend himself, inadver tence is going to be difficult. But, if the government comes clean at last and tables both forms, we can at least measure whether there is some credibility to his argument about inadvertence, poor memory, poor diary or poor work there.

Senator Faulkner hit it right on the head tonight when he said that the first person in the gun is Mr Jull. This is the same Mr Jull who was happy to release Labor ministers' travel allowance on three occasions. First of all, we were criticised for not putting out the 1994-95 figures. So the moment Mr Jull came to office he published them. He then did not wait until the normal August period for the 1995‐96 figures; he put them out in June and drew attention to them. Finally, when he published all the annual ones, having delayed his own first three months for nine months—a lot longer than we ever have—he republished them for the third time in case anyone missed them.

I will tell you something else he did two weeks ago. When he published ministerial and office holder travel allowance and other expenses in the House of Representatives, he had his office draw up a one-page anonymous document and sent it round the gallery trying to highlight what he saw was any embarrassment to the opposition. He did that. He started the war. So never look across to us and say that we are starting the war on this. He did it, but he did it anonymously through his office two weeks ago—Thursday, the last day of sitting here. He did that.

I remember Senator Herron saying, `What did your blokes do?' This has to be understood: the repayments that were made by Labor ministers were for claims made after the election policy speech, and they only had a moral, not a legal, obligation to refund it. Senator Minchin claimed 11. Did we ever mention it in this chamber? Never. Senator Macdonald claimed some and repaid. We did not raise it as an issue. Someone on our side claimed. You could argue that it was official duty, you could argue it was campaign duty. So they repaid. They thought, `Let us have the cleanest system possible. There is some doubt in this. We will repay.'

BREAK.PARA: What does Mr Jull do when it comes to publishing the figures? Here are the figures. He puts an inverted `v' next to each of the claims of the Labor ministers saying the following: `Amount which the former member or minister has indicated was legitimately claimed, but for which he was repaid or intends to repay.' Again: `Amounts which the member has indicated were legitimately claimed but the member intends to pay.' He drew attention to it for Labor members. Their equivalents, the shadow ministers, who were paid out of the House of Representatives and had paid back money—not one iota of attention was drawn to them in the House of Representatives.

Having set the standard two weeks ago, which he may say is only appropriate for ministers and office holders, when he published in the House of Representatives all the office holders' money, did he put a little asterisk next to the biggest refunder of all, bigger than Senator Colston? Does he do that? He puts in the amended figure of $20,000 and does not put in a note that the minister has repaid a certain amount of money—not even an amount. Why not? He was trying to cover up. He did not want attention drawn to this. That is why he did it, and it is shameful behaviour by a minister.

The Minister for Administrative Services does have a slightly higher ethical responsibility to parliament because he is given a whole range of confidential material to do with all of us, and therefore he should try to be a little more impartial than he has been. But constantly what we have had out of the minister's office are these sorts of smarmy attempts to smear the opposition while covering up for any inadvertence in government ranks.

TALK.START.PARA: —And yet you give him our travelling allowances.

—As I said at the start, there is some doubt—you might listen to this, Senator Harradine—about Mr Sharp. It is the accountability that is important here, in an adversarial sense; that we can make them accountable where it is much harder in the Senate. But that is an argument and a discussion we can have another time, which you concede.

BREAK.PARA: But if there is some doubt about Mr Sharp's future, there are a lot more doubts about Mr Jull. This is unethical behaviour: to highlight other ministers of another government who have repaid money and not to highlight yourself. This has been an absolutely consistent pattern of behaviour. What we would like Mr Jull to do in five minutes time, when he goes into the other place and makes his statement, is table both sets of forms so we can make a judgment, so we can see when Mr Sharp signed these off—whether it was six or eight months later, when memory may have dimmed, when mistakes were possible. But I tell you what: if you claimed, as here, some nights in Sydney right towards the end of the month and signed the form off four days later, you can remember whether you were in Sydney or not. All the evasions that we are getting now: the confusion about the 100 kilometres; the confusion about whether he was in Goulburn on a Thursday night or whether in Canberra—all these disseminating little bits put out in the gallery, all these misleaders, can be forensically examined and he can be brought to account for them.

As John Faulkner has said, the real case here is why Mr Jull did not draw this to our attention two weeks ago when he published this figures, when he did for others, and why it took a leak from the Department of Administrative Services and a journalist to expose this. He might explain the nature of the conversation he had with Mr Howard yesterday when he was called in to discuss these particular matters in Mr Howard's office. He may like to explain why he made no statement earlier in the day, until he found out that this was going to be on the Channel Nine news tonight and in the Bulletin tomorrow, why he did not come clean and explain these particular things. Until he does, I have to say Mr Sharp's future is doubtful, but Mr Jull's future is extremely gloomy.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 June 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to Forestry Tasmania advertising a `tree trust', which effectively `gives' land to `growers' to plant trees, with the costs and revenues from the plantations established being shared by Forestry Tasmania and the `grower':
(1) Is Forestry Tasmania subject to Commonwealth taxes; if so, please detail the categories of activity which are taxable and whether the taxation is `notional'.

(2) (a) Will `growers', under the scheme advertised by Forestry Tasmania, be able to deduct the costs of plantation establishment from their taxable income; and (b) what factors would be considered in deciding whether the plantation establishment costs are deductible.
(3) If native vegetation is cleared to establish the plantations, does this have any bearing on potential tax deductibility of the costs of plantation establishment.

(4) What similarities or differences are there in the tree trust scheme being promoted by Forestry Tasmania and earlier schemes involving the sale and lease‐back of public assets where the resulting tax benefits were disallowed by the Australian Taxation Office.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (the Act) (s16) do not permit the disclosure or communication of information in respect of the affairs of another person. It is therefore not possible to discuss specifically the affairs of Forestry Tasmania. The Act does, however, assess a resident on all gross income received where that income is not exempt or the resident is not exempt.

(2) (a) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) does not provide general rulings in respect of specific arrangements and therefore it is not possible to say generally whether or not the `growers' are entitled to a deduction for the costs of plantation establishment. Requests for a private ruling will be considered.

(2) (b) The ATO is soon to issue a draft Taxation Ruling in respect of afforestation schemes. This will clarify what factors are to be considered when deciding whether or not plantation establishment costs are deductible. The critical factors can be summarised as:

. the `grower' should be in the business of growing and harvesting for sale forest trees or timber. For this they need to have an interest in specific trees, carry out the afforestation activities or have someone else carry out those activities on their behalf, and the activities should have a significant commercial purpose in view of their nature, size, scale and repetition.

. for a deduction to be allowed in the first year the work to be performed under the agreements should be completed within 13 months of the executing of those agreements. If not the deduction will be allowed over the shorter of the term of the agreement or 10 years.
. the `grower' should intend to stay in the project for its full term.
. the `grower' should not have a dominant purpose of obtaining a tax benefit through being involved in the project.
. the initial fees should not be excessive in relation to the cost of the work to be performed.
. there should not be a limited recourse loan where the cash does not actually flow to fund the cost of doing the agreed work.
(3) The cost of clearing the land of native vegetation is a capital cost and is therefore not deductible to the `grower'.
(4) A review of the prospectus issued for the scheme currently being promoted by Forestry Tasmania does not reveal a sale and lease back arrangement for any public assets.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 23 June 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Can a breakdown be provided of how funding under the $19 million National Youth Suicide Strategy was spent in New South Wales by: (a) organisation; (b) region; and (c) electorate.

(2) Can a breakdown be provided of how funding under the $19 million National Youth Suicide Strategy was spent in all States and Territories, except New South Wales by: (a) organisation; (b) region; and (c) electorate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As stated in the answer to Parliamentary Question Number 556, some $6 million has been provided to States and Territories for rural and regional youth counselling services. That funding is being distributed as set out in the answer to Question Number 556. Final allocation to regions, subject to the project guidelines, is a State and Territory government responsibility. As the projects are in the early stages of development and not all the funding has yet been allocated within States and Territories, it is not yet possible to obtain a complete regional or electoral breakdown from State and Territory governments.

In addition, a further $1.5 million is being allocated to States and Territories to support education and training programs for health professionals. These funds are allocated as follows: $300,000 for each of New South Wales and Victoria; $200,000 for Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia; and $100,000 for Tasmania and the Territories. Information on the allocation of these funds within States is not available at present.
Some $6 million is being provided to Lifeline and Kid's Help Line for the enhancement of over the phone support programs on a national basis.
Of the remaining funding, some $300,000 was allocated through a tender process to the Hunter Institute of Psychiatry to develop national university curricula.
Some $4.2 million—$3 million for parenting activity, $1 million for research and $200,000 for education and training—has yet to be tendered.
Note: While the funds allocated to the projects described above total $18 million, they represent a total of $19 million in out‐turned prices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 4 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Australian Red Cross (ARC) or any of its blood banks or CSL Ltd (formerly Commonwealth Serum Laboratories) ever undertaken research or collaborated in research with another party to produce a vaccine against any form of hepatitis which has been made from human plasma or any other human blood constituents; if so: (a) from whom was the material derived and how were donors attracted; (b) was any foreign plasma used; (c) was any foreign plasma mixed with local plasma; (d) when was the research carried out; (e) at whose request was it undertaken; (f) what did the research involve; and (g) if the research was discontinued: (i) what was the reason; and (ii) can documentation be provided.

(2) Has the ARC or any of its blood banks or CSL Ltd ever manufactured or attempted to manufacture a vaccine against any form of hepatitis, made from human plasma or any other blood constituents; if so: (a) how many treatment doses were produced and from what volume of starting material; (b) what were the dates of manufacture; (c) what manufacturing method was used; (d) was material locally derived, obtained overseas or a mixture; and (e) what methods were used to render the material safe from unwanted pathogens.

(3) Has the ARC or any of its blood banks or CSL Ltd ever trialled its own or any other manufacturer's vaccine against hepatitis made from human plasma or other blood constituents; if so: (a) when and where were the trials conducted and how many subjects were involved; (b) how was participation and consent obtained; (c) what were the results of the trial(s); and (d) what follow‐up monitoring was undertaken to check for unwanted results; (e) can evidence of follow‐up monitoring be provided including when it was done and excluding identifying details of consumers.

(4) Has the ARC or any of its blood banks or CSL Ltd ever distributed another's vaccine against hepatitis made from human plasma or other blood constituents; if so: (a) how many doses were distributed and on what dates; (b) to whom and for whom were they distributed; (c) what were the results of the treatment; (d) what follow‐up monitoring was undertaken to check for unwanted results; and (e) can evidence of follow‐up monitoring be provided including when it was done and excluding identifying details of consumers.

(5) Has any Red Cross Blood Bank in Australia, knowing that blood or blood products in its possession were likely to be contaminated with the HIV/AIDS virus, or having grounds to believe that blood or blood products in its possession were presumptively contaminated with the HIV/AIDS virus, distributed or allowed the distribution of these products for use in humans.

(6) Has CSL Ltd, the manufacturer of blood products for Australian use, ever distributed or allowed the distribution of blood products for human use in Australia or overseas when any of its officials knew or had grounds for believing that the products were or were likely to be contaminated with the HIV/AIDS virus.
(7) Before the introduction in Australia of HIV/AIDS testing on blood, what steps did CSL take to treat plasma and other blood constituents to inactivate the HIV virus and can details be provided.
(8) What research was undertaken by CSL to determine what inactivation steps could and should be done.
(9) What method was used to inactivate HIV in: (a) plasma pools; (b) clotting fractions; and (c) other blood constituents.
(10) In what month and year was heating commenced for (a), (b) and (c) in (9).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The answers are based upon information supplied by the Australian Red Cross Society (ARC), former officers of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission (CSLC) and information held within the Department.
(4) ARC—No.

CSLC distributed a H‐B‐Vax, hepatitis B vaccine manufactured by Merck Sharp and Dohme (Australia) Pty Ltd, which was based on hepatitis B surface antigen, a non infectious viral protein harvested from plasma in which it was present and subjected to a 3 stage inactivation process.
(a) Several thousand doses between April 1983 and March 1988.
(b) To hospitals and pharmaceutical wholesalers for use in persons at substantial risk of hepatitis B virus infection.
(c) Protection against infection with hepatitis B virus.

(d) The conditions of approval of H‐B‐Vax in Australia included a requirement that the sponsor company forward to the Adverse Drug Reactions Advisory Committee (ADRAC) details of all Australian reports of suspected adverse reactions to the vaccine. This was, and remains, a standard condition applied to the registration of new medicines and vaccines. There was no additional requirement for special post‐marketing or follow‐up monitoring in Australia.

In addition to this requirement, health professionals were, as at present, encouraged to report any suspected adverse reactions to drugs and vaccines to ADRAC. In contrast to the obligation on the manufacturer, reporting by health professionals is not compulsory. ADRAC then reviews all reports from sponsor companies and health professionals and may recommend that the sponsor take appropriate action.

(e) In respect of the hepatitis B vaccine, there were 65 suspected adverse reactions in Australia reported to and considered by ADRAC during the period 1983 to 1988. About half the reports specified H‐B‐Vax as the suspected product. The other half described suspected reactions to "hepatitis B vaccine". It is highly likely that all the reports submitted prior to late 1987 related to the plasma derived Merck product as it was the only vaccine registered for use in Australia. It is possible that some of the reports submitted during late 1987 and 1988 related to use of a non‐plasma derived, recombinant vaccine, which became available at that time.

The reported local and systemic adverse reactions were consistent with the description in the H‐B‐Vax product information which was based principally on the clinical trial experience available when H‐B‐Vax was recommended for approval by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee in 1982, but which was also updated by the sponsor in the light of international experience.
(7) From November 1984 Factor VIII and Factor IX concentrates were both heated in the dry state at 60/C for 72 hours.
(8) CSLC began heat studies on Factor VIII concentrates in February 1984. Collaboration was established with Hyland Laboratories and the Centres for Disease Control (both in the USA).
(9) (a) None. To maintain biological activity, viral inactivation of plasma products occurs after plasma has been processed.
(b) See (7) above.

(c) Albumin has been pasteurised since the 1940's and this step inactivates the HIV virus. There are no viral inactivation steps in respect to CSL's intramuscular immunoglobulins. However, it should be noted that there have been no reports of viral transmission associated with immunoglobulins produced by the methods used at CSL. The manufacture of intravenous immunoglobulin products includes a low pH incubation step which has viral inactivation properties for HIV and which has been validated.
(10) (a) Not applicable.
(b) November 1984.
(c) Albumin in the 1940's and for intravenous immunoglobulins, a viral inactivation step was validated in late 1989.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that Murdoch University is proposing to lease part of its campus to Mobil Oil Australia Ltd to build a service station, convenience store, fast food outlet, icecream kiosk, lottery and newspaper agency, dry‐cleaning shop and liquor store.
(2) Is the Minister aware that local residents and the local government authority have expressed concern to the university about this proposal.

(3) (a) Is the Minister aware that there are three other service stations within one kilometre of the university, including one directly across the road from the university's front entrance; and (b) does the Minister have concerns about the proposal.

(4) Is the Minister concerned that this sort of development could set a precedent for other universities to make quick profits by leasing part of their land for commercial developments and that these developments are not subject to the usual local government approval process.
(5) Are developments such as this an appropriate use of public land which is reserved for education.
(6) Could such developments cause anxiety in the community and undermine the profitability of other small businesses which are required to comply with local government regulations.
(7) Is any action being planned to review or reject the university's proposal for commercial development of its campus; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Minister for Justice

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am not aware of Murdoch University's proposal to lease part of its campus. My Department has also informed me that the University's Education Profile for the 1997‐2000 period does not refer to this proposal.
(2) I am not, nor is my Department, aware that concern has been expressed in the local community about the proposal.
(3) (a) I am not, nor is my Department, aware that there are three other service stations within one kilometre of the university.

(3) (b) The Commonwealth has no concerns regarding the commercial developments undertaken by universities providing that they are consistent with the National Competition Principles. The principles require the elimination of any net competitive advantages or disadvantages that publicly owned or funded organisations enjoy simply as a result of their public sector ownership or support. Significant progress has been made in developing a framework to implement these principles. Specifically, the Ministerial Council for Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (of which I am a member) recently endorsed a coordinated policy position for the implementation of competition policy in the higher education sector. One of the principles agreed by the Council is that:
. those activities that are purely commercial, such as property development and manufacturing for retail or wholesale, should be structur ally separate and subject to a fully commercial regime.
(4) Universities are established under State Legislation and accordingly issues relating to the use of University land are the responsibility of the State Government.
(5) This issue regarding location of commercial activities should be directed to the Western Australian Government and Local Government Authorities.

(6) The Commonwealth expects that universities comply with all Local and State Government regulations. However, the compliance with Local Government regulations by universities is a matter that should be taken up with the relevant Local Government authority and the State Government.
(7) As mentioned above, university land is a State responsibility and this issue must be taken up with the State Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 4 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why are only those members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces (BCOF) who served in Japan between 3 January 1949 and 30 June 1951 being granted eligibility to disability pension and treatment, and not those BCOF members who served outside those dates.
(2) On what supporting evidence did the Government rely to decide on those dates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Service in the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (BCOF) in Japan commenced on 13 February 1946 and extended up to and including 27 April 1952. Australian members of the BCOF did not arrive in Japan until February 1946, some five months after hostilities with Japan ceased.
All members of BCOF, up to 3 January 1949, have been, and will continue to be, eligible to claim a disability pension and associated treatment under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

There was a period of service from 3 January 1949 to 30 June 1951 inclusive when different members of the ADF within BCOF received different compensation cover for undertaking the same type of service.

By virtue of the conditions of their enlistment, Australian Imperial Forces and Interim Forces personnel who served with BCOF were covered for repatriation benefits up until 30 June 1951 at which time they became covered by the former Commonwealth employees compensation legislation.

However, similar repatriation cover for personnel who enlisted in the Permanent Defence Force ceased on 2 January 1949 when the former Commonwealth employees compensation legislation was introduced. As the result of a Government election commitment a review was conducted by the Department of Defence which found that the different treatment of members of the Permanent Defence Force, who served with BCOF, constitutes an anomaly and that these members should also be eligible for disability pension and treatment cover, under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, for the period 3 January 1949 to 30 June 1951.

Passage of the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Budget and Compensation Measures) Bill 1997 will remove the anomaly by providing the same disability compensation benefits for all members of BCOF.
(2) My Department relied on the advice of the Department of Defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 20 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that a spacecraft named Cassini is due to be launched on 6 October 1997 by the National Aeronautics Space Agency (NASA) from Cape Kennedy, Florida, for a Saturn-bound mission, and that the instruments on this spacecraft are powered by radioisotope thermoelectric generators (RTG) fuelled by 72.3 pounds of plutonium, an amount in excess of the total plutonium released into the atmosphere by all of the open nuclear tests combined.

(2) Is the Minister aware that: (a) out of 24 previous NASA missions, three satellites have crashed either on lift-off or during re-entry into the atmosphere, namely a 1 in 8 failure; (b) this resulted in the release of radioactivity in to the atmosphere; and (c) that out of 39 missions by the former USSR, 6 spacecraft have crashed with similar results.
(3) Is the Minister aware of the acute toxicity of plutonium, and that medical authorities indicate that the inhalation of one-millionth of a gram is enough to result in lung cancer.

(4) Has the Minister seen NASA's up-to-date environmental impact statement regarding Cassini, and (b) can a report be given to parliament on the odds calculated by NASA for failure on lift-off, for accidental re-entry into the atmosphere during the spacecraft's gravity swing manoeuvre around the Earth and for release of plutonium into the atmosphere.
(5) Is the Minister aware that the development of new sensitive solar cells by the European Space Agency obviates the need for the use of plutonium-fuelled RTG's in space missions.

(6) In view of the high probability of fatal contamination of the atmosphere and biosphere by accidental release of plutonium from spacecraft, which poses a fatal risk to Australians as well as other people, will the Government consider requesting the United States of American and NASA to postpone despatching plutonium-bearing spacecraft pending the application of safe solar cells.

(7) In the event of a decline of such a request by the US and NASA, will the Minister consider an injunction to the World Court of Justice in the Hague, by the Australian Government, in order to delay the launch of Cassini, as has been done by the United Nations in the context of atmospheric nuclear tests, and in view of the similar nature of the health effects of these tests and the accidental release of plutonium for plutonium-fuelled spacecraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Brown's question raises issues which fall within the portfolio responsibilities of both the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism and myself. As such, I have consulted with my colleague, The Hon John Moore MP, about this matter and the following reply represents the Government's response.

(1) I am aware that a spacecraft named Cassini is due to be launched no earlier than 6 October 1997 by the National Aeronautics Space Agency (NASA) from Cape Canaveral, Florida, for a Saturn-bound mission. Because the Cassini spacecraft will be operating at a distance from the sun that makes the use of solar power systems not feasible, Cassini's electrical power source will be provided by Radioisotope Thermoelectric Generators (RTGs). RTGs provide power through the natural radioactive decay of plutonium (mostly Pu-238, a non-weapons grade isotope). RTGs are not nuclear reactors, have no moving parts, and use neither fission nor fusion processes to produce energy. Cassini will employ three RTGs, each of which will carry 10.8 kg (23.8 lb) of plutonium dioxide fuel.

(2) Launch reliability should be considered with respect to the launch vehicle being used for Cassini, in this case the Titan IV launch vehicle. As of February 1997, there have been 20 Titan IV launches, of which 19 have been successful. The single failure, in August 1993, was due to a flaw in one of the solid rocket motors which was caused by an inadequate repair procedure following manufacture. This problem has been fixed. I am advised that since RTG's were redesigned in 1965, to prevent the release of radioactive material, there have been two accidents during NASA missions where RTG's were on board. These were the 1968 NIMBUS-B satellite launch and the 1970 Apollo 13 lunar module re-entry. In both cases the plutonium fuel was fully contained.

(3) Plutonium is a hazardous material and if a small particle is inhaled, there is a chance that a cancer may result from long term radiation exposure. However, the risk to human health as a result of the Cassini launch is extremely low because of the design of the fuel and the RTG's.

The following should be noted with respect to the plutonium fuel aboard Cassini: The fuel is divided among 18 small independent modular units, each with its own heat shield and impact shell to reduce the chances of fuel release in an accident. In addition, multiple layers of protective materials are used to protect the fuel and prevent its accidental dispersion. The fuel itself is in a heat-resistant, ceramic form, which reduces its chance of vaporising in an accidental fire or in re-entry environments. The fuel is also highly insoluble, has a low chemical reactivity, and primarily fractures into large, non-respirable particles and chunks. This would mitigate the potential health effects in the unlikely event of an accident involving the release of this fuel.

An extensive independent safety evaluation of the Cassini mission was performed as part of the nuclear launch safety approval process by an Inter-agency Nuclear Safety Review Panel, which is supported by experts from the US Government, industry and academia.

(4) (a) I am advised that the following environmental impact assessments have been produced in the USA: Final Environmental Impact Statement for the Cassini Mission (June 1995), Nuclear Safety Analyses for Cassini Mission Environmental Impact Statement Process (April 1997), and Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Statement for the Cassini Mission (June 1997). The Department of Industry, Science and Tourism holds a copy of the Cassini environmental impact statement (EIS). Neither I nor my Department have had reason to examine the EIS.

(b) Odds calculated by NASA are contained in the aforementioned reports. NASA's analysis estimates that the probability of an early launch accident is 1 in 160, the probability of a late launch accident is 1 in 48, the probability of an inadvertent earth re-entry is less than one in 1 million, and the probability for an accident releasing plutonium dioxide into the atmosphere is 1 in 19,200 for pre-launch phase, 1 in 1,490 for early launch, 1 in 476 for late launch, 1 in 1,250,000 for short term inadvertent re-entry, and 1 in 5,000,000 for long-term inadvertent re-entry.

(5) A Cassini spacecraft equipped with the highest efficiency solar cells available, or even the new high-efficiency cells under development by ESA, would make Cassini too massive for launching to Saturn. I am advised that the ESA scientists who developed the high-efficiency cells have stated that their cells would not enable a solar powered Cassini mission.

(6) In view of the circumstances outlined above the Government does not consider it appropriate to request the United States of America and NASA to postpone despatching plutonium-bearing spacecraft pending the application of safe solar cells.
(7) I do not consider an injunction to the World Court of Justice in the Hague on behalf of the Australian Government in order to delay the launch of Cassini is necessary or appropriate.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Women in Science: Engineering and Technology

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to paragraph (3) of the answer to question on notice no. 687, which stated that the Government `is not aware of any structural barriers to women participating in science, engineering and technology careers' even though in paragraph (1) of the same answer the government accepted it had examined the report entitled Women in Science, Engineering and Technology (also known as the WISET report): does this mean the government has rejected the WISET report.
(2) If the Government has not rejected the WISET report, are there any aspects of the report that the Government accepts.
(3) If the Government has rejected the WISET report, why has it done so.

(4) With reference to paragraph (3) of the answer to question on notice no. 687, which stated that the Government is not aware of any structural barriers to women participating in science, engineering and technology careers': will the Government examine the participation of women in science, engineering and technology careers to determine if there are any structural barriers.
(5) If there are structural barriers to the participation of women in science, engineering and technology careers, does this concern the Government: if so, what are the Government's concerns.

(6) Do structural barriers to the participation of women in science, engineering and technology careers affect the government's intention to create a broad, positive environment in which all Australians have the maximum opportunity to achieve their potential; if so, what are those effects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) See the answer to Senate question on notice no. 447, in Official Senate Hansard , 24 March 1997, pp2340‐1.
(2) See the answer to Senate question on notice no. 447, in Official Senate Hansard , 24 March 1997, pp2340‐1.
(3) See the answer to Senate question on notice no. 447, in Official Senate Hansard , 24 March 1997, pp2340‐1.

(4) Such an examination has been undertaken by the WISET Advisory Group. Despite repeated general reference to `structural barriers' in its report, it actually identified only one such barrier, namely a perceived `gender bias' in school curriculum materials. Whether this is a structural or an attitudinal barrier is debatable, and the WISET report itself notes that the issue has already been addressed.
(5) See the answer to paragraph (4) above.
(6) See the answer to paragraph (4) above.
